PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the minister that on Sunday Mr Keating said he had received the message sent by Canberrans during the weekend by-election, yet the very next day he belittled middle Australia by referring to the fact that they are concentrating on the `grindstone' of their mortgages when they should be, like him, concentrating on the big issues of the republic, Mabo and Aboriginal rights, and apparently our identity. I ask: does the minister understand that a fear of rising mortgage rates is a grindstone of middle class Australians? Is he prepared to express some sympathy about their plight in these uncertain times? Doesn't Mr Keating's callous and insensitive throwaway line really reflect the attitude of someone who lives rent and mortgage free in a government provided home?

—That is a grotesque caricature of the Prime Minister's position, and Senator Hill perfectly well knows it. Nobody in this government has been more conscious of the impact of economic mismanagement on ordinary Australians of the kind that occurred during the dark years of the Fraser-Howard period. No-one has been more conscious of the damage and the difficulty that are caused for people by a high inflation, low growth economy. Nobody is more conscious than the Prime Minister of the damage that flows from an economy that is inward looking, uncompetitive, unable to export and unable to generate the growth which generates the jobs which generates the standard of living maintenance in this country.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that we are all intensely conscious of the immediate and direct impact that interest rate hikes have on ordinary Australians and in particular mortgage holders. The Prime Minister is acutely conscious of that. He has said that, in terms of our budgetary aspirations at the moment, one of the key objectives is to put the kind of budget down which will make any upward move in interest rates far less likely. He said as much on the radio program PM just a couple of days ago. He is very conscious of the need, as we all are, of the budget to accomplish just that kind of pressure, operating in that kind of direction.

We are also committed, so far as the longer term objectives of the fiscal exercise are concerned, to significantly tightening fiscal policy in the May budget so as to boost national savings, reduce Australia's call on overseas capital and generally make that side of economic management far more manageable. They are the aspirations that we have articulated. That is where we expect to get.

The truth of the matter is that most Australians do understand that there is a necessity for growth in the Australian economy to be sustainable in character. Most Australians do understand that it is necessary accordingly on occasion to put on the brakes to ensure not that the economy comes to a halt but that it is maintainable at a sustainable momentum. It is like driving a car down the highway: if it is humanly possible, you try to organise your speed of approach to lights such that you keep on clicking through the green lights rather than having to stop and start at the red ones. That is exactly what we have been trying to do with the Australian economy—to so manage the dimensions of the economy that we do not have to bring the economy to a halt at a red light if we confront it, but to so organise the speed of the economic recovery and the sustainability of that recovery to ensure that we will go on clicking our way through green lights endlessly into the future. That is the objective and that is what we have been able to achieve.

The interest rate increases that were necessary last year were designed to slow down the economy from that kind of over-exaggerated momentum 12 to 18 months out which produces a stop-start economy. We want to avoid that at all costs, and the interest rate increases in the latter part of last year were designed to do just that. It may well be, when the latest national account figures come out and we get a full picture of the economy, that it will be proven to have achieved just that and that the remaining disciplines on the economy can be imposed only by fiscal policy without the necessity to go further at all so far as interest rates are concerned.

If that is possible, if that is attainable, that is a very much to be hoped for and very much to be looked for result, because, of course, we are conscious of the impact of high interest rates not only on borrowers in the business community but also, of course, on home owners. That is the perspective from which the government operates in this respect, and it is a gross caricature and a gross calumny of the Prime Minister to suggest that he thinks any differently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the minister of exactly what the Prime Minister said. He was talking about what might be referred to as middle Australians or mainstream Australians when he was belittling them. He said: `It is really down to the grindstone in the mortgage and nothing else.' He is talking about that in contrast to himself dealing with the big issues that face this country—the republic, our place in the world, and so forth. I put to the minister: why is the Prime Minister so out of touch? Why does he find it necessary apparently to continually talk down middle Australians, who are in fact battling with interest rates? Why does he not recognise that the policies of this government, as we saw in the late 1980s and we are seeing now again, are to continually push up interest rates to try to counter the current account and that in each instance it affects these people in middle Australia—ordinary Australians trying to pay off their mortgage? Why does he not demonstrate a little sensitivity towards their plight? And why don't you get up here and recognise it today and do likewise?

—Interest rates in Australia at the moment are at historically low levels by comparison with the experience of past decades. They are much lower than the levels that prevailed during the mid-1980s and there is no question whatsoever in anyone's mind, in any commentator's mind, that interest rates are headed back north in the direction they were in the mid- to late 1980s. The economy is in a much sounder fundamental shape now than it was then as a result of the decade long attention that we have paid to basic fundamental economic reform.

PARA.TAB: What we have got is a high growth, low inflation, high investment, increasingly high employment economy which is sustainable. To do that, to make it sustainable, there has had to be some small interest rate increase. We are all trying very hard indeed to ensure that that will not need to go any further.

To the extent that it may need to go further at some stage in an unpredictable future, it certainly will not have to go anything like as far as it has in the past. You know that, and everything else is just political crocodile tear shedding.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade with United States of America

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It is asked in circumstances where a very important delegation is going to America very soon led by you, Mr President, and Senator Troeth, who is very learned, may I say, in the area of the pastoral industry. Senator Colston is going too, and even I am going. Is the minister aware of recent comments by a designate of the United States Secretary for Agriculture, Mr Dan Glickman, referring to an Australian threat to the US grain industry? Is that a description that should be applied to the Australian rural industry?

—During the United States Senate confirmation hearings for Mr Glickman last week, Mr Glickman stated that the export enhancement program, known as the EEP program, was introduced `to meet the European, Canadian'—and to our astonishment he went on to say this—`and Australian threat.' I have since read a transcript of what Mr Glickman actually said, and I was pleased to see that he did temper his remark in a subsequent exchange with Senator Richard Lugar when Mr Glickman said that the Australian threat had `diminished in recent years'.

PARA.TAB: I will certainly go one step further than Mr Glickman did. An Australian threat in the sense of a subsidy has never existed. This has been acknowledged in all previous explanations that have been given by relevant people in the United States, up to and including, I might add, the President of the United States. Statements in the past have focused solely on the threat of subsidised exports from the European Union. In fact, Australia has received assurances at the highest level—as I have just said, from the President—that the interests of Australia as a non-subsidised competitor would be taken into account when EEP subsidies were allocated.

Australia is not an export subsidiser. It is Australia that has had to penetrate markets that have been corrupted primarily by the United States and the European Union. Moreover, it is difficult to imagine—it is not difficult; it is impossible given the facts—how Australia could ever constitute a threat to United States producers.

The major industry supported by the EEP is wheat. Australia currently supplies around 10 per cent of the world market compared with the 36 per cent supplied from the United States. As only the fourth largest supplier in the world, we are price takers. In good years—that is, non-drought years—there is a test to the limit of our wheat producing capacity. So there is little prospect of any expansion towards a dominant market share by Australia. It is simply not possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again.

—I do not have time, Senator Panizza. Why don't you listen instead? The only threat that Australia presents to the US grain industry is as an efficient competitor. That was the disturbing element about what Mr Glickman said.

PARA.TAB: It is this reality that appears to be the cause of some frustration for the Americans: for the billions of dollars that have been spent by American taxpayers on export subsidies since 1985, the US market share has stayed the same. So, if it is a test for United States taxpayers to put billions of dollars into subsidies to get a bigger share of the world market, I have to say that the EEP scheme has failed profoundly because the market share is the same now as it was in 1985.

Recent farm policy debate in the United States has revealed an emerging trend towards the US engaging in a far more aggressive export policy to capture world markets. Under recent legislative changes, the EEP can now be employed in markets other than those distorted by European Union subsidies. The government is concerned that the EEP not be used as a trade development tool or be allocated on a regional or global basis.

I understand that Mr Glickman, should the processes proceed satisfactorily, will be appointed as agriculture secretary before Easter. That being the case, both Senator McMullan and I will raise in our traditional letters of congratulations our concerns about Mr Glickman's perceptions of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Minister, were you, your staff or your department involved in any discussions concerning the issuance of offset credits for the benefit of Robert Burgess or an associated company? Did the offset credits flow from government contracts with McDonnell Douglas? Were you, your staff or department, or any other minister, involved in discussions with McDonnell Douglas in relation to this matter? What were the credits? What benefits flowed to Robert Burgess or his associated companies?

—The thrust of this question is very similar to a statement made in the Queensland parliament today by, I think, a National Party member. The thrust of the allegation is that I attended a meeting with McDonnell Douglas, IMS—
—It was a straight question.
—I will answer this because it goes to my probity, Senator Hill.
—There is no implication at all in the question.

—Implications have been raised here. I will deal with this straight after question time by way of a personal statement. I will go directly to the question, but Senator Hill should know that Senator Chapman has put a 54-part question on the Notice Paper that does contain some implications in regard to me. I have followed the full and proper procedure by trying to get answers to all 54 parts of that question, many of which do not directly concern me.

PARA.TAB: I have had absolutely no dealings with any company on defence offset programs in the last five years. I have had only one meeting with McDonnell Douglas, which was in my office one week ago to discuss the Goshawk for the lead-in fighter project that that company is involved in.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your staff?
—Neither have my staff been involved in any discussions on these matters with McDonnell Douglas, with IMS or with any of the other ones.
—Or the department?

—Obviously IMS was a legitimate defence company before certain people moved in on it. It did have dealings with the department and it would have had dealings over offsets. This is a matter of Federal Police investigation. No evidence of any criminal activity whatsoever has been turned up. Nevertheless, accusations having been made, properly they should be investigated. That is the procedure that is being followed.

PARA.TAB: I add: the reason these matters—I will go to this again after question time—are on the public record is that certain members of the Criminal Justice Commission of Queensland have deliberately put them in the public domain, betraying people's trust in its being a crime fighting authority.
Senator Chapman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you deny it. On 7 June 1994 you admitted as such in an interview with Murray Nicholl.
—I did not.
—Absolutely, and I will produce the transcript.
—Mr President, on a point of order: the minister refers to a transcript of an interview which I did last year—
—That is not a point of order.
—It is a point of order.
—It is not relevant and it is not a point of order.
—I have been misrepresented.
—Unless you have a point of order, be seated. Have you a point of order?
—The minister is misrepresenting—
—You will have a chance to do that later.
—I will do that later, Mr President.

—As I said, some allegations, which I will go to directly after question time, were raised about me. They are baseless. They have absolutely no substance at all. But the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission put those in the public domain with politicians and with reporters without checking them properly.
—Prove it.

—I will be in a position, if necessary, to name the person who put it in the public domain. By the way, I support the National Crime Authority and the CJC in their attacks on organised crime, but they will not achieve their end if they deliberately put in the public domain every rumour, every bit of scuttlebutt and every unsubstantiated allegation that comes around.

PARA.TAB: They do this on the justification that somehow, politically, they will be closed down if they do not. They have never been closed down, but it does not stop them doing it. These zealots who think they can affect public policy by putting lies on the public record are betraying the trust people put in them to do the very valuable job they are entrusted with. That is an absolutely disgraceful method of operation. Politicians and others will be victims of this as long as no-one stands up and nominates them doing it. That is what they have done.

In terms of dealings with any defence industry groups, I have led my life with full probity, Senator Chapman. Every meeting I have had with defence industry representatives has been in my office in Melbourne or Canberra with a staff member and a departmental official present at every meeting. You can go through my diary and find that that is the fact. It is most annoying when these sorts of allegations float around. It is very hard to nail them down when they are absolutely and categorically false. You have my absolute assurance on my reputation that that is the case. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Water Supply and Sewerage Systems in South Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I draw the minister's attention to the decision of the South Australian government to contract out the operation and maintenance of the South Australian water supply and sewerage systems. Is the minister aware that none of the four companies left in the bid is Australian owned or has majority Australian ownership? What impact on Australian industry development will there be if the water resources in the driest state in the driest continent are managed by a foreign owned or controlled company? Has industry expressed concern about the damage such a move by the South Australian government will cause?

—I am aware of the decision by the South Australian government to contract out its management and operation of the E&WS in South Australia. Many in industry, and some industry associations, have written to me voicing their concern about this approach. In the ring now, four consortia are bidding for the rights for this contract. All of them are foreign owned in the majority. Two of them are British and two of them are French. There are no Australian owned companies here.

PARA.TAB: The South Australian government has acted in a way in which it excludes the opportunity for Australian companies to be properly formed and to bid for this project. It is true that some of the foreign owned companies have minority Australian shareholding. It is very important in a matter as fundamental to an economy as water, waste water and solid waste management that there be, in this strategic area of the economy, Australian ownership—at least for the majority of the operation—and in a way in which international skills can certainly be captured and utilised to Australian advantage, but under Australian ownership.

Those companies that have a minority Australian participation in them do so on the construction or financing side. Significantly, they do not have it in the area of technology, in the area of solid or liquid waste management or in the area of water management skills overall. This is a shame given that Australia has a number of very internationally competitive companies which are skilled in the area of water management, waste water management and solid and liquid waste management. Some of them, on the environmental technology side of their operations, have won international contracts overseas. They are excluded under this operation.

In my view, the principle that should operate here for a key strategic area of the economy is that it is for Australian companies to employ foreign skills under Australian ownership rather than leasing off key operations of Australian strategic importance to foreign companies employing Australian skills to their advantage. It is a fundamental question of industry policy and the development of capability in Australian industry that that principle be observed. This is not the principle that the South Australian government is observing. If it continues down its course, then this strategic area of the economy will effectively be in foreign hands and dominated by foreign companies.

As I have said, I have written to Mr Olsen about that. I have not at this point got a reply from him. So today, we try to clarify the great mystery on industry policy in Australia—where does the federal opposition stand? It is a mystery because no-one from the opposition benches has ever asked me a question, as industry minister, on industry policy; nor has anyone asked Mr Lee in the House of Representatives a question on industry policy and nor has anyone raised any questions on industry policy.

I have written to Mr Howard today and asked him to intervene in South Australia, and asked Dean Brown to stand up for Australian companies in this strategic area of the economy. Mr Howard can no longer hide behind the arras and pretend he has no policy. He is now being called forth to say where he does stand on a fundamental question of strategic ownership of a national resource. Is he in favour of losing Australian skills and technology overseas, or is he in favour of developing industry policy that cultivates them in Australia for Australians? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I draw the minister's attention to the recent survey by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia. Minister, do you agree with the survey's findings that the Commonwealth collected $3.8 billion in taxes on alcohol and tobacco in 1993-94 but spent only $36.4 million on specific drug and alcohol programs and services? If so, what is the explanation for that gap, considering that drug and alcohol abuse costs the Australian community at least $20 million a year? Finally, while the states and territories spend somewhere between 2.9 per cent and 24 per cent of what they collect for such programs and services on those services and the Commonwealth manages only one per cent, is it not about time for a considerable increase in the Commonwealth's financial commitment to education, intervention, treatment, research and other drug and alcohol related programs?

—First of all, I have to say that I have not seen the report by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council. I do not know the accuracy of those figures, but I have no reason to dispute the collection of $3.8 billion from an excise on tobacco and alcohol. The implication of the question is why we are spending only $34 million and not all of the excise on the treatment of drug and alcohol abuse. That is to misunderstand what the collection of excise is for. It is for general revenue and the allocation by government to a whole lot of its priority programs; it is not to re-route that money straight back to alcohol and tobacco programs.

PARA.TAB: The amount that the states and territories choose to spend from the amounts they collect in their own revenue is a matter for the states and territories. It is interesting to note on the figures Senator Lees provides that there is a very big difference from one state to another if the figures are 2.9 to 24 per cent. She then says that the Commonwealth spends only one per cent of its budget. I will certainly check that figure. I have not been provided with any detailed analysis of that one per cent figure.

But it is true that the Commonwealth is also quite considerably involved in a variety of programs dealing with the difficulties of managing not only illicit drugs but also licit drugs, particularly alcohol and tobacco. It does that through a number of its national programs and research. It also assists, other than by allocated dollars, through an anti-smoking or anti-alcohol strategy. I will certainly see whether there is any detailed information I can provide for Senator Lees. But to conclude that we should churn back into the campaign against smoking and alcohol abuse the $3 billion we raise from excise is to misunderstand the intent of our excise collection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister, but that surely leaves open this question: does she believe the Commonwealth has any responsibility to put at least some money back? I am certainly not talking about all of it; we are looking at a realistic level in the states of putting four or five per cent back into drug and alcohol related programs. If the Commonwealth is not going to do that, those people will frequently end up in our hospital system, which is the most expensive end of our health service, as a whole range of services will be missing. I ask the minister: does the Commonwealth not have some responsibility? Is not the very small amount of money put back—it is about $2 per head; compare that with the Northern Territory, which is putting back $55 per head of what it raises in drug and alcohol taxes—only a fraction of what is needed?
—They drink more up there.

—I will try to resist what Senator Schacht said by interjection, which is that perhaps the Northern Territory is addressing a serious alcohol problem in the Territory. Therefore, it focuses more money on its services.

PARA.TAB: As I say, I do not have a detailed brief. I will certainly see if there is anything I can get for Senator Lees in terms of a government response in this area. The Commonwealth spends money on prevention. It is very strongly committed to health promotion and the prevention of illness and disease. It is clearly understood by government that if it can prevent large, expensive hospitalisation by way of treatment down the illness trail post long-time cigarette use or post alcohol abuse, it is a much better thing to do. It is not only more efficient for government; it is much better for the health of the community.

The Commonwealth is committed. It has already put a large number of national dollars into national health promotion and disease prevention. I will see whether I can find anything further for Senator Lees.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister confirm that, despite Australian representations, both Indonesia and Malaysia are still resisting an indefinite extension of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty? If so, what reasons have these states given Australia for their opposition? Is Australia still supporting an indefinite extension, despite the views of regional neighbours? If so, why? Is the minister aware of the arguments presented by democratic South Africa at the fourth preparatory conference which suggest that so-called rolling fixed extensions are permissible under article 10 of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty? Does Australia, despite its view on indefinite extension, concur with South Africa that rolling fixed extensions are permissible? If so, why? If not, why not?

—As I think I have said before, the question of the non-proliferation treaty review and extension conference, commencing in three weeks in New York, is probably the most important issue facing the international community this year. It is crucially important to get this one right. Australia is very firmly continuing to argue for an indefinite extension of that treaty. We do so essentially for three reasons. First, so far as the nuclear weapons states are concerned, we think that indefinite extension will offer far and away the most encouragement for them to continue the process of disarmament and nuclear arms reduction on which they have already embarked. It will enable this far more so than at any previous time under the START I and II treaties and related measures of that kind. The uncertainty generated by a non-indefinite extension and the prospect of proliferation elsewhere would be the last thing calculated to encourage that process to proceed.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, so far as the twilight zone countries are concerned—I will not name them, but I think we know who they are—who are either thought to have nuclear weapons, although not declared, or are on the threshold of being able to do so, again it is our very firm view that indefinite extension is far and away the best way to maintain the discipline on them not to go any further or hopefully to wind back. If you create an environment in which intellectual credibility is given to the possibility of proliferation being allowed and not outlawed by the international community, you do not help in any way maintain the pressure on those twilight zone states.

Thirdly, so far as those other countries which have no intention ever of getting into the nuclear arms business but want access to peaceful nuclear technology and material supplies are concerned, again indefinite extension is the best environment within which they can be guaranteed supply, their needs satisfied and their political willingness accordingly to support the maintenance of non-proliferation of weapons can be maintained.

In a nutshell, they are the reasons why we are supporting indefinite extension. It has nothing to do with the fact that those arguments have also appealed to a number of the existing nuclear weapon states. We make our own judgment about these things and we are continuing to work hard at that.

To answer your specific question, it is the case that neither Indonesia nor Malaysia has yet reached a final position on the question of NPT extension. They are reserving their positions, and a number of countries like them are expected to do so, until the actual parties make their decision, which will not be until around the second week of May.

I have been very actively involved, personally and through correspondence, in lobbying a number of these countries, not just in our own region, and I will continue to do that. There are a number of regional countries which have already expressed strong support for indefinite extension including Japan, the Philippines, the Republic of Korea and the member states of the South Pacific Forum.

As to your last question about South Africa, it may well be the case that the kind of extension that it is talking about with rolling fixed extensions is permissible under the terms of article 10 of the treaty. Article 10 identifies several different options for extension after this current period has expired, as it has—that is, indefinite, fixed or for fixed periods. That is not the point. The argument is not whether it is legally permissible to come up with one or other of these models—and South Africa, to our knowledge, has not firmly advocated any particular position; it is just stating an option—the argument is about the policy choices that we should be making. For all the reasons I have already indicated, Australia is of the very firm view that that policy choice ought to be for indefinite extension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the minister says that Australia is of the very firm view, which government departments had an input to this discussion on Australia's position on the NPT? Did this decision receive cabinet approval?

—I am not aware of the precise consultative process that was followed, but this is a matter in which a number of departments, including Defence, Primary Industries and Energy and Environment, would have an interest. I am not aware of any suggestion that anyone within the Australian governmental community has any different view about this. There is a romantic view around the place, which I am familiar with in dealing with a number of other countries, that the best way to maintain leverage on the nuclear weapons states to continue the process of disarmament is to go down the path of a fixed period extension with review periods.

PARA.TAB: I am familiar with the arguments, but I am simply saying that I do not accept them and the government does not accept them. That is a firm government position and the reasons are not just a reflex response; they are a matter of considered attention to the dynamics of this whole process and what is best likely to guarantee for us a minimum nuclear proliferation world. The treaty has served us remarkably well. I think I have said before that we could have expected by now 25 or 30 countries to have nuclear weapons. The fact that there are fewer than that is a triumph for the treaty and we want to keep it going. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Post-Mortem on Suspected Toxic Shock Victim

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Will the minister confirm that on 13 March 1995 she distributed to selected journalists a precis in all its detail of a post-mortem on a 13-year-old Mareeba girl, and suspected toxic shock victim, without the knowledge of the girl's parents and in contravention of all privacy considerations? Will the minister further confirm that the inquest has not yet been held and will not be held until 23 May this year? How did the minister obtain details of the post-mortem? Does the minister acknowledge that her distribution of these very private details of the post-mortem has caused considerable distress to the family? Will the minister acknowledge that as Minister for Family Services she has betrayed the trust of those people who asked her to help them in educating Australian women on the dangers emanating from the use of tampons and the resultant risk of toxic shock syndrome?

—This is a real tragedy, particularly for that family in Queensland. As a result of that death and a story on the 7.30 Report, I immediately asked for an inquiry of the Therapeutic Goods Authority about tampons and any standards that we had in this country so that I could make a report to Australia about whether or not our tampons are safe and other matters that relate to it. At the same time, I was able to incorporate into that a report from Standards Australia about standards for Australian tampons. I think that report was made public on the Friday before 13 March; I will have to check the date.

PARA.TAB: The TGA reports to me that Australian tampon standards are very safe. Australian women should feel very assured on that matter. Its report is contrary to the information provided on the 7.30 Report, which showed claims by an American doctor that our tampons are not safe. Australia is the only country to have a national standard for tampons. As a result of the reports from Standards Australia and the TGA, I have asked the Therapeutic Goods Authority to get back to me as quickly as possible with a report that does two things. Firstly, it allows me to mandate safe standards on the manufacture of tampons and, secondly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. This is all useful information, and it might be given afterwards. The question that was asked, which should be answered, was whether Senator Crowley distributed to selected journalists a precis of a post-mortem on a 13-year-old girl without the permission of her parents.

—If you want the answer in that order, I will do that. I thought it would be much more useful to give you the background as to why on 13 March I called a press conference and released to the community at large and to the media a three-page summary that contained absolutely no information going to the personal history of that girl—neither her name nor any other information. That three-page history contained the information I was telling you. Since you put it like this and you want that direct answer and not the information about tampons or any of the other serious matters, I shall give it to you. There was a three-page summary, and it did not contain any of that private information.

—On a point of order: Mr President, on numerous occasions you have used as a reason for not bringing that side into line the fact that questions have contained some sort of invective or inducement to be offensive in return. I put it to you that Senator O'Chee's question did not contain any such dramatisation of events. Yet you allow a minister to answer a question and impute that the questioner has a motive and a lack of interest in other matters, even though that is not what the minister was asked. Mr President, you cannot have it both ways. I ask you to direct the minister to give a relevant answer to the question without offering gratuitous comments about what other things she thinks Senator O'Chee may or may not be interested in.

—On the point of order: Senator Crowley has responded to what was clearly a loaded question from Senator O'Chee with great dignity, great restraint, great sensitivity and great accuracy. These are nonsensical points of order that have been made. Senator Crowley should be allowed to get on with giving what is a very clear, straightforward, good and impressive answer.
—It is just that.

—What Senator Vanstone may not know and I certainly do is just how some of this material became public in Queensland. I was not prepared to put that on the public record, nor was I prepared to name this child. These things have not come from me. This is a campaign that has been whipped up and I have preferred to keep well away from it because of the pain and hurt it might do to that family. I do not wish to buy into this at all.

PARA.TAB: There was a more detailed and comprehensive report that went to the matters of the safety of tampons and how they are manufactured. A cotton and rayon mixture has been available in this country for some 25 years and is very safe in terms of public health and now newly on the market there are all cotton tampons. There has been in the past a content in those tampons called CMCs, carboxymethylcellulose fibres, that have in the past been associated with toxic shock it is thought. It is very hard to be clear about that. There are none of those fibres in Australian tampons and I would look to mandating that they never ever be included again.

In the meantime, something like 392 million tampons were bought by Australian girls and women last year. There are two reported cases of toxic shock. While toxic shock can be fatal—and it is a matter which we have to treat with the greatest gravity—I also believe we have to make sure that there is a balanced response to women who are assisted by tampons and that proper information about hygiene, accurate labelling and the contents and manufacturers should be provided to people, not a campaign of frenzy that might distort the facts in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to circumstances in the Middle East. I ask the minister: can he advise the Senate of the reasons for the visit of the head of the PLO Political Affairs Department, Farouk Kaddoumi, the outcomes of his discussions on 27 March with Mr Kaddoumi and what this means from an Australian perspective on Middle East politics?

—Since the signing of the historic Israel-PLO accord in September 1993, the PLO has assumed a recognised and absolutely crucial role on behalf of Palestinians in the negotiations toward Palestinian autonomy on the West Bank and the Gaza. Despite the various difficulties, some of them quite severe, which have arisen between parties since 1993, particularly in the last few months, both sides have continued to work through their differences with a view to making the accord work. In the course of these negotiations, the PLO's role has not been questioned by the international community.

PARA.TAB: Last year PLO leaders expressed their disappointment over the state as they saw it of Australia's relations with the PLO and sought an official invitation from Australia for a senior political figure nominated by them to visit this country. I agreed to that in principle. Subsequently, I was informed that the PLO had nominated Farouk Kaddoumi, the head of the PLO political department and, perhaps more importantly, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Palestinian Economic Council for Development and Reconstruction—PECDAR. Despite the atmosphere of controversy surrounding Mr Kaddoumi, of which I have long been well aware, I took the view that, given his senior position within the PLO hierarchy and my previous agreement in principle to accept a PLO nominee, the visit should proceed.

I had no doubt, firstly, that Mr Kaddoumi has long been one of those within the PLO most reluctant to enter into the peace process in the first place; secondly, that he is one of those most keen to maintain the resistance option, and; thirdly, that he is one of those most critical of the present peace process and the frustrations and difficulties and failures so far along the way. There is a view about Mr Kaddoumi in some Western capitals that his views are not as bad as they sound—rather like, as some people have said, Wagner's musical works—but I am left in some doubt about that, having had a substantial meeting with him. There was more than a little ambiguity about some of Mr Kaddoumi's responses to me but, certainly, I have to say he is at the less moderate, more tough-minded end of the PLO's spectrum.

The main point of the meeting was really to communicate clearly to Mr Kaddoumi Australia's views on the matters in issue in the Middle East peace process. I certainly took that opportunity to convey Australia's very strong support for the peace process and for the Oslo accords and our absolute opposition to political objectives ever being pursued by violent means.

The opportunity was taken to emphasise our support for democratic elections and respect for human rights by the Palestinian authority. Moreover, I urged Mr Kaddoumi to see the importance for confidence building purposes of early fulfilment of the PLO's commitment to submit to the Palestinian National Council for formal approval the necessary changes to its covenant of those elements which are incompatible with Israel's right to exist as recognised, or at least implicitly recognised, in the declaration of principles signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1993. I also urged him to see the Arab boycott of Israel as an obsolete relic since the Oslo accords and to continue to support the Israel-Jordan peace treaty.

I advised Mr Kaddoumi that the Australian government will continue to stand behind those parties which have the courage and commitment to go on with the search for peace, which began with the Oslo accords. We do, of course, continue to support very strongly the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination and, if they wish, to an independent state alongside a secure Israel. We absolutely reject and condemn political violence. I repeated that view on a number of occasions—that all peoples of the region have the right to be free from threats of violence from any quarter.

The visit of Mr Kaddoumi was consistent with the pattern of contact with the PLO followed by a number of Western governments for a number of years. I strongly believe that it is only through such contact at senior level that the views of the Australian government and the Australian community can be delivered to best effect.

While I am on my feet, I just say very briefly that the Canberra Times headline on Saturday ascribing the view to my press spokeswoman of Jewish elements `peddling lies' on PLO visit is a wildly inaccurate account of what was said. The words in quotation marks were never said by the government and do not reflect the government's position.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer the minister to the evidence before the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee on 6 March which shows that private patient numbers in public hospitals have declined by 25 per cent over the last four years. I ask: is it correct that the Commonwealth and state ministers have agreed that the trigger for a review of the Medicare agreement was actually reached last November? Is it correct that the Commonwealth has made no extra payments to the states despite lower numbers of private patients and that Victoria is owed $59 million to compensate for the decline in private patient numbers over the last 15 months? When will the minister renegotiate the Medicare agreement with the states and what will the Commonwealth do to ensure that any additional Commonwealth funds provided to the states are not used by state governments as an excuse to further reduce state funding to hospitals.

—This question is very much the same as the question asked by Senator Lees yesterday about South Australia. The answer to the question is much the same as what I said yesterday. Yes, indeed, Senator Spindler, the two per cent trigger was reached. That was agreed and work has started as a consequence of that. A review is being conducted by a working group of Commonwealth and state officers which first met on 18 November 1994 and that has produced an interim report which has shown, beyond doubt now, some very, very important and interesting statistics.

PARA.TAB: They show for Victoria, as they have shown for New South Wales and for South Australia, that Commonwealth money to the state of Victoria has increased over the last three years while at the same time the Victorian state government has withdrawn money. I will read the figures for you, Senator. The Victorian state government money in 1991-92 was $1,133 million. In 1992-93 it fell to $1,055 million. In 1993-94 it fell further to $973 million. That is a drop of 7.61 per cent in real terms from 1992 to 1994, with the fall being 8.75 per cent between 1993 and 1994. So if the Victorian state government wants to say that it is having trouble dealing with waiting lists and costs in Victoria, why is it cutting its own health dollars? Why is it cutting expenditure on the hospitals and why is it that Victoria is one of the very rare places where all the doctors in the public health system have recently protested against the cuts in health funding in Victoria?

The Victorian state government has taken the Commonwealth increased funding and used that as a cover to reduce its own funding. It has savagely cut funding in Victoria. It has savagely damaged the opportunities for hospitals in Victoria, to the point where the doctors in those hospitals have actually publicly agitated against those cuts. It is not something that Victoria should be proud of.

To go to the other points of your question, Senator Spindler, the review committee is trying to work on what exactly are the costs that might be consequent on that two per cent trigger. There has been quite clearly a fall in the number of privately insured patients. No-one disagrees with that. A large number of those are young people and they are not putting a cost on the public sector, but one could assume that there is some small increased cost on the public sector. It is not possible to put a figure on it yet, and it is one of the things the review is working on. At the same time, the review is also looking at what adjustments may have to be made because of the deliberate cost shifting by the Victorian state government on to the Commonwealth—a point I alluded to vis-a-vis South Australia in answer to a question from Senator Lees.

The Commonwealth Medicare agreements are in place for the next five years and those Medicare agreements, from the Commonwealth's point of view, guarantee ongoing increased real funding to the states. If the states are serious about the problems in their hospitals, then they should look to their own expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, but I am no apologist for the Victorian government and I certainly know of the cuts undertaken in this area by the Victorian government. My question was, in part: what will the Minister for Health and the Commonwealth government do to stop state governments using increased Commonwealth funding, if and when they receive it, in this manner and off-loading the load on to the Commonwealth? —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I note that in today's Financial Review it is reported that Austrade expects $310 million in orders from the CeBIT information technology fair, recently held in Hanover, Germany. I ask: can the minister confirm Austrade's assessment of CeBIT's outcome for Australian information technology companies?

—Senators will know that the CeBIT fair, held every year in Hanover, Germany, is the premier international event for information technology. This year Australia was the preferred exhibitor and co-hosted the CeBIT fair. Senators will know that the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, went and participated in the opening of that fair to assist Australian industry in the promotion of our information technology capability and our telecommunications industries.

PARA.TAB: As the Financial Review has reported today, Austrade has forecast that approximately $310 million of sales will be made during the next 12 months as a direct consequence of Australia's participation in CeBIT 95. In fact, exhibitors at CeBIT, which as I said was held in Hanover, have actually forecast $443 million in feedback reports received by Austrade from 63 of the 156 exhibitors who participated in that fair.

The Austrade forecast is a conservative one, based on experience which has shown that around 70 per cent of anticipated sales materialise. This would represent a rise of 15 per cent in Australian exports of information technology and telecommunications products and services as a result of our endeavours at CeBIT 95. Some $21 million in orders was actually written by 14 Australian exhibitors during the fair. This achievement, I believe, is a tribute to the excellence of Australian information technology companies which participated and the world-class products that they, as Australian companies, can offer.

The two examples given by the Financial Review today illustrate the range of technologies that the Australian information industry is capable of offering to the world. The Perth based smart card company signed a $16 million contract for a hand-held home automation product. Another company, Open Software Associates, is reported to have signed a very large contract with Germany's second largest private bank, the Dresdner, concerning banking software technology. The results are in part due to the efforts that the Prime Minister put into promoting Australian companies at this premiere international event. This was a serious effort by the government to work hand in hand with the private sector in promoting Australia's image in information technology and throwing our best representative of the nation into the fray to help achieve that.

Australia was the fifth largest exhibitor at CeBIT this year, putting it ahead of countries such as France, Italy, Switzerland and Canada. Australian exhibitors demonstrated highly advanced information technology systems for electronic data interchange and export mining and manufacturing systems. In many cases, Australia's systems for smart cards, EFTPOS and immigration passport checks were the best available in the world. Companies marketing these systems are already well established in the European market. In addition, Australia offered highly advanced telecommunications products and software applications for business, finance, accounting, personal information management and appointment tracking.

Let us go back to the Austrade report. Of the 156 exhibitors, 117 have reported back on their marketing activities. As a result, they anticipate appointing 342 distributors, securing 37 licence agreements and opening 36 overseas branches or subsidiaries. Of those firms reporting, 32 supported existing agents or distributors, 47 successfully launched new products, 82 felt they had reinforced their corporate image, 16 forecast substantial growth in market share and six secured more than $15 million in venture capital.
