PARA.TAB: All I am putting to Senator Ray, when he gets up and expresses irritation at the way in which the CJC is apparently operating, is that perhaps he should take one step back and seek to explore why it might be operating in that way. Part of it at least—it may not be an adequate excuse or even a legitimate excuse—might arise out of a sense of frustration that the CJC has not received the level of cooperation that it believed it was entitled to from federal authorities, the AFP and the NCA. From what we are reading, there are suggestions again that, when international aspects came into this matter and attempts were made to brief the FBI, it was thwarted in that as well. Perhaps that is related to this matter. I do not yet know, but in due course we will know.

The other area that it occurs to me may well be frustrating the CJC is the whole area of conflicts of jurisdiction. Where the responsibility of one of these law enforcement bodies starts and where it ends is a related matter. There is no doubt that there are turf battles taking place within law enforcement in Australia and frustrations are being expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't matter how many people are victims; is that what you are saying?
—I don't know of anything that has been released. Who is being made a victim?
—I have for a start.

—Referring to what was in the Queensland parliament? On the basis of what was in the Queensland parliament, and accepting what you said today that it is untrue, you have got every right to complain. I accept that without qualification; of course you do. But that matter is out of the way. We are now trying to establish why the CJC might be operating in this way—whether it does relate to conflicts of jurisdiction, whether it is getting the support that it deserves from the Queensland government and whether it is frustrated in the exercise of its responsibilities under the act. We will seek to explore and pursue those matters. We are not backing away from that. We will continue to seek to explore the issue of the offsets.

PARA.TAB: They are very strange matters. No doubt Senator Ray could give the explanations. If it is true, I do not understand how Burgess can get 11 container loads of equipment from McDonnell Douglas for the payment of one dollar. There must be a simple explanation in all of this. I am not surprised that law enforcement authorities think that there ought to be some form of investigation. I am pleased that the AFP is now investigating the matter. We look forward to as much information as we can get—which may not be much—on the results of that investigation.

The bottom line is that the question that was asked today by Senator Chapman is totally legitimate. It is within his responsibilities, within the responsibilities of the Senate and within the responsibilities of the opposition in the Senate. There is an undercurrent of wider issues in this whole matter that can also be legitimately explored without wrongly attributing fault to any individual.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am entitled to now speak to the matter that Senator Hill has raised. I will not re-canvass the matter. The implication has been made that in some way the government has been hesitant to pursue this. I am not in a position to absolutely say yes or no to that because I do not cover every department. But let me at least put on record my department's role in the investigation so that Senator Hill understands it. This was raised by the CJC for the Department of Defence. The Department of Defence response was that any potential federal offences should be investigated by one of the two federal authorities—the NCA or the police. That was our advice to the CJC. We put it in its hands to have it investigated.

PARA.TAB: It was first raised with us by the CJC in September 1994. It took a couple of months to convince the AFP, for different reasons, that there should be a full investigation. Ever since, it has had a unit working on it and that other related matter—which I regard as the more serious one—of fuel technology abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The onsale from Australia?

—No. The possible importation and then exportation of dual technology. It is a Commonwealth offence, but it is also a customs offence, although we would normally licence it. If they do not approach us for a licence, it just becomes a customs offence.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman asked whether buying $4 million worth of produce for $1 can be credited to defence offsets. It can, but we would need a long explanation of how the defence offset system works. Whatever brings benefit and credit to Australia is regarded as an offset in goods, irrespective of whether they are used. There may be more fundamental questions as to what the IMS and McDonnell Douglas had. Again, that is a matter for a Federal Police investigation. Senator Newman—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite a legitimate question for us to ask.

—Everyone in politics looks for some coincidence. This was put on notice two weeks ago. This question has been raised today at the same time as a bucket job is being done in the Queensland parliament. We are all political animals in this chamber. It could have been totally coincidental.
—I was telling you it was, but you won't believe me.

—I have conceded the possibility that it could be coincidental. I want to say only one other thing. The police are investigating those two aspects. It is hard for me to respond to all the details for two reasons. Firstly, I do not want to pre-empt the inquiry. Secondly, the police have possession of the files. So Senator Chapman's detailed question cannot be answered at the moment. But I felt I did the proper thing in not extracting out those points relating to me and answering them immediately, because they do not always make commonsense in relation to the rest of the issues. I knew that I would suffer in the meantime by not addressing them straight out. An accusation was made in the Queensland parliament that is false and base. I therefore have to respond to it today.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing worse—I will finish on this point—in public life than to be accused of impropriety when you are not guilty. It is bad enough being caught when you are, but there is nothing worse than being accused of something you have had nothing to do with and then having to get up and explain to your colleagues the true facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, some significant matters arise out of what was said by Mr Grice in the Queensland parliament today. No-one on this side quarrels for a moment with Senator Ray's sense of outrage, given that what is said about him would appear to be manifestly untrue. It is perfectly proper for him to react in the way that he did. But, if we are to be able to assess precisely what is going on in Queensland, and particularly what information comes before the Queensland parliament, it would also be helpful if Senator Ray could be pro-active in enabling this parliament to make a judgment about the role of national law enforcement agencies. In the last 12 months, we have been trying to ascertain the extent to which the NCA and the Federal Police have been involved with the CJC in general and with Operation Wallah in particular. These matters obviously have a flow-on relationship to the offsets inquiry that is currently under way. Therefore, Senator Ray could best put matters on the table and clear the air by, perhaps in discussion with some of his colleagues, providing this chamber with a full detail of the history of the NCA and the Federal Police in relation to these Queensland investigations.

PARA.TAB: It has been like drawing teeth to date. We have never been able to get anything other than fobbing off answers from Senator Bolkus, covered with the usual disgraceful smokescreen and gutter tactics that we have come to expect as a matter of course and which we saw in evidence today. The fact remains that in January this year, when the parliament was not sitting, we were suddenly told that, after all, some potential Commonwealth offences were being investigated. We now know a lot more about the substance of them.

Therefore, if you are not to complain about the behaviour of the CJC in the way that you have and perhaps suggest it is releasing material in ways that it should not be then you should go back to square one and spell out the extent to which it has asked for assistance from the federal agencies and the extent to which it has been denied that assistance.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That may well be so. I am not quarrelling with that proposition. We will continue to express high levels of concern—

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand that as well. If you are a team player and you want to put these matters to rest as far as the role of the federal government is concerned, then you had best do that by having discussions with people like Senator Bolkus to try to make full disclosure about the role of the NCA and the Australian Federal Police. If they have nothing to hide, let us hear about it. We should get a chronology of when they were first asked to provide assistance. We should find out whether they were briefed, as Mr Grice from Queensland says. He says that they were involved in Operation Wallah from the beginning and they were given full briefings.

PARA.TAB: We do not even know whether that is correct. What we seem to have had to date are technical defences that they have not been involved because there was no evidence of federal offences being committed. That is a different thing to saying that they knew nothing about it from the outset. It would seem that they have been made aware of it and you would expect that to happen. But if the reality is that at every turn the CJC has found that it has not been able to get any assistance from the federal authorities, then one begins to understand why it might feel a high level of frustration. I simply invite the minister, in the spirit of cooperation, to give us a lot more information than we have had to date.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Some eight or nine months ago these issues were first raised by Senator Chapman and me. It has been like drawing teeth, but we have had an admission that there was an investigation. To get that admission took a number of questions. The matter has proceeded down the path to the stage where certain information has come forward in the Courier-Mail in the last month. It quite clearly expresses concern that no action has been taken by either the NCA or the Australian Federal Police.
—How would they know; how would they know, Senator?
—I do not know how they would know, but I believe the Courier-Mail is a very reputable newspaper that stands by its stories. It has stood by its stories in this regard.

PARA.TAB: Certain allegations have appeared in the Courier-Mail. For instance, it has been reported that the NCA threw the CJC out of the office. The NCA denied that, but the Courier-Mail stood by that story. Therefore, I believe that, wherever it gets its information from, it is credible information. Allegations have been made today and as a result Senator Ray has made a personal explanation. This has opened up the whole debate again. We can proceed to ask questions. As Senator Ray has said, it is our role to ask questions. It is also our role to seek information. I also believe that there are so many straws in the wind that it has now become a haystack.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't just talk rhetoric and of vague things.

—There is no rhetoric about it. There have been allegations against Mr Burgess, and Mr Burgess's associate has been arrested. Senator Ray has acknowledged that IMS has been involved. IMS is a Burgess company now. All these things add up to uncertainty. As a member of cabinet, Senator Ray has a responsibility to tell the parliament what is happening. He has a responsibility to say why all these things are coming together. Burgess owns IMS. Senator Ray said today that he has had meetings with IMS. Burgess's associate has been arrested. Burgess is overseas.
—So what?

—Senator Ray can ask, `So what?' He may think it is all a coincidence, but I am sure no-one else in this parliament does. Burgess's associate has been accused of bribing a company. Burgess and Carlos are associated, and so it goes on. I believe this parliament is owed a full explanation of what is happening.

PARA.TAB: I think everyone would acknowledge that Senator Ray is one of the straightshooters in this parliament. Senator Ray owes this parliament a detailed explanation of what is happening. If anyone in this parliament or the gallery is to have faith in the government, he has to get up and tell us why all these things happened. I have said this in this place time and time again: I am a great believer in the idea that if it is either a conspiracy or a stuff-up, we should back the stuff-up. But in these circumstances, there are too many coincidences. Therefore, we can proceed, but I believe that Senator Ray owes this parliament an explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty with this whole debate is illustrated by what has happened here. Senator Robert Ray has been accused of gross misbehaviour and has made a very forceful rebuttal of the suggestions made about him. As I understand it, nobody on the other side has done anything but accept his explanation. But having accepted his explanation, they then said, `Nevertheless, he should have done more to forward the investigations. This government should have given the CJC a better go,' but they have given no explanation as to why the government should have done this.

PARA.TAB: As a result of this, those opposite have said that they accept that Senator Ray is absolutely innocent of any suggestion made, but they continue to create an atmosphere that somehow leaves him in touch with the allegations made against him. I would have thought the proper way to deal with this issue was to say, `Senator Ray, we accept what you have said. We don't want to continue with the allegations that we have made.' That would be the proper way to deal with these things. There are some real worries about what is happening in the Senate at the moment. I was disgusted yesterday to receive a document through the fax about a senator whom I hold in high regard. There was no explanation; it was just fed through the fax machine and circulated to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgusting.

—Absolutely disgusting. I think the Senate has got to start asking questions about where we go from here. If an allegation is made and rebutted—as it has been today—that rebuttal should be accepted, or evidence should be produced to show that it is wrong.

PARA.TAB: Other matters have been raised today. I heard what Senator Boswell said. I regard him as a highly intelligent man—a good contributor to this chamber—but I do not think it was helpful for him to get up in the context of this debate and raise these other issues after Senator Ray had made a rebuttal of an allegation made against him. They should have been raised in a debate separate to Senator Ray's rebuttal of this allegation.

Any of us can understand that what means. Any of us who had the sort of thing said about them that has been said today in the Queensland parliament would want that rebutted. We would have hoped that, having made that rebuttal and that having been accepted, it would have been left in that context.

These other matters that Senator Boswell has talked about as to what should happen and what the CJC has been through, whether it has had cooperation from the Federal Police or not, should be brought up separately. It is a legitimate issue if we want to debate it, but it is wrong to introduce that sort of material at a time when a person has made a personal explanation. If somebody gets up and makes an explanation and says, `I didn't do this' and everybody says, `Yes, we accept what you say' but then go on to fudge the edges to that acceptance, then there are some real problems.

I would like to say some things about the CJC, the NCA and the Federal Police. I must confess I do not know the CJC. I know Mr Sherman from the NCA and I know the Federal Police. I find those two bodies, the NCA and the Federal Police, to be staffed by people of the utmost rectitude and integrity, but that is a matter for another debate. I think the debate here today should be limited to the very strong denial by Senator Robert Ray, and it was a convincing denial. He got up and said, `At about the time it was alleged we were somewhere else we were here. There is the evidence.'

What more can a person do than what he has done to rebut an allegation made without any evidence? He has taken the onus upon himself to prove that allegation is wrong, which is the reversal of the usual situation in this area. Having done all he can do and that having been accepted by the other side, he then has to face—and I keep coming back to this because it is a real worry—a discussion about other matters which in some way impinge upon him, that leaves him, as it were, to some extent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Vulnerable.

—Vulnerable and in some way compromised, rather than as he ought to come out of this—completely exonerated and accepted by the Senate and by people who are listening to this broadcast today as a person of absolute and unchallenged integrity.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. My personal explanation again relates to the issue that has been under debate for the last 40 minutes or so. I welcome the acknowledgment by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) of the legitimacy of the question I put to him in question time, apparently unlike some of his other colleagues who interjected during that question. I also assure him that it was absolutely coincidental that this question was asked on the same day that certain statements were made in the Queensland parliament. In fact it was only just before question time that I became aware those statements had been made, well after this particular question that I asked was drafted and planned for today. I give him that absolute assurance.

PARA.TAB: The area where the minister in answering the question misrepresented me was his claim that, in an interview on the Murray Nicoll program on radio 5AN in Adelaide on 7 June last year, I identified the Criminal Justice Commission as the source of the information that I had used for questions directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice in this place in May-June of last year. I am aware that the Minister for Justice, Mr Kerr, has for a couple of weeks been bandying this transcript around to various people claiming that this is irrefutable evidence that the Criminal Justice Commission was the source of my information.
I just go to the detail of the transcript to show quite clearly that is not the case. The transcript states:

SPEECH.PARA: NICOLL: Right, so police leaked the information to you about Sen Richardson to put pressure on the Govt . . .
CHAPMAN: I'm not indicating who particularly made the information available, but people involved in law enforcement in Queensland . . .
Further down, as the minister quoted, Nicoll said:
NICOLL: So, let me get this straight. It was Fed Police was it not that were having a look at this.
He then goes on to ask a second question:
This information has come from Fed Police, right.
I am then, in fact, in responding to that, answering his first question; in other words, `Who were the bodies that were having a look at this issue?' The transcript states:
Chapman: Queensland law enforcement agencies.
Nicoll: I see, the CJC, Criminal Justice Commission.
Chapman: And other law enforcement agencies in Queensland.

I was there referring to the bodies that are looking at this issue; I was not in any way referring to where or when or how this information may have come into my hands. I give the minister that absolute assurance. I have accepted his assurances today on certain issues, and I trust that he will accept this assurance. At no time have I indicated the source of the documents to which I referred in asking those questions in the Senate last year and, indeed, even in this interview I was very careful not to do that. So to say that this document—this interview—identifies the CJC as my source of information is quite false, and I want to lay that to rest absolutely right now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation of Senator Chapman.

SPEECH.PARA: I say this to Senator Chapman: he can clear this up and follow me and he can say, if he wants to, whether the CJC leaks to him. Does he want to deny that? Do you want to deny that the CJC has leaked to you? You do not have to—but you do not respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a highly improper.

—It is in some ways. Nevertheless, my view of the CJC leaking is not dependent simply on that transcript but on journalists contacting me and indicating vaguely where they got the information. They also indicated that, when the police met with the CJC some two weeks ago, material given by the Australian Federal Police to the CJC, not known to them, got into the public domain within two hours. So it is absolutely their view too, I think, that the CJC is leaking. I am not going to go into the merits of whether the CJC should leak or not, but I restate that it is my view—whether or not Senator Chapman confirms it in relation to himself—that the CJC has been deliberately leaking material.

—I take up the minister's invitation to respond and say that, as I understand it, there are 10 agencies which have information about this particular matter and these particular investigations. Therefore, information could be coming from any one of those particular 10 agencies. I can say to the minister I have absolutely no reason to believe that the source of my information was the Criminal Justice Commission.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Post-mortem on Suspected Toxic Shock Victim

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Chee this day, relating to toxic shock syndrome and the release of a report of a post mortem.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley, in her answer today, gave the Senate a lot of information in relation to the use of tampons, which was useful and informative. What she sought to do, however, was to avoid the principal issue at stake, which was the violation of this family's privacy and the violation of the privacy of the young girl who died. That is really what is at stake. It is very clear from the minister's answer that she made information from a post-mortem available to journalists without asking the permission of the parents of this 13-year-old girl. Senator Crowley's defence was that she did not divulge the name.

PARA.TAB: In the other place this afternoon, Dr Lawrence admitted that the girl's identity was well known. So the defence that Senator Crowley put forward, that she did not divulge the name when she gave out the details of the post-

SPEECH.PARA: mortem, is a pretty pathetic defence, given that her senior minister has already acknowledged the fact that this girl's death and her identity were well-known facts in the public arena. To whom else were these details supposed to relate but to the girl in question? What was supposed to be added to the grand total of public knowledge by divulging these very detailed, personal matters that related to the post-mortem? What was the added benefit to the public and, if there was an added benefit to the public, why did not Senator Crowley have the decency to at least ask this girl's family first?

PARA.TAB: From the evidence that Senator Crowley presented to the Senate this afternoon, it appears that she had the information for at least a couple of days. At some stage between her receiving the information from the Therapeutic Goods Administration and her releasing it on 13 March, you would have thought that she would have had the decency to phone the parents. But, no, that did not happen. In fact, the parents told me yesterday they still have not heard from Senator Crowley notwithstanding her liberal use of their daughter's private post-mortem details.

Senator Crowley has to explain to the Senate why she did not consult these parents before she released this information. What was so urgent that she could not wait even to make a phone call to the parents before rushing off to the media? What was it that was added to the import of this matter by releasing the details of this poor girl's post-mortem before the inquest had even been held? What was it that was added to her press release? Why was it that Senator Crowley, from her explanation, gave out a three-page summary and then, when people wanted more information, gave out a 12-page document from the Therapeutic Goods Administration? What was contained in those documents? What was the benefit in releasing that information? Did she weigh up the benefit against the enormous distress that she would cause?

Senator Crowley is a minister with enormous responsibilities in relation to these matters. A minister with those responsibilities has to consider each and every action carefully, instead of rushing off to the media in some unseemly haste to somehow boost a press release. This is a thoroughly, thoroughly disappointing matter and I hope that Senator Crowley will explain her actions and explain why she chose to so grossly violate the privacy of this family at a time when they were mourning for a very dear 13-year-old daughter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Post-mortem on Suspected Toxic Shock Victim

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it remarkable that this information is being trawled over again today by Senator O'Chee some two or three weeks after the events that he is referring to. I have said on the record and I have made clear my deepest sympathy to the family on the loss of their daughter. But I would have to say that, in providing this report, I have also had to deal with two things: my concern under my government responsibilities for the public health and, particularly through the Therapeutic Goods Administration, my concern about therapeutic devices. In this case we are referring to a tampon.
—He has not questioned that.

—Excuse me, Senator. I can actually put my case how I will. My responsibility was to seek, as I did immediately following the 7.30 Report, full information and a report on this. I am very distressed that information of this sort is now being used to tar my name. I have never released the child's name. I have never released the medical history.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't I have to, Senator?
—Because everybody knew.
—Why?
—Why did you release the post-mortem?
—I did not release the post-mortem.
—You did release the post-mortem.

—Just a minute. I did not, Senator. If you want to misrepresent, you can. I seek leave to table what I released, a one and a half page press release going to the matters, and a three-page summary report. That should make it quite clear.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Minister, you do not need leave. You may table it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to that, on request, we would provide the full report to anybody with a special interest, particularly those of the medical profession or journalists. It is important to know the reason for this child's name being so well known: this matter was very extensively canvassed throughout the month of February in the Queensland press, and it was a major concern. In that report there was one brief reference to one part that the TGA judged to be relevant to the matters of my concern, and that is the public health concern about the safety of tampons.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that report, we are looking at how best to assure Australian women and girls of the safety of tampons. On the report, I hope to see increased standards and to ensure that those standards are available for the comfort and confidence of Australian women and girls. Also, we will be looking at the labelling to make sure that those words are not only on the plastic wraps but also available on the packages—again, to assure people. One of the other requirements is an enclosure which talks about the basic hygiene that women and girls using tampons need perhaps to be reminded of in every case. They go to the matter, the one small point, that was referred to in the report.

The opposition might want to get carried away and points score about this. I am deeply concerned that the publicity surrounding all of this, prior to us getting the report, prior to us being able to do anything, might have added in any way to this family's pain. It is not and never has been my intention to add any harm or hurt to those people. But I also have an obligation to make sure that the therapeutic device here mentioned, a tampon, is safe for use by all Australian women and girls.

That is the matter that we were addressing—a matter of concern about the public health of thousands of women and girls in this country. I think a lot of senators would know of the concern that was raised through press considerations of this matter, prior to and since our report. I would hope the fact is that we never named this child. I certainly never named this child; I never released a medical history; I did not release a post-mortem report. One small relevant detail was included in the full report for those who requested that report as a matter of further information.

Our concern has been always to make sure that we put as our priority the public health concerns that are my responsibility and to do everything we could to protect and sympathise with this family through this long period of considerable pain and tragedy. I hope that the rest of the Senate might now do that family and this whole question the honour of waiting in silence until there is an outcome from the coronial inquiry. That inquiry is listed for some time late in May—I think the senator may have mentioned the date—and it would be best for all concerned if we waited until then.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Post-mortem on Suspected Toxic Shock Victim

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the answer given today by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) to a question properly asked by Senator O'Chee. The question that the minister was asked was:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the minister confirm that on 13 March 1995 she distributed to selected journalists—
and it was quite clear that we were not talking about to all journalists by way of broad press release; she was quite specifically asked whether she distributed material to selected journalists—
. . . detail of a post-mortem on a 13-year-old Mareeba girl—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not the question, Senator.
—This was the question, and it continues:

SPEECH.PARA: and suspected toxic shock victim, without the knowledge of the girl's parents and in contravention of all privacy considerations?

If the minister wants to say that I have been misleading with that, we will deal with that tomorrow. But I say that she is being misleading now in purporting to say that she was only asked about a three-page release; she was not. She was asked whether she distributed certain material to `selected journalists'. What she said was that—and this is her answer: I was not prepared . . . to name this child. These things have not come from me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never named the child.
—She said, `These things have not come from me.' Not `I didn't name her' but `These things have not come from me.' That is what the minister said. She went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I have preferred to keep well away from it because of the . . . hurt it might do to that family. I do not wish to buy into this at all.
That is her initial answer. In other words, `I didn't distribute this stuff to selected journalists at all.'

PARA.TAB: Then we come to the supplementary answer. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: That was not part of the three-page summary. It was part of that 12-page comprehensive report provided to me. For those very few people who sought that report, it was provided to them. Very few journalists sought that report and it was provided to them.

In the first answer, the minister comes in here and says that it did not come from her. She wanted to keep away from it all. Finally, in her supplementary answer, she had to admit that it did in fact come from her. She said that she had provided the report to any journalist who had an interest; she may as well have said to the world at large. It was a very dishonest response, Minister. You sought to mislead and, in my view, you have done so again in what is a quite pathetic and dishonourable explanation that you have offered, which is in marked contrast to that of your senior minister, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). It is abundantly clear why she is senior to you. Unlike you, who have only been able to express sympathy with the family, the senior minister stood up in the other place and apologised to the family for any hurt that was caused by this release—something you could not bring yourself to do. The reason you could not bring yourself to do it is that you would have had to admit that you had released the information. But your senior minister has done it for you, sensing the trouble that you had got yourself into.

PARA.TAB: We have satisfied ourselves that you did release the information. You released it in the further report that was made available to journalists. The minister seeks to hold on to this slim gossamer thread that the name of this child was not mentioned. It was not, but let me read to you what is at the commencement of the report: it names the date, the age and the town that the young girl came from. From the minister's own answer that we heard this afternoon, there are so few cases of toxic shock or alleged toxic shock that all the world would know whose details these were. More importantly, the family and friends know whose details these are that you released.

Your senior minister can spot that. The senior minister, the minister for health, in the other place has acknowledged that the publicity surrounding this matter, the death of this girl, was such that whether you named her or not did not matter; everyone knew whom you were talking about. Don't let the minister pretend there was no identification. There is the date, the age and the town, and in her own answer she made it clear how few cases there were. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to briefly contribute to this debate. This is a serious matter. The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) might walk away from it. Not only was her answer in question time misleading but she sought to take a series of technical defences. Firstly, she sought to avoid facing up to her responsibility by interpreting Senator O'Chee's question as referring apparently to a three-page document. She kept interjecting saying that the question referred to the three-page document, but it did not at all. She did that because she wanted to avoid facing up to the fact that she had distributed to selected journalists the 12-page post-mortem report. She did not want to say so.

PARA.TAB: You can only interpret that answer as being misleading. In terms of parliamentary practice, there are few more serious offences than deliberately misleading the parliament. Perhaps there is something that is more serious in this instance: why did she distribute this highly personal, sensitive material to selected journalists without first obtaining the approval of the parents of the girl? Why did she act in such an insensitive way? We still have not had an explanation for that.

The implication in what she is saying is that she did it as a matter of public health and that it was necessary for this detail to be distributed to journalists in order to enhance the public health debate in this country. That is patent nonsense, isn't it? The personal biological details of the post-mortem were not relevant to the journalist writing that the girl suffered shocking trauma and died. No defence has been put to the Senate at all as to why she did distribute it.

Firstly, the minister has hesitated in acknowledging that she distributed the 12-page report to selected journalists. Secondly, she has put up no defence to it. Thirdly, as I hear her, she still has not apologised to the parents for what she did. Her senior minister did in the other chamber but she has not come in here and apologised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The senior minister apologised.

—Yes, but Senator Crowley is the guilty party. After having all these opportunities today, she still has not come in here and apologised to the parents for the offence that she caused them. What is her justification in doing that, other than a failure to meet responsibility? We expect of ministers reasonable standards of public behaviour. She erred in this instance. She made a bad error of judgment. She caused grave offence to the parents of this girl. She sought to avoid meeting that responsibility in this place and she still has not got the guts to come in here and apologise to the parents for the offence that she has caused them. That is a pretty appalling performance; it is an appalling record. I believe that it does justify censure of this chamber. What I wanted to hear from the minister, who has walked out of the chamber now—
—There is no minister.

—There is no minister. All I wanted from Senator Crowley today, after she had a time of reflection and after she has heard what her senior minister said in the other place, was a response. I expected to hear her say, `I made an error of judgment. I caused offence. I apologise for that offence. I also apologise to the extent to which I may have misled the Senate.' TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: We again had today evidence of the way in which this federal Labor government is proposing to rip more money away from the students in universities in Australia. We have had a number of cases over the last few years, in legislation and in other forms, of the government increasing the burden placed on students. We have seen over the 12 years of this Labor government a move from no fees to a position of greater imposition of fees. It started originally with an administrative charge of about $400. This was then converted into the HECS scheme, which has gradually risen over the years to a level of about $2,400 a year.

PARA.TAB: We have now heard that the government is proposing in the next budget a further increase; and this, we believe, is supported by the Department of Finance and by the Treasury, and what they plan to do is put this up by another $1,000. If you multiply that across the student body of Australia, which is 450,000 students, this reaps for the government an incredible amount of money. This is on top of other measures in recent times whereby the government has increased the repayment rate of HECS and lowered the level of income at which HECS has to be repaid.

The unclaimed debt of HECS to the government from students is now reaching $2 billion, and we have a Treasury and a Department of Finance starved of funds who see this $2 billion out there and want to get it back as quickly as possible by raising the repayment rates and lowering the level of income at which it is reclaimed. Now we find yet again that this is not an adjustment that is in line with the CPI. As a matter of fact, it is way out of line with the CPI. It is an absolutely massive increase—from 23 per cent to 30 per cent.One would ask why a Labor government wants to really slug one of the poorest groups in the community. As we all know, and I am sure that probably all of us in this chamber were students at one stage—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not all of them.

—Not all on the other side, obviously. But we all know how difficult it is, as a student, to make ends meet. One relates to the lack of public money it is prepared to put into university education at a time when it has expanded the system. It has expanded the system by about 40 per cent since 1988, but it has not expanded the resources to match that. What we see with this proposed measure is the government yet again trying to grab from a poor group in the community to make up the funding shortfalls.

When they get to the ballot box at the next election the students of this country, and their parents, should definitely vote against this deceptive and lying government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to advise that I will not be seeking formality on general business notice of motion No. 1415 standing in my name. I seek leave to make a brief statement of explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Greens are pleased that the government has seen reason and decided to extend the exemption of married Austudy recipients under the age of 22 from the Sex Discrimination Act. The government has been using the expiry of this exemption as justification to knock 2,100 married students off Austudy, which was a selective enforcement of a legal provision to save money and force students off their only income. The Greens realise that, by extending the exemption, there will be temporary discrimination for single students and de facto students while married students continue to collect Austudy. However, we believe that this can be the only outcome while DEET operates with such a flawed definition of the `independent rate of Austudy', the basis of which is age discrimi nation.

PARA.TAB: Students cannot be defined as being independent from their parents unless they are over the age of 22, even if they are financially independent adults. This definition is therefore not targeting those financially disadvantaged students who require Austudy to study when attending university straight from high school. It does not affect mature age students. The government has agreed to conditions within the Sex Discrimination Act—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We did not object to Senator Margetts speaking. However, I did not think she would give this sort of delivery. I thought that she was only going to explain why she was not going on with motion.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is a brief statement that will take less than five minutes. Considering the seriousness of what nearly occurred, it is worthwhile explaining what happened.

PARA.TAB: The government has agreed to conditions within the Sex Discrimination Act exemption, which means that a working party will come up with an alternative definition to the independent rate of Austudy. This move is welcomed by the Greens. The government will also undertake a review of the Sex Discrimination Act exemption for married Austudy students at the same time as it reviews the Sex Discrimination Act exemption for the tax act and the Social Security Act. At the moment, the whole of the Social Security Act is exempt from the Sex Discrimination Act.

The Greens found it hard to believe that married students were being targeted while so many other exemptions under the Sex Discrimination Act still existed. When the Greens saw the implications of taking away those exemptions, we expressed our deepest concerns that this legal process may have been used to cut more people off allowances and create savings for the government.

We often see the government using the tool of making things consistent or non-discriminatory as a guise for disadvantaging sections of the community. I am very concerned that in this exemption review process the government will be looking to remove as many exemptions from the Sex Discrimination Act as possible, even if it disadvantages the people it is meant to protect, which is women.

We have already seen this with the increase in the female retirement age, which was an economic measure rather than a social equity one. I also fear that the Social Security Act will be slashed of its marital allowances. The government will invariably go for the least cost option, even when the objectives are to supposedly improve social policy. The social policy objectives will be innocently pursued, and the working party may be overruled by the economic rationalism of the present government. The result will be one of compromised social policy and hard-won games of the social sector being forced down to the lowest common denominator.

In conclusion, though the Greens have fought hard for this exemption and for married students to retain Austudy, we realise that this is only a temporary measure for the government. We realise that this measure is not a solution and that the solution lies with redefining the independent rate of Austudy by more appropriate and non-discriminatory criteria. However, we are concerned that this process will be used as a justification for cutting back social spending. We fear that we will again be fighting the same issue at the end of 1996. We will be fighting this principle over a number of policy areas instead of just one.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to put the government's position on the statement made by Senator Margetts. Since the Austudy regulations were disallowed by the Senate on 9 February 1995, the government has been carefully considering the position of the entitlement of all students, particularly married students, to the independent rate of Austudy. The government has been concerned to not disadvantage students as a result of the disallowance or maintaining its commitment to a non-discriminatory students assistance scheme. In particular, the government has been concerned about the fact that the disallowance removed the grandfather clause, financially disadvantaging up to 1,200 students under the age of 22 who received Austudy last year on the basis of marriage.

PARA.TAB: The government has now addressed the situation of married students and Austudy. It has resolved any uncertainty which might have resulted from the disallowance of the proposed regulations. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) yesterday announced that an exemption covering Austudy payments to married students has been granted by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That was a decision of the commissioner, not the government. This exemption will now allow Austudy to be paid at the independent rate for all married students subject to the relevant income and assets test. This exemption will continue until the end of 1996. During this time, the government has established a task force which will review the granting of independent status under Austudy with a view to finding criteria which are not discriminatory but which reflect the community's view of who should receive Austudy benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This has been a victory for the Senate. The government should accept its defeat with more grace than what Senator Schacht just demonstrated. The government sought to remove the independent rate of Austudy for married individuals under the age of 22. It sought to argue that it had no choice as a result of the Sex Discrimination—
—Until the sex discrimination commissioner gave an exemption, you fool.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Surely you will ask Senator Schacht to withdraw that comment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Schacht, would you care to withdraw the remark that you just made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—The government is obviously sensitive, because it realises that what it did represented an appalling abuse to young married students. It tried to argue that students who have left home and are married are no longer independent. It was basically a cost saving measure. It tried to argue that it had no choice but to reduce the Austudy payments to these students because of provisions in the Sex Discrimination Act.

PARA.TAB: We said from the outset that a number of different options were open to the government. It could amend the act or seek a further exemption. There were also a couple of other options. For several weeks, it refused to consider those options. It dug in and said that it was not going to. It said that it had no choice other than the process it adopted.

However, we used the procedures of this Senate to in effect force it to reconsider. We started that process by moving a disallowance of its regulations, which were going to set in concrete the removal of the independent rate of Austudy from married students under the age of 22. I am very pleased that we have received the support of the minority parties in this chamber. The defeat of those regulations forced the government back to the sex discrimination commissioner. It had to consider what other options were open to it.

The next important aspect is the outcry by students and student unions. This was another instance in which the government was breaking its promise to Australian students. There have been so many areas in which this government has done that since the last election. There have been many occasions when the opposition and minority parties have had to do our best to keep the government honest. This was just another example of that.

The technique adopted was that an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats to one of the miscellaneous bills tacked on an amendment that would have the same effect. The result of these various pressures was that the government had no alternative in the end but to accept that it had been in error and to find a solution. The solution it adopted was a negotiation with the sex discrimination commissioner, which has further extended the exemption for two years under the Sex Discrimination Act. The problem has been partially solved for two years. Students will be pleased about that.

However, it is not a final solution. All I can say is that, fortunately, in two years we do not expect this government to be in office. We expect that Australia will again be under good government. The solution that Australian students will receive will be not only fair but one which recognises that when students leave home they are independent, irrespective of whether the Australian Labor Party realises it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I think it highlights a process of the parliament that this afternoon Senator Schacht finally admitted that this whole matter has been resolved not by the actions of the government but by the actions of the Sex Discrimination Commission.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, but you should have had the commonsense at the start not to bring in such a stupid provision.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Tierney, please resume your seat for a moment. The debate we are having at the moment is as a result of a notice of motion being withdrawn. I the debate is going to be as heated as it appears to be getting from the interjections it is attracting from both sides of the chamber, perhaps there is a different process that the Senate can engage in in order to facilitate the debate. I call Senator Tierney and ask that he be heard in silence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why Senator Schacht is so embarrassed. The commission has worked out the obvious course of action that the government should have worked out in the first place—that is, that this group obviously should have an exemption. It is a great pity that the government did not have the commonsense to work this out in the first place. Instead it subjected the chamber to the time wasting process of putting up a piece of legislation that was going to raise about $100,000—that is all it was going to raise—and, if successful, therefore severely discriminate against a group of students on the ground that they are married. It should have been obvious to the government that a lot of these people have moved away from home, often live in different states to their parents and do not rely on their parents. Why on earth should the income of their parents be taken into account in calculating their Austudy.

PARA.TAB: I think the opposition was right in disallowing this proposal. We welcome the support of other parties in relation to this matter. I think it is a tribute to the Senate that yet again a silly piece of government legislation has been stopped by the appropriate authorities—in this case it is the Sex Discrimination Commission—and the people in this place. In the future, let us hope that the government considers whether these matters are serious before it brings them before the Senate and wastes our time. I think the legislation on this occasion certainly did waste our time. It is good to see that this matter has now been resolved and that this rather silly measure has been disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I gave notice of a motion earlier today in which I outlined how married couples are discriminated against in the same manner. I draw this to Senator Schacht's attention in the hope that something can be done about it as well. I will give a specific example because I think that will be the quickest way of making sure that you understand.
—Was that about education?

—I am talking about the discrimination against married couples which is the subject of this debate. I am talking about the situation where a person is admitted to a nursing home. In particular, I am referring to a man in his early forties who had a stroke. He has now been admitted to a nursing home. His wife has a job and a reasonably modest income. Her job is important to her and she is entitled to keep it.

PARA.TAB: Because she has a job she is now required to pay for her husband to be in the nursing home. She cannot afford to do that and continue to support her children. The advice she was given was that she should divorce her husband. The trauma associated with receiving that advice was absolutely dramatic. I have checked with Social Security and it says that that is the case. This is another example of discrimination against married couples and it ought to be eliminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I agree with the comments that Senator Hill made in addressing this matter and I also agree with the reasons Senator Margetts gave for pursuing this matter. It is a victory for the Senate that this action by the commissioner has led to the matter being resolved in a temporary sense. I wish to address a phrase Senator Schacht used when describing the state of the situation as it is at the moment. I think it is important to draw out this particular phrase.

PARA.TAB: The minister led us to believe that students had been receiving Austudy on the basis of their marriage. That is inaccurate. We need to address that fact and acknowledge that what was occurring was that students were receiving Austudy on the basis of their marriage being part of the definition of independence that was used by the department at that time. It is that inadequacy which has led to this situation.

Senator Margetts is right in drawing attention to the fact that the department needs to have a proper definition of what independence is before payments can be made on the basis of people being independent of their parents. The impression that the minister gave that students were receiving money on the basis of their marriage illustrates how faulty that definition was and how faulty the government's attitude is towards students in this situation.

The government thought it could continue to whittle away the benefits of Austudy while increasing costs to students. The government has been found out. This was the straw that broke the camel's back and the student bodies persisted to resolve the matter. Thank goodness the Senate was able to coagulate the various forces and oppose this proposal successfully. Having opposed it and having forced the government to resolve the issue in a temporary sense, I hope the government has the capacity, with the help of its advisers and departments, to come up with a definition of an independent person. If that is finally resolved, then we will not be faced with this sort of nonsense in the future.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—The President has received a letter from Senator Reid proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
The Prime Minister's continuing failure to appreciate the needs and aspirations of mainstream Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
