TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take senators back to part of the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the night in 1993 when the Labor government was re-elected. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I can assure you the Government will now be redoubling its efforts to be as good a government as you hope and expect we can be . . . keeping those great nostrums of access and equity. Getting people into the game. The policies of inclusion.
He concluded by saying:
. . . we won't let you down.

He had previously talked about being concerned about those who were unemployed and getting them back to work. They were the words of the Prime Minister in 1993 when the people of Australia re-elected this Labor government. You might have thought at that time that the people were being rewarded by his recognition of what was required at the time.

PARA.TAB: I come now to the comments of Chris Uhlmann in today's Canberra Times on the by-election which was held in Canberra last Saturday. The by-election was for the seat of Canberra, caused by the resignation of the former member, Mrs Kelly. It was won convincingly and dramatically by the Liberal Party candidate, Mr Brendan Smyth, who will shortly take his place in the House of Representatives. Mr Acting Deputy President, I would love to read all of her article in case you have not read it, but I will keep to just a couple of bits. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Think of the major political stories being kicked around by Paul Keating in the past month and try to find one which addresses the concerns of the bulk of people who live in Tuggeranong, or the rest of the seat of Canberra, or any other middle-Australian area.
She continued:

PARA.TAB: The ALP's recent approach to winning friends and influencing elections in this country is to split Australia into a nation of tribes and then try to buy off the bits.

SPEECH.PARA: They are very valid comments about what has occurred, and the vote of the people of Canberra endorses it. One of the things that we found when we were doorknocking and being amongst the electorate in recent weeks—and, in particular, this was reported to me by Brendan Smyth from the much more extensive doorknocking that he did—was that people commented time and time again on the Prime Minister's bad manners at home, in the parliament and, at that time, overseas.

PARA.TAB: We can recall what the Prime Minister has been indulging himself in: the unsubstantiated accusations of a deal in relation to media matters and, as far as Canberra is concerned, that absolutely dismissive comment of `So what?' when the Liberal Party won the ACT election. Senator McMullan tried to explain that away by saying, `Oh, no. He didn't mean, "So what?" He meant, "It's not really relevant because it was a local matter and not a federal matter."' But Mr Acting Deputy President, if you had heard it, you would have been left in absolutely no doubt whatever that the Prime Minister was saying to the people of Canberra, `So what? Who cares about you? I don't.'

He pontificates about the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, and I am not suggesting that there is not some point in it. But he has raised all these diversions—the constitution, the flag and the things he talked about when he was overseas—ignoring completely the issues that are important to the people in the electorate of Canberra.

People are concerned about interest rates. They are having difficulty maintaining the mortgages on their homes. Families are still suffering and businesses, certainly, are still suffering from the recession that we had to have. People have not forgotten that. Mr Keating has created uncertainty about where interest rates will go from where they are at the present time. Mr Keating may not be aware of it but the ratio of family income paid towards mortgages and loan repayments went up in the December quarter to about 16 per cent, and people are hurting because of this. They know what is happening to them, even though the Prime Minister obviously does not.

People are concerned about employment. There is very high youth unemployment in Canberra, and people wonder what will become of their children here. Youth unemployment is at 32.4 per cent, and it is a higher proportion for females than males. I could not tell the Senate how many children have had to leave Canberra, their home and their family earlier than they might otherwise have done in an attempt to obtain employment. These young people are leaving Canberra in an attempt to find work, especially after they have obtained tertiary qualifications.

There are 800,000 people unemployed nationally. The Labor Party keeps telling us that it has created 500,000 jobs recently. Senator Gareth Evans said that in answer to a question in the Senate only a couple of days ago, but fewer than half of these are real additions to the employment figures. We would like to know some more facts and figures about these alleged 500,000 new jobs. How many of them are permanent? What industries have provided the jobs? How many apprentices have been taken on and are being given the opportunity? There are many more things that one could go through when talking about the impact of unemployment on our society. For example, over 700,000 children live in households where there are parents without work. These are the things that people are concerned about.

People are concerned about the standard of education for their families, the inadequate level of literacy and, more recently, the fees for tertiary students which we have heard about in the Senate. From 1994 postgraduate students have been forced to pay thousands of dollars for many courses after Labor decided to allow the universities to charge these fees. In the ACT a fee of $9,000 a year was being asked for a legal workshop. I have suggested that this is not even a postgraduate course; it is merely a year's course that turns the degree technically into a degree which would enable people to obtain employment.

Few Australians, certainly students, will have forgotten the Prime Minister's comment just a week or so ago to students who were trying to get access to him—the access which was promised in March 1993—to talk about the problems and the difficulties they have with Labor's education policies. What did he say to them? He said, `Get a job.' Well, wouldn't they like to be able to get a job? People are encouraged to stay at school and go to university to get better qualifications, and this is what happens to them.

Perhaps a smaller, but growing, group of people who are concerned about what is happening to them are the self-funded retirees. Since the government introduced the Commonwealth senior's health card on 1 July 1994 for retired people who are not on a pension, an absolutely staggering 200,000 people have qualified for the card. That indicates that people who formerly were living on an income of about the same as a pension and getting absolutely no benefits were living in quite restricted conditions. We knew that, but it has taken a long time to get the additional card which has made such a difference for them.

Since 1 July 1994, 200,000 people have qualified for this card. I believe that number will grow, because self-funded retirees are a significant part of our community. Their situation is not being looked at. These are the people who have saved and made a significant contribution towards their retirement, but they are not doing well in our society at the present time. Those figures really are quite dramatic.

People are concerned about superannuation. Government senators stand up in here and talk endlessly about their superannuation packages, but they have forgotten the casual and part-time workers. If people work for three months, the super levy is paid, but they get absolutely nothing from it by the time the funds take their fees out of it. I refer senators to speeches I have made previously in Hansard setting out the details of how little is left after these fees are paid and what a rip-off this is. The government has made absolutely no effort to put in place a super scheme which enables these people to receive some benefit. People are concerned about health, and why wouldn't they be? It was a big issue in the ACT election. Senator Minchin and Senator Patterson will deal with other matters in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this matter of public importance. Clearly, one expected that the opposition would make some effort to reflect on the Canberra by-election at some stage this week. That is only natural after one accepts the big victory it had in Canberra. I want to point out that winning by-elections is a lot different from winning general elections. We have lost by-elections before in the last 12 years.
—Not as dramatically as this.

—I remember the Adelaide by-election in 1988, the Port Adelaide by-election in a safe seat and the big swing in Oxley and so on—all with big swings. In the end, when it came down to the crunch, people voted the government back. We have been in government for 12 years and one of the features in Australia is that there is no doubt that the longer we are in government the stronger the by-election syndrome gets as people like to remind the government that the longer we are here the higher their expectations of us and they want to keep us on our toes. So in both by-elections and public opinion polls I think the by-election syndrome, the protest, takes place.

PARA.TAB: No mention was made in the remarks of Senator Reid today about the result in New South Wales. On the predictions so far by the pundits, the Fahey government will go out of office by the end of this week or early next week. Of course even last Thursday and Friday the opinion polls of New South Wales understated the Labor vote first preference by some two to three per cent. It is quite clear that people give an indication in a public opinion poll as to whether they will vote a Labor government out or in but when they have to make that decision they are more likely to vote for a Labor government at the ballot-box than in an opinion poll.

I believe that, whatever the difficulties about the by-election, when it comes to the crunch some time in the next 12 months, as happened leading up to the 1993 election, Labor will be voted back in. I remind senators opposite that there were plenty of times during 1992 when members opposite pointed out that Labor was 20 per cent behind the opposition in the opinion polls. When it came to the crunch, when people got to the ballot-box, they voted this government back. I believe that those on the other side who think it is an easy ride into government ought to remember what happened in 1987, 1990 and 1993. We do not take the electorate for granted as the opposition has in the past. That is why when it comes to the crunch people are willing to vote for us.

I want to talk about the economy, which Senator Reid made some passing reference to. This economy is on a sustainable growth path. We have recorded 13 consecutive quarters of economic growth. The growth rate of the economy has exceeded one per cent in each of the last four quarters. The economy grew by 1.3 per cent in the September quarter and by 6.4 per cent through the year to the September quarter 1994. The economy grew by 4.2 per cent in 1993-94. Economic growth will be stronger in 1994-95 than in 1993-94. A recent business survey shows that the output growth remains strong in the December quarter.

Business investment is growing strongly. The government's revised economic outlook is for growth in business investment of 24 per cent. What happened when we predicted 14 per cent in the budget last year? Everyone in the opposition pooh-poohed that figure. You said that 14 per cent was impossible to achieve. It is now 24 per cent. The total business investment in new assets grew by 5.7 per cent in the September quarter in 1994 and by 24.4 per cent in through the year terms. New investment in plant and equipment grew by 6.3 per cent in the September quarter and by 29.4 per cent in through the year terms.

This government, as well as having the economic runs on the board over the last 13 quarters, has demonstrated a clear commitment to combating inequality and alleviating poverty. Significant social security changes in this regard have included a real increase of almost 14 per cent in the base pension rate and real increases of up to nearly 150 per cent in payments for children—150 per cent since you were last in office. Last year we announced the Working Nation statement to tackle the problem of long-term unemployment, creating jobs in industry. We had the Creative Nation statement to create growth in our cultural areas.

We will be coming up with the establishment of the Hilmer competition rules. Despite the huffing and puffing of the conservative state premiers, which delayed this for six months, in the end they all caved in four weeks ago when they had a meeting, to which they did not invite the Prime Minister. They themselves caved in and surrendered, `Yes, we will have the competition policy.' All the Liberal premiers who shouted and screamed—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Wayne Goss.

—Yes, and Wayne Goss. In the end they all caved in because the federal government's competition policy was unimpeachable. They had to give in. One of the reasons they gave in was the business community got on to those state premiers and said, `You are absolutely stupid to oppose what the federal government is putting up here.' This government has the runs on the board as far as economic performance is concerned and competition policy, the Hilmer thrust, is a major micro-economic reform of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Your mob would never have touched this issue in a million years. You would not have taken the state Liberal premiers on. You would have caved in, Senator Minchin. You would have lined up with Dean Brown and said, `Yes, Dean. Anything you want we will do.' Only we would have stood up to them. Only the Prime Minister would have told them what we were on about in the broad national picture which Senator Reid is quite dismissive about.

We get back to this obsession by the opposition about the personality of the Prime Minister. Senator Minchin, Senator Reid and others in the opposition remind me of the Labor Party in the 1950s and 1960s, the party I joined. We were obsessed about Bob Menzies. For 20 years we complained about Bob Menzies being Pig Iron Bob. We thought of every name we could. We put slogans on bridges and so on. All the campaigns for 20 years were against the personality of the Prime Minister, Robert Menzies. Come election time, he always got re-elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because he was popular.

—Despite the fact that at times he was very unpopular. In 1961 when he had the credit squeeze and in 1951 when he had inflation at 22 per cent he was very unpopular. We all thought this would do him in. We attacked him personally; we paid the penalty by not winning. We also had a few problems like you have now of being a divided party. However, when it comes to the crunch you have to make a choice in the electorate—do you want a populist Prime Minister who is well liked or do you want a tough one who can deliver the job?

PARA.TAB: I want to point out some independent qualitative research reported in the Australian Financial Review on 22 March. Senator Minchin, as a former party secretary of the Liberal Party, knows about this. He has been through this process as I have. I think these quotes sum up the difference. What did these people say about John Howard? They said, `Why did he come back? For a quid or what?', `You've got a has-been in there.' and `He has had so many tries.

TALK.START.PARA: —One person said that. So what?

—This is representative. The voters see Mr Howard as yesterday's man and are sceptical about the sincerity of his convictions to a less ideological position on key issues. What did they say about the Prime Minister? They said:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating's done well due to a strong personality . . . Whether you love him or hate him, you're more likely to vote for him.

We discovered this with Malcolm Fraser. He may not have been very well liked—and most of the Liberals bag him now, even though he did win three elections for them—but, in the end, the electorate respected his strength. In the end, the electorate will always support a strong leader like Paul Keating rather than a weak leader like John Howard. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —That hopeless contribution by Senator Schacht, which did not address the matter of public importance, demonstrated very clearly for everyone to see exactly the point we are making in this matter of public importance debate, that is, that the Labor Party, represented by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), is continually failing to appreciate the needs and aspirations of mainstream Australia. That is exactly what Senator Schacht demonstrated today. At the end, he quoted one, two or three people selectively from some qualitative research. We could get just as many and more statements like that about the Prime Minister. You only have to read the front page of the Canberra Times today to see what Canberra people are saying about this Labor government and about this Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: He went on and on about growth, but he omitted to mention the things which Australians are concerned about; that is, three quarters of appalling and disastrous current account deficits. He omitted to remind the Australian public about the billions and billions—I think it is $160-odd billion—of foreign debt. It was $23 billion when this government came to power, now it is $160-odd billion. They are the things that are concerning Australians. The things that are concerning mainstream Australians are things like that and, in particular, the fact that their future and the future of their children and their grandchildren is being mortgaged by this government, which has no idea how to keep government spending under control and how to deal with issues like the foreign debt.

We are in the same position we were in when Mr Keating said he was concerned we were going to be a banana republic, and we are going down the Mexican road. That is exactly what is happening. That is what mainstream Australians were saying to the Prime Minister at that election.

Much has been said in the aftermath of the Canberra by-election as to why there was a 16-plus per cent swing against Labor in what was considered a relatively safe Labor seat. Why did 22,000 voters—22,000 people—who voted Labor last time, abandon the party this time? Why did they do it? You only had to listen to talkback radio on Monday, and you only had to read the Canberra Times to hear what the people of Canberra were saying. Over and over they were referring to the arrogance of this government and the arrogance, in particular, of this Prime Minister.

The once true believer who has now sold his soul for a few shekels of silver interpreted the by-election results as heralding a massacre for the federal government in the next federal election, and he said that the Prime Minister should apologise to the voters for what he has done to Australia. Will Mr Keating apologise? No. He says he has heard the message. It is like those people who sit and say, `I hear what you're saying,' but they are not actually hearing what you are saying at all.

Mr Keating has learned nothing, and he continues to deflect responsibility to everything and everyone but himself. He is the problem. He is the problem because he has ignored the concerns of mainstream Australia; he is the problem because he has deceived mainstream Australians; and he is the problem because he has divided Australians. He has divided them on all sorts of issues such as the republic. But the worst division of all, the one for which he will go down in history, is the increased division between the rich and the poor. That is what he has done as Treasurer, and that is what he is continuing to do as Prime Minister.

Australians have said through the Canberra voters that they are sick and tired of this government's arrogance, of the Prime Minister's political grandstanding while he is overseas and of his cynical manipulation of events to suit his own view of the world—and he reinvents history to suit his own view of the world. It is not just the people of Canberra, it is the university students, families and older Australians—in fact, everyone who is concerned about what is happening in Australia and to Australia. They are not very interested in what his views are about redesigning cities in Germany or wherever else he might happen to decide that he is going to grandstand—in Paris or Asia or wherever. Whatever they must have thought of him in Singapore when he stood there having a go at John Howard on the steps of Parliament House just makes the mind boggle.

You only have to look at how Mr Keating and this government have ignored the needs and aspirations of older Australians to appreciate the magnitude of his arrogance and indifference. Seniors are not a group to be disregarded or patronised. They are an increasingly active, vocal and powerful group, and they are sick and tired of being overlooked and ignored. They are concerned about a whole range of issues and, principally, what they want is stability, financial and physical security, access to affordable and good quality health care, and confidence that they will be cared for if and when they can no longer look after themselves.

Older Australians must be just staggered when they hear, as they have done, that nobody seems to be able to get access to Minister Lawrence. One of the Senate committees recently had a hearing on the health reforms, and group after group said that they had not been consulted. When you talk to the age care industry, the same message comes through. Older Australians must know that their views are not being represented to the minister because she, like her boss, does not want to listen.

Older people are not just concerned about economic issues, they are also concerned about the value systems in our society and about social cohesion. Some of them must have been mortified—and that is the only word I can use—to read the guide to safe sex in Cleo and that it was not a factual description of safe sex, but that it advocated a range of sexual behaviours that, in fact, one woman in her seventies told Senator Herron she had never known about.

Older people are also concerned about the quality of life relating not just to economic wellbeing but also to levels of happiness, contentment and, as I said, social cohesion. They are concerned about falling living standards. They are concerned about unemployment. Unemployment affects many older people. Look what the government has had to do. It has had to bring in a mature age allowance because there are so many long-term unemployed in that senior category, that older group.

Older people are concerned about retirement incomes, they are concerned about the health system, and they are concerned about community services. Minister Crowley today could not even answer a question as to whether the government was going to reduce HACC yet again, having done so in real terms three out of the last four years. These people are concerned about inflexibility in residential care and respite care for older people.

These are just a few examples of how the government and the Prime Minister have failed to appreciate the needs and aspirations of older Australians. They are also grandparents who care and are concerned about their children and their grandchildren not being able to find jobs and having to pay increased interest on their mortgages. It affects them as well as their own children and their grandchildren. The Canberra people have demonstrated to the Prime Minister that they care about Australia and that he does not.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In contributing to the defence of the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this debate, I think we need to look at what we understand to be the needs and aspirations of mainstream Australia first and then look at how the Prime Minister, who—I do not think anyone would dispute—has had a central role in policy development for this government over the last decade or so. Some of the needs and aspirations of Australians would include a secure economic future.
—Well, they haven't got that!

—I will get to that in a moment, Senator Patterson. They include things like a house, a secure retirement, a health policy and a pride in the country. I think they are the sorts of things we would all accept are important to meet the needs and aspirations of mainstream Australia. Senator Patterson touched on a number of matters relating to the ACT by-election. We heard the same theme after the Wills by-election; we heard the same theme after the Adelaide by-election; we heard the same theme after the Port Adelaide by-election—all before general elections which we won.
—So you haven't listened.
—No, we are listening, Senator Patterson. The important thing about by-elections is they do send a message.
—Is this what he told you in caucus this morning?

—No, the caucus was remarkably placid this morning. We listen and we learn from our by-election losses, but we do not panic. The point I make is that if you think the next election is a lay down misere because of last Saturday, then think again.

PARA.TAB: Let us deal with some of the needs and aspirations that mainstream Australia expects to be dealt with in policy terms. Senator Patterson touched on the seniors and retirement issues. Which government has tackled the issue of retirement income, superannuation?

TALK.START.PARA: —You ask them.

—I meet with significant numbers of them. I had some in my office last week. I ask you: who dealt with the issue of putting aside sufficient income for people's retirement, given the range of problems we face with the aging population? Our government has dealt with that and Paul Keating was central to the development of that policy. Ours is the first government since 1949 to deal with the issue, and we have dealt with it in an effective way. I am not going to devote my contribution to the debate to the details of our superannuation policy, but by the year 2025 there will be sufficient savings via the superannuation policy, combined with the basic age pension, to provide a better average income than is currently provided through the age pension. We have done that. You can laugh and try to destroy that, as indeed your policy would do by freezing contributions, but that is an essential contribution to the wellbeing of the people of Australia and this Prime Minister has played an important role in that, particularly when he was Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: I want to mention a couple of the economic issues. Senator Schacht concentrated on the impressive economic growth. There is also the issue of inflation. Until the last for our five years we were a high inflation country. Our underlying rate of inflation this year will be 2 to 2 1/4 per cent. That compares very well with other countries. It compares very well with the record over the previous 20 years. One of the monumental economic failures of the current opposition when it was in government, when John Howard was Treasurer, was its failure to tackle the issue of inflation.

Interest rates are important from both the economic perspective and the perspective of housing purchase. Currently, interest rate bills are substantially lower than the average levels over the past 20 years. I know there is some concern in the community about this issue. People can remember when interest rates were touching 20 per cent four years ago and I think they fear that interest rates will move back to those levels. I believe very strongly that that is not going to occur, but I understand that people have that fear and that is an issue which we are in the process of dealing with by dealing with issues like our economic growth, the budget, the deficit—and how that unfolds we will see in May. But the issue of interest rates is very central to the concerns of Australians. It is one that the Prime Minister has acknowledged and holds uppermost in his mind.

At the moment we are enjoying economic growth and job growth at an unprecedented level. There will be 300,000 new jobs this year. Our unemployment rate is expected to fall to 8.5 per cent by the June quarter of this year. This is a much better outcome than we forecast in last year's budget. The opposition pooh poohed and criticised the projections in last year's budget. Employment has risen by 4.4 per cent through the 12 months to February of this year. We have exceeded our commitment to job growth made at the last election. That is obviously an issue which has to be uppermost in the minds of mainstream Australia and again is an issue which the Prime Minister, in terms of developing policy as part of the government, is very concerned about.

Other issues that we have tackled since we have been in government include health and the Medicare system. What is the opposition's solution to providing basic health care for all Australians? Again, it was this government that introduced Medicare. It was this Prime Minister as Treasurer who played a central role in the development of that policy. In respect of issues such as retirement incomes, carrying out an essential restructuring of the Australian economy, economic growth, inflation and health, the Prime Minister is very much in touch with the needs and aspirations of mainstream Australia. They are the basic fundamentals that everyone agrees need to be tackled.

I want to touch on one issue about which the Prime Minister is lambasted, and that is the theme that I mentioned when I began: pride in your own country. Our Prime Minister passionately believes that we should have an Australian as head of state of this country. He passionately believes that but most in the opposition apparently do not accept that as a theme. Well, fine, that is up to you. I know that everyone on our side is passionately devoted to that goal of the Prime Minister's. You can call it divisive if you like; we would call it effective leadership—making sure that the political institutions of this country reflect the modern needs of this country. The Prime Minister, I and all of us on this side of the chamber do not want to see the monarch of another country as the head of state of this country. The time for that has gone and the time for the development of an Australian head of state is here. You can resist that if you like. You can call it divisive and, by your definition, it is divisive, but we would call it effective leadership and making sure the political institutions of this country are indeed reflecting the times and the needs of our future.

The Prime Minister's devotion to improving and establishing our links with Asia through the APEC forum is often a hard issue for people in the community to understand and to accept. There has been, I think, always a latent concern about our relationships with Asia, for obvious historical reasons, particularly with a country like Japan but, again, it is an issue that has to be tackled and our Prime Minister is tackling it because it is essential for the future economic development of this country that we have very strong links with our Asian trading nations. Who would have believed 10 years ago that Korea was to overtake the United States as our major trading partner. Again the Prime Minister has spent enormous amounts of policy energy and time in this area.

The opposition can continue to abuse the Prime Minister personally—I think in many areas without justification. You swilled around in the so-called pig controversy when the Prime Minister had some investments in that area. You attack his personal interest in antique clocks and you continue to criticise him as a part-time prime minister because he turns up for two days in question time, but that will not do you any good at the end of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —For 12 long, excruciating years Australians have been putting up with Labor's politics of interest groups. We have had 12 years of this government trying to buy off and politicise a whole variety of interest groups in Australia—whether it is ethnic groups, green groups, trade unionists, artists, whatever. Labour's whole approach to politics has been this approach of interest groups. But this playing off interest groups is finally catching up with the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: We saw it here earlier this year with the great confrontation between the greens and the forestry trade unionists which had Labor in its pincers, and we have really seen it come to the fore in the Canberra by-election where the politics of interest groups has really caught up with Labor. But the greatest problem for Labor and the greatest indictment of Labor over the last 12 years is that it has ignored the biggest interest group of all in Australia, and that is Australian families. They have been completely ignored by this government and that is the message out of Canberra. Fortunately, it appears from our point of view that Senator Sherry and Senator Schacht have missed the whole point of the Canberra by-election and that will lead to their defeat in a year's time.

On this issue of families, it is tragic that the government wasted the opportunity provided to it last year, which was the International Year of the Family. Most Australians would not know that now. It was a wasted opportunity. The Labor government could have put primacy upon Australian families and it did not. The year was wasted with debate about what a family was. The greatest achievement that the Labor Party can claim from last year is the use of the external affairs powers to override Tasmania's laws on homosexuality. That is the only thing we got from this government in the International Year of the Family.

The government had the Cass report, the national report from the Council for the International Year of the Family. That report came down late last year with some damning criticism of the government's family policy. We have seen nothing from the government yet, no government response to that. We know from that what priority this government places on families who are mainstream Australia but who are constantly ignored by this government. That is the real message of the Canberra by-election.

I happened to be the campaign director for the Adelaide and Port Adelaide by-elections which I thought showed significant swings and concerns among Australians about Labor, but I never expected anything like the Canberra by-election. That was a staggering swing, twice the size of the Adelaide by-election. It certainly means that those on the government benches opposite will soon be on this side of the chamber.

The government is ignoring what is a very deep, underlying concern in Australia; that is, the extent of and consequences flowing from family breakdown. There are enormous pressures on families in Australia today that the government seems to be incapable of recognising. Those concerns relate very much to taxes—the threat of higher taxes and the broken promises of this government on taxes. The Australian people feel conned by what happened in 1993. We have seen that in the results of the Canberra by-election. They are taking it out on the government because it conned them on taxes.

The Australian people feel conned on interest rates. Those opposite promised to keep interest rates down. Just in the last six months the Australian people have seen interest rates rise three times. Interest rates now are costing Australian families $60 a month more because of the government's incompetent economic management. The Australian people are still very concerned about unemployment—eight per cent unemployment and much higher rates of youth unemployment.

There is concern about not only the economic pressures on families but also what is occurring in Australian society. Divorce in Australia is now at a 10-year high. Family breakdown is costing Australians $3,000 million a year; there are over 45,000 children a year who are affected by it; and we have the highest youth suicide rate in the world. What more damning indictment can there be of this government's complete ignorance as to what is of most concern to mainstream Australia—and that is the position of Australian families.

The government is simply not focusing on the things that really matter to ordinary, mainstream Australians—those things being family concerns. The government has no strategy for dealing with Australian families and their concerns; it is totally preoccupied with attacking us. It seems much more concerned with the coalition and John Howard than it is with ordinary Australians. It says to us here today that it wonders why we are so concerned with Keating. Our concern with Mr Keating is nothing compared to the government's utter preoccupation with our leader, John Howard.

The government is running around the country, destroying our constitution and our freedom of speech, trying to create issues out of the flag and the Racial Hatred Bill. It is simply not dealing with the issues that matter to ordinary Australians. The government really seems to have lost its capacity to read the polls. I notice opposite a former state secretary from Western Australia, Senator Chris Evans. I am amazed at the way the government forgets the fact that the issues that rate in the polls are taxes, interest rates and unemployment. They are the issues that matter to Australians—not the republic, the flag or racial hatred. Those issues do not rate at all.

The government is suffering, I think, from the loss of Senator Richardson, and it will soon suffer from the loss of Senator Loosley. I think at least they knew what really mattered to ordinary Australians because at least they could understand opinion polls.

This government is fundamentally anti-family. There is nothing in anything that this government has done for 12 years that we could really say points to this government being pro-family. There have been consistent attacks on family allowances. There has been a constant lowering of the means test on family allowances. We have seen from the leaked budget papers that there is a proposition to lower the means test for family allowance from $60,000 down to $35,000. What the government has done in relation to the home child-care allowance and the child-care cash rebate is nothing more than a flagrant attack on the position of Australian families.

The government is providing incentives through the rebate system for women to enter the paid work force and place their children in child care; it is doing so in such a way as to grossly discriminate against women who sacrifice an income to care for their children at home. The government's whole policy is biased against women who sacrifice an income to care for their children at home. That was recognised in the Cass report. The Cass report, which the government has completely ignored, called for the amalgamation of those two payments because they are so discriminatory and because they are biased against ordinary Australian families and in favour of those who put their children in child care and go into the paid work force.

The Canberra by-election result was an extraordinary manifestation of the problems being experienced by ordinary Australian families, by mainstream Australians. The government will reap a whirlwind in one year's time if it ignores the lessons of the Canberra by-election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion. In doing so, I congratulate the previous speaker Senator Minchin. As always, he makes a thoughtful and politically motivated contribution. Really, I think in his contribution he reflected the reasons behind the Liberal Party moving this motion. It is a question of the Liberal Party trying to put its spin on the results of the weekend, to put its interpretation on the result.
—Let's hear you put your spin on it!

—That is a perfectly legitimate political tactic to pursue—and that is fine. But it is interesting to note that the reasons the Liberal Party did so well in the Canberra by-election just happen to coincide with all the things that Senator Minchin has been talking about in the last few years. All the other opposition speakers have also found that the reasons the Liberal Party did so well in the Canberra by-election coincide with all those things that they have been pursuing for many years. After the Fremantle by-election when there was a one per cent swing to the Labor Party, I do not recall those opposite making the same speeches. But that is what political opportunism is all about.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing about today's motion is the reference to the aspirations of mainstream Australia. Here we go again: Johnny Howard's vision, the white picket fence, the little wife at home with a couple of kids, all wrapped up in the flag, talking about the queen and toasting the empire. That may be the view of mainstream Australia held by those opposite, but my view is that it is a much more multicultural and diverse society than that.

What the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is about is trying to represent all Australians, taking up the issues of all Australians. When he talks about Mabo and native title, he is taking up the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal Australians. When he is talking about the Racial Hatred Bill, he is taking up concerns raised by multicultural Australians or Australians of non-English speaking background. When we take up some of these other issues that so divide and cause so many problems for the Liberal Party, we are taking up the issues of all Australians—rather than promoting this view of Australia as being some sort of homogeneous group of people, all having some sort of single view of the world. I think this really reflects the Liberal Party's longing for some past Australian society, which I do not think ever really existed, but that is for them.

Quite frankly, the fact that I felt quite shaken by the Canberra result—like most Labor members should—I found quite beneficial. I am very keen to examine the reasons why the Labor Party did so poorly. But, unlike some of my colleagues on the other side of the chamber and some of my own colleagues, I intend to give it a bit more of a professional and scientific analysis than a merely knee-jerk reaction and the use of one's own prejudices to try to interpret the result. And I am sure Senator Minchin will be giving it a much more professional examination than one would suspect from his contribution today. I hope that some of my colleagues do also, because there is a message in there for the Labor Party. It is important that we understand and hear that message. I do not agree with Mr Downer's analysis of the importance of the result. However, I think it is important that the Labor Party listens to that result. I am sure we will, and I think the Prime Minister has indicated that.

Interestingly, though, while we are on the question of weekend election results, I think it is important to point out that the New South Wales people are also part of mainstream Australia. The millions of people who voted in New South Wales in the election on Saturday also expressed a view. While I regard the Canberra by-election as very important, I also regard the result in New South Wales as very important. It was a contest between Labor and Liberal; it was a contest about who should govern in that state for the next four years. I think one also has to give due weight to that when talking about what is happening in Australian society.

It is interesting in that I think the Liberal Party before Saturday shared my view. It is only since Saturday that its members have been keen to talk about the Canberra result and less keen to talk about New South Wales. In the last week in the Senate, prior to those elections, members of the Liberal and National coalition made 31 contributions on the New South Wales election. On 31 occasions they rose to discuss the New South Wales election and how they would be sending a message to Canberra with the re-election of the Fahey government.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 25 of 1994-95—Efficiency Audit—Australian Defence Force—Living-in Accommodation—Department of Defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the second part of a report by the Australian National Audit Office into the accommodation of Defence Force personnel. The Senate looked at the first part of the report some time ago. This report today relates to the accommodation of people, including single people without family, living in Defence barracks. It is interesting to note that the proportion of members who are required to live in for operational or other reasons represents about 25 per cent of all members without families. Many members choose to live off-base if they can, but usually they are required to obtain the consent of their CO if they are to be eligible for living out allowances. Often people who are living out of barracks are doing so totally at their own expense.

PARA.TAB: It is important to the Defence Force that certain personnel live in barracks, especially young or new recruits who need to develop an esprit de corps, et cetera. Often, as people get older, it is less appropriate and less necessary for them to live in barracks.

Community attitudes towards living standards have changed considerably in the last few years. The lack of privacy associated with living in barracks needs to be contended with by the Defence Force. There is a need for privacy; there is a need for more space. I am sad to find that over the past 10 years there have been recommendations in these areas, yet little or nothing has been done about them.

It is sad that this report was needed at all. As I say, reports in this area have been presented to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), yet little or no action has been taken in relation to accommodation for members without families. Having said that, I recognise that money has been spent on upgrading existing accommodation, but the scales and standards still have not been changed and there is still a lack of privacy. The Auditor-General has been fairly critical of the failure of the department to respond to previous reviews.

The report contains recommendations which propose that the separation of food and accommodation charges is an essential step in the process of resolving inequities between members. Members with families are treated in a different way from those without families, and it is to the detriment of those with families. There were reviews in 1982 and there were two reviews in 1991. There has been deferral of some action until there is an outcome of a fundamental review of personnel policy. That is not due for completion until the middle of this year. Consultants have been engaged to consider payment of a cash subsidy as an option to the provision of accommodation. The audit office is concerned that, despite a series of reviews, as I have said, inequities and financial disabilities associated with accommodation assistance for ADF members have been allowed to continue.

The audit office has recommended that Defence take action to consider all outstanding matters relating to ADF accommodation, removal and relocation conditions. I add my voice to the Auditor-General. It is totally unsatisfactory that recommendation after recommendation has gone to government for more than 10 years and we still have the same recommendations being made in 1995 by the Auditor-General.

The audit office noted that the existing arrangements had resulted in some dissatisfaction among members. As I have mentioned, there is a lack of privacy and loss of social freedom in on-base accommodation. A measure of the level of dissatisfaction is that some 35 per cent of people married without families are choosing to live off-base without financial assistance. I mentioned the recent upgrading program, but a significant proportion of the accommodation still does not meet the service's own scales and standards, and those scales and standards are out of date in terms of space available per person.

The audit office considers that Defence may need to give further consideration to the standard of accommodation provided for these personnel in order to improve the equity between ADF members. Currently, there is no centralised record of the level of accommodation utilisation or of the availability of suitable accommodation. There is little information available relating to the variation in the quality of the accommodation. Accurate and complete accommodation records are essential for planning and costing purposes and for other purposes as well. The audit office has recommended that guidelines be developed for the classification of accommodation and that a survey of the standard of the existing accommodation be conducted and incorporated into a central database.

I have here a report of the Inspector-General's Division of the Department of Defence of January 1991. Some of the recommendations contained in this report are just the same as those that are being given today. I draw attention to the recommendation in the 1991 report that a recognition of the appropriateness of different types of accommodation must be accompanied by a recognition of the negative impact on moral and hence operational effectiveness of poor standard accommodation. The 1991 report also notes that to determine living in accommodation requirements accurate information is required on patterns of utilisation. The evaluation team found that planning was often not based on accurate information or verifiable assumptions.

Four years later the Auditor-General is saying the same thing. The inquiry in 1991 said that there was a lack of systems in place to effectively record the real cost of the accommodation. Similarly, there was no system in place to enable coordination of accommodation booking within services or between services. The report also noted that the space entitlements for members in this sort of accommodation needed to be increased. The team also found that reliable data on the real costs of providing accommodation, particularly the individual establishments, were not generally available and this deficiency was due to a combination of dispersed authority and responsibility for those costs and a lack of suitable systems for control of the costs.

I could continue reading the recommendations contained in the 1991 report from the Inspector-General which are almost word for word those contained in today's report from the Auditor-General. Suffice to summarise, I say that nothing seems to have been done. With 108,081 people employed in the Defence function by the taxpayers of Australia, how is it that nobody seems to have been made available to do something about the living in accommodation of Defence Force personnel? Why is it that in running a major department of state worth billions of dollars that department cannot spare anybody out of that 108,000 people to get proper databases and information systems in place and to cost and value the assets, their maintenance and their use? I think it is a scandal. What are these 108,081 people doing? Fighting the battle of Russell Hill? I cannot see that we are going to get very far with them in light of their lack of progress to date.

We constantly find the Auditor-General coming before us saying, `We've made recommendations to Defence and they haven't been implemented.' It is not good enough. If Defence had a real limitation on the number of public servants and restrictions on the information systems that it has been able to introduce, for example, then perhaps we could understand. But Defence has been spending millions of dollars on information systems over the last five or six years. It has 108,000 people available for the Defence function. Surely, some of these people and these resources could have been put to work to make sure that it was running as an efficient organisation in terms of its management of its assets and its provision of quality accommodation for its personnel. If we are not able to provide good quality accommodation for those who for one reason or another must live in, then we do not deserve to have people whom we have spent a lot of money on in respect of training wanting to stay in the Defence Force.

It is in the interests of the nation that we do not lose people prematurely after we have invested so much in their training. One day—God forbid—we may need every one of these people that we have invested so heavily in. We do not want to find that they have been dispersed to the four winds and their skills have become rusty for the lack of concern about the quality of their accommodation. How many of us in this place would want to live in some of the barrack accommodation that is available to our defence personnel around Australia? While I recognise that some of the accommodation has been upgraded, most of us would consider it was accommodation of the 1960s and the 1970s, not the 1990s.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present part 2 of the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee on its inquiry into the development of open learning in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to table part 2 of this report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee on the development of open learning in Australia. This is the first report that we have tabled since the death of our deputy chair, former Senator Olive Zakharov. Olive Zakharov made a substantial contribution to this inquiry, and she had, of course, a very strong professional interest in education matters as a former teacher and school counsellor. Senator Zakharov attended all the public hearings and meetings of the committee during the inquiry and the committee wishes to place on record its appreciation of her contribution to this report.

PARA.TAB: In part 1 of the report, which we tabled in December 1994, the committee looked at the role played in open learning by the Open Learning Agency of Australia, the Open Learning Technology Corporation and the Open Learning Electronic Service, which has now become known as Open Net. The committee report at this time was highly critical of the establishment, structure and operation of the OLAA, after hearing evidence from a very wide range of stakeholders.
The committee's main recommendations in part 1 are that the government enter negotiations with Monash University and the AVCC with a view to placing the Open Learning

SPEECH.PARA: Agency of Australia under the auspices of the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee and that the government provide funds equivalent to 50 per cent of the EFTSU for students entering the system through the Open Learning Agency. We urge the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee, which is still considering these recommendations, to accept them so that the work of the Open Learning Agency can be placed on a proper national footing inclusive of all universities and so that the sector can be better placed and properly funded to enter the international marketplace, where quality must be assured.

PARA.TAB: In part 2 of the report, which I am tabling today, the committee has looked more broadly at the many exciting facets of open learning as they unfold in this country. The committee was very impressed with the many fine examples of open learning practice which are encountered in a whole range of areas, particularly in higher education and the TAFE system.

Universities, in particular those that have had a tradition of offering distance education, are at the forefront of the developments in open learning in Australia. The former distance education centres, or DECs, as they are known, are playing a major role in providing the infrastructure and the expertise necessary to develop open learning courses and to assist students who enrol in these courses. In 1994, there were around 69,000 distant education enrolments in universities, mostly in the DECs, with around 5,000 students registered through the OLAA.

A concern which emerged during the inquiry was that there seemed to be no coordination of the various open learning programs currently offered at different levels in our education system. Accordingly, the committee has recommended to the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs the establishment of a forum representative of the key education and training interest groups to develop a blueprint for the implementation of open learning across schools, vocational education and training and the higher education sector.

One of the major outcomes of the present lack of coordination was the problem that it creates for students who are seeking credit transfer between institutions and levels of education. At present, students who are unable, for various reasons, to obtain credit for courses already completed use public funds to repeat these courses. Institutions have found that assessment of prior learning can be difficult and expensive and are often reluctant to engage in it. This process is extremely wasteful. My own daughter was caught up with this when she transferred between universities doing a Bachelor of Business course. Going from one university to another, the courses did not exactly match. She had done in a previous course twice as much commercial law as she needed to do for the new university, so it was not going to count half the law she did. This sort of silly anomaly has to go. If students, particularly in what is called a unified national system, have completed one-third of a degree in a university, they should get recognition for one-third of the degree when they move to another institution.

Credit transfer arrangements, which the government is now trumpeting as being one of its great triumphs, I have discovered from personal interest to be very much in their infancy. I would urge the government to move on in this area as fast as it can. It is very wasteful not to do so, because what you are doing really is requiring students to repeat credit points that they have already done. This takes up resources, staffing, and library and building space at a university, so it is totally counterproductive. The committee is pleased to see that the government and the AVCC came to an agreement on 14 February to establish, on a pilot basis, a national credit transfer agency; and the permanent agency will be established later this year.

Open learning is used extensively also in vocational education and training and, in particular, by the TAFE institutions who wish to reach students around Australia who otherwise would not be able to complete the courses that are offered. TAFE prefers to use the term `flexible delivery' rather than `open learning'; and we did discover, as we moved around Australia, that some of the most innovative approaches to open learning came from the TAFE sector.

There are also in this area a number of companies which are encouraging their employees to undertake courses through open learning; and the committee learned of several Australian companies that have entered into arrangements with both university and TAFE sectors to provide courses tailored to their needs. I have certainly seen this on the north coast of New South Wales at Southern Cross University, which has developed a range of courses, from certificate right through to PhD, that are tailored to the needs of private and public companies. That development is most welcome.

There is also, at another level, a great development in open learning in the high schools of New South Wales. But one fears that the cost of infrastructure to do it properly in this new technological age will put a brake on schools' participation. To overcome the disadvantage of schools that cannot afford to have access to open learning networks, the committee has recommended that the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs develop a joint Commonwealth-state funding proposal to establish a base level of telecommunications and computing infrastructure in the schools by the year 2000.

This I have seen develop overseas, and states like North Carolina are moving very quickly towards all public infrastructure, including all schools being linked to the information superhighway. The adult and community education sector is another group which fears that it will not be able to participate properly in open learning because of its inability to meet the high cost involved in the acquisition of computer equipment.

We met with that group today. Since our report on adult and community education there has been some landmark changes in this sector. We urge the government not to rest on its laurels but to provide further material and further resources so that that group can have proper access to open learning, particularly with new technology. Equity and access is heavily dependent on facilitating access to such groups by opening existing school facilities after hours, for example. We need that sort of flexibility in the system so that adult and community education can fully develop.

The development of open learning has resulted in a blurring of the lines and increasing pressure on facilities and resources, particularly in the TAFE sectors and in relation to public libraries. The pressure is often coming from students enrolled with institutions other than those from which they seek assistance. It is important that appropriate funding arrangements be put in place to ensure that all open learning students have access to the learning materials and support they need for the successful completion of the courses in which they are enrolled.

During the inquiry the committee visited educational centres in every state of the nation as well as the Northern Territory. An Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory provided an excellent example of the use of the open learning technique through the Tanami network. The community uses the network to overcome some of the disadvantages imposed on its students by distance and the lack of support systems for those who choose to move to a major centre to study. (Extension of time granted).

At present the success of these students is heavily dependent on the availability of an on-site tutor who takes them through the work and enables them to work at their own pace. There is some anxiety regarding the continuation of funding for this on-site tutor. The committee recommends that DEET continue this funding and recommends the extension and development of the Tanami network to support open learning initiatives for Aboriginal students in remote communities.

There was a recognition amongst the many players in open learning that it could also provide opportunities for further export of education. If those opportunities are to be fully exploited, greater attention will have to be paid to the important issue of courseware development for open learning in the vocational education and training sector in particular in order to meet the requirements for overseas markets.

The OLTC, which is the Open Learning Technology Corporation, and the Australian Committee for Training Curriculum both have a role to play in advising the ministerial council on the development of a coherent approach to the funding and coordination of courseware development, not just for this country but for the export potential in overseas markets.

The committee is of the view that open learning entails a paradigm shift in the way in which we provide education and training to meet the technical and intellectual requirements of the future and in particular to serve the concept of learning as a lifelong activity. The way in which we have done things so far and the conceptual and structural boundaries that surround them are profoundly challenged by and indeed often antagonistic to open learning.

Traditional institutions, teacher training, administrative structures and policies designed for semester-bound courses and campus-bound students must be all transformed into concepts and structures which make sense in the new open learning environment. Such a transformation requires imagination as much as it requires rigorous thinking. A considerable amount of imagination and rigour is already evident throughout the country in the open learning areas. Schools, universities, TAFE colleges and industry training agencies are using open learning approaches that make changes in their effectiveness and in the quality and accessibility of services that they provide to students.

But, to bring about these changes in favour of open learning at the level of systems, we must bring about major changes in the way in which we measure training effort and also in the way we fund those systems, including how we provide income support for students. The committee has therefore recommended that the Commonwealth undertake a review of the funding of student financial support with a view to accommodating the wide range of study patterns now available to students, particularly as a result of open learning.

The issue of training and support for teachers who are new to open learning approaches needs also to be addressed. There are important industrial relations implications here. We have to change the support and reward systems for teachers if we are to carry through the logic of a student-centred rather than a teacher-centred or institution-centred approach to learning. If we do not make the change, we will greatly diminish the potential of open learning to help students from all walks of life and with very diverse needs to meet their education and training goals. I am confident that the work of the committee and its report on open learning will help to bring about these changes. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

This bill is one of a package of 3 bills which amend Radiocommunications tax legislation to implement improvements to the radiocommunications apparatus licensing regime following the findings of a public inquiry held by the Spectrum Management Agency.
The other 2 bills in this package are the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1994 and the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1994.

A majority of submissions to the SMA's inquiry supported the issuing of apparatus licences for periods of up to 5 years, and greater flexibility for licensees in relation to the payment of licence fees, either by full up-front payment, or by annual instalments which may or may not be equal.
With the commissioning of its new licensing computer system in March 1995, the SMA will be in a position to issue apparatus licences for terms of up to 5 years.

The proposed bills will give spectrum users greater flexibility in organising their licensing arrangements. Under the amendments proposed in the 3 bills, an applicant for an apparatus licence or a licensee will be able to choose between the following tax options:
(i)for an apparatus licence issued for a period of 12 months, payment of the annual licence fee current at the time the licence is issued;
(ii)for a licence issued for a period of more than 12 months, payment at the time of issue of the total licence fees;
(iii)for a licence issued for a period of more than 12 months, payment of an annual instalment upon issue and on each anniversary of the date of issue during the term of the licence; or

(iv)for a licence issued for a period of more than 12 months, where the licensee has previously elected to pay by annual instalments, and then decides to pay the balance of the licence fees, payment of the balance on the next occurring anniversary of the issue of the licence.
The Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill and the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill provide for the imposition of tax under each of these options.
The Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Amendment Bill amends the Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Act 1983 to set out the time the tax becomes payable under each option.
Where a licensee defaults on a payment of tax, the licensee will have failed to comply with the act, which would allow the suspension or cancellation of the licence.

The Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Amendment Bill includes an amendment which will enable the SMA to determine that an interest penalty is payable by a licensee who is paying tax upon each anniversary of the issue of the licence, but does not pay upon the due date for an anniversary. Such a determination will be disallowable by the Parliament.

The Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill and the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill include a provision which will impose tax if a default persists for 60 days following the anniversary payment due date. The amount of tax would reflect the total amount payable over the remaining period of the licence.
Financial Impact

It is not possible to make a firm estimate of the financial impact of the proposed amendments as it is impossible to estimate accurately what percentage of licensees will take up the option of apparatus licences of more than 12 months when that option is made generally available to licensees and, of those, what proportion will elect to pay the full fee up-front, rather than pay on each anniversary during the currency of the licence.
The overall intention for the legislative package is to provide more flexible methods of paying licence fees for licensees with no net loss of revenue over the period of the licence.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Australian Land Transport Development Program for 1993-94—almost another financial year has gone—shows that for national arterials Western Australia was allocated $22 million for works from 1 July 1993 to 31 December 1993 and a further $22 million from 1 January 1994 to 30 June 1994.

PARA.TAB: This report also states that 29 kilometres of the Kalgoorlie-Meekatharra-Pilbara highway was sealed. To anyone looking at this report, on the surface that may seem a great distance, but when looking at it in the context of the massive distances to be covered in those areas, it is very minimal. How totally inadequate that road is was borne out by the floods we had recently.

On the Goldfields, Pilbara and Midwest highway, as it is commonly known, you can go from eastern Australia to Kalgoorlie and head up towards the Pilbara, but at the same time you may be able to go to the western region of Geraldton. There is a big debate about which route that should take—whether it should go up to Wiluna, across to Meekatharra and up to the Pilbara, whether it should go from Leinster over to Mt Magnet and then to the Pilbara or to Geraldton, or whether it should go from Goldfields up to Wiluna and then up to Three Rivers station, Meekatharra and so forth. There is so much debate amongst the locals about which way that should go that I will leave it to them to finally work that out. The main point I make is that the funding that has been given to them is totally inadequate.

The report says that an extension of the Reid Highway was completed in that year, at a cost of $29 million, and also that $24 million was spent for 3 1/2 kilometres of Roe Highway, to take that over to Welshpool. Of course, that is a welcome extension and we look forward to that sort of highway system around Perth continuing and finally being finished.

The report also mentioned the 12 kilometre extension of the Kwinana Freeway for $36 million. The report says—this amazes me—that the extension of the Kwinana Freeway a further 12 kilometres between Forest Road and Thomas Road at a cost of $36 million completes construction of the entire Kwinana Freeway from Perth to Rockingham. It was my understanding—I presume it was the understanding of all Western Australian members and senators—that that freeway would be finished down by Rockingham and not by going down to Forest Road and having to do a hard right over to the highway that goes down through to Rockingham at present. I hope what is in the report is a mistake, because it would be ridiculous if that program was not finished and did not extend the bottom of the freeway in the proper way to take it right through to Kwinana. I look forward to the day this government makes the sort of money available that will enable that to be done.

I put on record the dismay of Western Australia at the lack of road funding it gets from this federal government. I have said before and I will say again that in 1994, $760 million was raised in fuel levies in Western Australia and only $150 million went back to that state. In 1995, $1 billion in fuel levies will be raised from Western Australia and only $150 million will go back there. This shows a total disregard for the state that supplies 25 per cent of Australia's export income and it is time this government addressed that situation. Otherwise, it will have to be addressed when the Howard government comes into action.
