(b)Senator Baume caused an injustice to a citizen to arise in the course of proceedings in the Senate without the Senate being aware of that consequence, and thereby impeded the Senate in the free exercise of its functions, and/or
(c)any other ground consistent with section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, and
(ii)if the action of Senator Baume could not be held to be a contempt under the law as it presently stands, whether such action should be able to be held to be a contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: In this parliament we are used to some pretty robust exchanges and some fairly crude use from time to time of the protections afforded by parliamentary privilege. There is a tradition of fairly high levels of tolerance for privacy invading and confidentiality invading behaviour which might otherwise be extremely questionable. These occasions often generate some heated parliamentary debate. Certainly, I have directed quite a lot of fire at Senator Baume in this respect in the past.

PARA.TAB: Sometimes a piece of parliamentary behaviour, or misbehaviour, under cover of privilege is so crude and so extreme that if the parliament is to retain any self-respect and any community respect as an institution, it just has to take some strong action. Such was the case last Thursday night when Senator Baume tabled copies of documents from the Australian Taxation Office setting out details of adjustments made and the tax payable by Dr Peter Macdonald, the independent candidate for Manly in the New South Wales election, for the period 1984 to 1989, which documents included Dr Macdonald's tax file number.

Had it occurred outside the parliament, Senator Baume's behaviour in publishing this material, in particular the tax file number, would have been criminally punishable. The Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes it an offence punishable by two years imprisonment or a fine of up to $10,000, or both, for the unauthorised disclosure of a person's tax file number.

Senator Baume's only stated purpose in doing what he did last Thursday night was to impugn the integrity of Dr Macdonald as the independent candidate for Manly, to secure political advantage. As he said himself:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Dr Macdonald's own taxation record shows a lack of integrity that must be of major concern to his constituents in Manly.

Senator Baume claimed at the time that he was only pre-empting an exercise by Dr Macdonald's own supporters, as he said, `dropping what is known as a bucket on the Liberal candidate for Manly at the last minute in the campaign for the state election, so denying Mr Oldfield the opportunity of an effective response.'

PARA.TAB: The intention to embark on this course of behaviour is what Senator Baume is attributing to the other side. But, of course, no such bucket, to use his terminology, was dropped by Dr Macdonald's supporters and Senator Baume was obliged to acknowledge the next day, as he did on ABC radio on 24 March, that there had in fact been no such intention by the local paper, the Manly Daily, to publish the material he was concerned about .

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that, that there had been no such intention.
—Whatever their original—
—This is a serious matter. Get it right.
—They made the decision. You acknowledge they made a decision not to publish it.
—They said there was no intention.
—There might have been an original intention to do something, but they didn't proceed with it.
—Just get it right.

—You get it right, Senator Baume, before you get stroppy, because you are the one that has perpetrated one of the most outrageous pieces of behaviour I have ever been familiar with in my 17 years in this parliament. Don't let's have any moral indignation from you.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume's actions were not only not encouraged or endorsed, it seems, by the New South Wales Liberal government, but also generated an immediate reaction from the Premier, Mr Fahey, who immediately dissociated himself from Senator Baume's actions. He said, quoting from various interviews:

SPEECH.PARA: I had no knowledge of the matter going to be raised.
To quote again:
I do not play politics that way now or ever. . . I never would play politics that way.

Whether Mr Fahey or any other senior members of the Liberal establishment did know about this exercise of Senator Baume is something that is challenged by Dr Macdonald. I do not know who is right in this respect. I do not know who knew what. I certainly know that it is on the public record that Mr Fahey has dissociated himself on the strongest possible terms from Senator Baume's behaviour.

PARA.TAB: In other statements reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 March, Mr Fahey says that he had given a personal undertaking to Dr Macdonald not to raise the tax issue, the details of which he had known previously about. The truth of the matter appears clearly to be, as Mr Fahey apparently acknowledged, that Dr Macdonald's understatement of his income was the product of an error made by his former accountant and that back taxes had been paid immediately that error had been sorted out.

In the result, Senator Baume did exactly what he had falsely accused Dr Macdonald's supporters of being about to do. Namely, he raised an apparently very damaging issue at the last possible moment, cynically timing it for maximum effect and maximum exposure, leaving his victim with little or no opportunity—remarkably little opportunity, 24 hours—in which to explain to the electorate the precise circumstances of the adjustment to his tax liability. With the result of this seat apparently still swinging on a handful of votes, it has to be acknowledged that every possibility remains that Senator Baume's dirty trick will have its intended effect: swaying maybe enough votes to make a difference to the outcome of the seat.
Alan Ramsey, who does not pull his punches on these occasions, I think put it very succinctly in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 March. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was a brutal hatchet job on an opponent given no chance to defend himself. His accuser attacked in the dark, under parliamentary privilege, at the last possible moment, from 300 kilometres away. Macdonald campaigning on home ground in Manly knew nothing of what Baume had done until much later. Only the next morning did he get an equal chance to strike back.
He also said:
It was cowardly, sleazy and more than likely self-defeating.

I hope it was self-defeating; as I have just said, that remains very much to be seen. It has been suggested by Senator Baume, in his brief response yesterday in this place, that he is somehow immunised from blame or censure in this matter because he was given leave to do what he did by the duty minister and by the handful of senators present in the chamber at the time of that adjournment debate.

PARA.TAB: It needs to be appreciated that Senator Baume gave no indication whatsoever that the document contained a tax file number. It certainly was not immediately apparent, with the kind of scrutiny that documents sought to be tabled are usually given by duty ministers, that the `file number' referred to in one of the documents was the individual's tax file number. As such, it was an extremely sensitive piece of information.
Senator Baume's preceding comments in the Senate before he tabled the documents certainly gave no indication of their content. He simply said words to this effect:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Macdonald's own taxation record shows a lack of integrity . . . I have evidence which I now seek leave to table.

To take the point now of leave being given, as Senator Baume wants us to do and to attach significance to, is to fail to acknowledge that the courtesies of this place have usually meant that leave is given for request to table documents without much detailed scrutiny or questioning. For Senator Baume to take advantage of that situation in the circumstances of this case is not to take a very elevated position and not to take a position which in any way detracts from his moral liability in this particular instance.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has to now expect that practice to change, so far as scrutiny of documents is concerned. I will be advising members of the government front bench in future to inquire very carefully as to the status of each document for which leave to table is sought. You have got to expect people to be asking you, `Is this document defamatory?', and, `Is it likely to be taken as such?' You have got to expect people to ask you in a further dimension—whether or not you answer it honestly is up to you—`Is a breach of the criminal law involved in this tabling of a document, or would it be if it were outside this parliament?'

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Richo?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the fact that it is so unthinkable that this kind of question would need to be asked in the past simply shows the sheer enormity of Senator Baume's offence on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: There is an earlier occasion in this parliament when the present opposition made clear its own feeling when a government member of parliament made public back in 1988 certain doctor provider numbers in what was argued then by the opposition to be in breach of the Health Insurance Act. In fact, in that case, there was advice from the Solicitor-General that there had been no breach of the Health Insurance Act because the information was essentially statistical in character. In this case, there is no doubt whatsoever—we do not need the Solicitor-General's advice to tell us this—that the Taxation Administration Act does prohibit the disclosure of exactly the information that Senator Baume provided. Had the transaction occurred outside the cover of privilege in this parliament, it would be criminally punishable.
Mr Howard's rhetoric in 1988 knew no bounds when this situation arose. On 23 February 1988, Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot think of a greater abuse of privacy or greater abuse of privilege or a greater abuse of confidentiality than occurred in this particular case.
He went on to say:

What group in this community can possibly feel confident that if it gives this government information, if it trusts the state . . . with any information about private affairs, that information will be kept confidential.

Page after page after page of Hansard rhetoric from Mr Howard, the then Leader of the Opposition before his first demise, without any acknowledgment that there was anything to be said on the other side of the equation. Against that background, we should not be holding our breath waiting for any condemnation from Mr Howard of Senator Baume's abuse of privacy, privilege and confidentiality on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard's repeated endorsement of Mr Ian McLachlan on his `honourable behaviour' over the Hindmarsh documents affair shows that he is simply no longer concerned, if he was ever concerned, about flagrant abuse of privacy and flagrant abuse of confidentiality. By his silence on the present occasion, he will stand condemned. If he does not want to stand condemned, let him answer the questions. Does he think that Senator Baume's actions on Thursday night were honest, decent and principled? Let him answer that question. When did Mr Howard, and Senator Hill for that matter, approve the tactic of tabling the taxation material on Dr Macdonald? Did they approve it? Would they like to answer that? Were they proud of the event that took place? Do they approve it now in retrospect? If they did not approve it, when did Mr Howard, and Senator Hill, move to censure Senator Baume privately for his disgraceful actions? When are they going to do it publicly? By their silence, they will stand condemned.

The question now is: what can the Senate do about the situation with which we are confronted by Senator Baume's behaviour? There is no doubt that Senator Baume, whether he deserves to be or not, is protected by parliamentary privilege from criminal or civil action against him in relation to the documents he tabled. The person whose privacy was so grossly invaded, whose integrity was so disgracefully impugned by Senator Baume, does have the opportunity of reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we talking about the—

—You have got to answer two sorts of questions: one is about the tax file number; the other is about your behaviour in putting on the record information about tax liability deliberately designed to impugn the integrity of an individual knowing perfectly well the circumstances in which that liability was approved, knowing perfectly well that the New South Wales Liberal Party establishment knew about that information and had given an undertaking not to raise it because they knew perfectly well it did not go to the question of Dr Macdonald's integrity. You knew all of that. The confidentiality and the privacy that you breached is a different issue again from the tax file number issue. You stand condemned on both counts.

PARA.TAB: The person whose privacy and confidentiality was so grossly invaded, the person whose integrity was so disgracefully impugned by Senator Baume, does have the opportunity of reply in this place under the privileges resolution that we have passed. But as we all know, that is a rather cumbrous process. The damage, such as it has been, has been well and truly done, given the timing that Senator Baume very deliberately adopted in this matter.

We may never know how much Dr Macdonald has been hurt by Senator Baume's actions. I suppose that we will never be precisely able to calibrate how much mud has stuck. We do not know how many votes were changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Keating's lies during the election?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I have called Senator Panizza to order on a number of occasions. In order to satisfy Senator Panizza, I will ensure that his name is put at top of the speakers list. That should help him to hold quiet for the time being and obey the standing orders of the Senate. As we all know, this is going to be a tough debate. Whilst I am in the chair, I will protect whoever is speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Under what standing order are you going to deny a senator his right to speak in this place?

—There is no point of order. However, in order to satisfy you, I will take the point of order as a question. I am not denying the senator a right to speak. I have called Senator Panizza to order a number of times. I do not want to be forced into a circumstance where I will name a senator. If there is continual disobedience from the floor whilst I am in the chair, I will go to those lengths.

—We may never know how much Dr Macdonald has been hurt by these actions, how much mud has stuck, how many votes were changed and whether that will in practice prove to make a difference to the outcome of this election. A right of reply now, should Dr Macdonald choose to exercise it, can hardly undo that damage, although he should feel free to do so if he believes the record needs further straightening beyond what I have done here tonight.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Baume's actions clearly demand, against that background and against the inadequacy of that other remedy, is the censure of this Senate in the strongest possible terms. The motion before the House does just that. Paragraph (b) of it states:
(b)censures Senator Baume for:

TAB.TAB: (i)his commission of an act, the disclosure of Dr Macdonald's tax file number, which would have been a crime if done outside the Parliament, and
(ii)his blatant and indefensible disregard, for reasons of political advantage rather than any larger public interest, of the privacy of an individual;

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise the point that his disregard was on that basis rather than for any larger public interest. What conceivable larger public interest can be claimed in this case? Senator Baume frankly acknowledged that he was about undermining the integrity of this individual. It was a blatant, straightforward attack of that kind. He deserves stronger censure for it.

PARA.TAB: The situation also clearly demands that Senator Baume apologise to Dr Macdonald and the Senate for his behaviour. The motion also demands that. We can consider at a later stage appropriate redress against him if he fails to make those apologies in the light of this motion's passage.

Finally, the situation also raises the larger question of other possible sanctions against Senator Baume. There was a time in the past when the commission in this place of what would otherwise be a criminal act, were it not protected by privilege, by a member or senator was nonetheless treated as a contempt of parliament that could justify the expulsion of the member or senator concerned. That was essentially the response made by the House of Representatives in the Mahon case in 1920. There was a lot of argument in the Mahon case about whether a real criminal offence was notionally committed or whether it was a defensible exercise of the right of free speech in the circumstances of that case.

We now have a situation whereby the 1987 Parliamentary Privileges Act has not only removed the power to expel, which in the past was treated as an appropriate response to someone who did engage in gross, outrageous and criminal behaviour in the parliament, but also redefined elements of the offence of contempt. If I could find section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, I would read it into the record. I will have to come back to it. Section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act makes it clear that someone can only be subject to proceedings in the House under the Senate's power to proceed for contempt. I am paraphrasing, because I do not have the text of section 4 in front of me. This occurs in circumstances where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate, its committees and senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them from the performance of their functions. That is the essence of section 4.

The question is whether a case can be made that Senator Baume's conduct amounts to a contempt of the Senate within the meaning of section 4. Paragraph (d) of the motion before us outlines the nature of that case. It draws attention to the fact that Senator Baume incompletely informed the Senate as to the nature of the documents and, in particular, did not inform the Senate that it contained the tax file number of a person. Moreover, in doing so, he caused an injustice to a citizen to arise in the course of proceedings in the Senate without the Senate being aware of that consequence, which thereby impeded the Senate in the free exercise of its functions.

That point is arguable. Under the circumstances, and given the time that is available, I do not think it is necessary to further pursue the nature of that argument at this stage. It is an argument, however, that should be looked at very carefully by the privileges committee. It is entirely appropriate that the Standing Committee on Privileges be given a reference in order to enable the full character of section 4, in its present language, to be explored. But in the event that the privileges committee should come to the conclusion that Senator Baume's conduct, however disgraceful, is nonetheless not a contempt within the meaning of section 4, as it is presently set out, the motion asks the committee to consider whether or not such action should be able to be treated as a contempt with some appropriate amendment of the legislation necessary to accommodate that.

The basic point comes down to this: this is a case in which a very strong response is required by this Senate, irrespective of whatever our party affiliations or whatever our views of the course of conduct undertaken by Senator Baume on other matters in the past may be. This case should be looked at entirely on its own terms. It is a situation where, to again use the words of Mr Howard on 23 February 1988, in relation to something much less specifically focused and not aimed at any individual, we have a senator who has acted `deliberately, not accidentally, and cold-bloodedly, not inadvertently'. I repeat, to use Mr Howard's words of 1988, that Senator Baume has acted `deliberately, not inadvertently, and cold-bloodedly, not inadvertently'.

The truth of the matter is that Senator Baume's behaviour, both in putting on the public record a tax file number—which to do so in any context other than a parliamentary one is a criminal offence punishable by a very substantial fine or term of imprisonment—and in putting on the record material deliberately and directly designed to impugn the integrity of an individual who is unable to effectively answer back, for straightforward crass political motives and uncoloured by any larger question of public interest, amounts to one of the most extreme and gross breaches of any residual parliamentary code of decency that might be thought to exist in this place. It is the worst behaviour of this kind that I have ever seen in 17 years in this place. Senator Baume deserves to be censured accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join in this debate and be associated with the remarks made by Senator Gareth Evans. I think it is worthwhile noting that it is a very great honour to serve in the Australian Senate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I did not realise that you were going to call Senator Loosley as part of this debate. I thought he must have had something additional to say or some special point to make. There is currently a motion before the Senate which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it would be the normal practice for a member of the opposition to follow.

—On the point of order: there is no list of who is to speak in this debate. We did not know whether Senator Baume or someone else was going to jump. Clearly if Senator Baume wants the call he can have it now.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—It seems that all senators in the chamber have agreed that it is appropriate for Senator Baume to speak at this point so I call Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A motion to censure a member of the Senate is one of the most serious that can come before the Senate. It should not be a political stunt or some kind of political get square, it must rest on principle. If that is the case, then Senator Gareth Evans's appalling, inept speech tonight certainly demonstrates that it does not rest on principle and that, in fact, it rests on next to nothing. Senator Evans's speech not only lacked substance but also lacked competence and integrity. I do not know what Senator Evans was really on about and I am certain that those who heard his speech would be astounded that this is a man who has pretensions to becoming a High Court judge.

PARA.TAB: I wish to deal shortly with the very serious matters that are nonetheless contained in the motion. Firstly, I want to demonstrate that this motion does not merit support not only because the punishment that Senator Evans wishes to impose on me does not fit the so-called crime, but also because of the disgraceful nature of the detail of the motion created by a putative High Court judge, Senator Evans, whose performance has been disgraceful. I think his speech tonight provides one of the most dramatic demonstrations of why he should not be allowed near that court let alone in it.

This motion was conceived in malice, born in deceit and swaddled in falsehood. Tonight Senator Evans gave an appalling speech that effectively abandoned his baby. This motion emerges from Senator Evans's humiliation last week when he had to correct his misleading understatements about the nature of the New South Wales Labor Party's huge debt. Senator Evans hates being wrong and he particularly hates being wrong when I have proved that he is wrong and I am right. I put it to the Senate that this motion is an offensive get square because Senator Evans made a fool of himself last week.

All this does not diminish in any way the need to put some matters right that were, quite frankly, wrong when I tabled this an accurate, totally correct and undisputedly true document relating to Dr Peter Macdonald who had understated his income for tax purposes. So putting Senator Evans's silly and self-serving motion to one side, I today wrote to Dr Macdonald in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Dr Macdonald,

I have noted your concern that your Tax File Number was inadvertently tabled by me along with documents revealing that your income was understated by $104,000. I would like you to know that immediately it was drawn to my attention that your TFN was on the document, I requested that it be excised and this was done.

The three journalists who received copies of the tabled documents assured me, on my request, that they would excise it from their copy. The only other recipients of the tabled document, according to the Senate Table Office, were two Labor Senators and I asked the Table Office to contact them in similar terms.
To my knowledge, no-one now has a copy of your Tax File Number as a result of my tabling the document, unless they received it from the two Labor Senators.

In the event that any copies of the tabled letter containing your TFN have been circulated, then I apologise that my action has inadvertently provided an opportunity for someone other than myself, and despite my best endeavours, to breach the confidence of your TFN.
If you feel that you now have a problem with your existing TFN, then I understand that this matter can be immediately resolved by your requesting a new TFN from the Tax Department.

I note that Senator Evans, having come in here and incompetently and defensively attacked me and my motives, is not here to hear my response. I must say that that does not surprise me. That is the sort of behaviour one would expect from Senator Evans and from the party he leads in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Seeking to damage a person by deliberately revealing their tax file number does merit censure. I accept and acknowledge that. Making a damaging and totally accurate statement about a person which inadvertently and peripherally involves revealing their tax file number followed by strenuous efforts to recover that situation is another matter altogether.

Ever since I entered this parliament 20 years ago, I have consistently and strongly supported the principle of privacy over other strong principles like states rights, for example, whenever there has been any conflict. Evidence of this was my vigorous and successful resistance to the Australia Card and my position on the recent Tasmanian issue. Once again that was successful. It is therefore very distressing to me that inadvertently Dr Peter Macdonald's tax file number was on the document I tabled in the Senate on Thursday night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you check it if it is so distressing?

—I accept that interjection because Senator Evans has already demolished that point. He said to this chamber that on this document the tax file number was not immediately evident. That was the excuse that Senator Evans gave for the duty minister Senator Crowley.
—You were the one tabling.
—This is a censure motion. I am being censured and yet this minister is continually interjecting. Am I not given the right in the Senate to respond without this kind of harassment?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Interjections are against the standing orders. I think it is appropriate for all senators in the chamber to understand the gravity of any motion that seeks to censure any other senator. I call upon the chamber to refrain from interjecting. I call Senator Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Your ruling that way is no more than I had expected and Senator Schacht's interruption of a debate of this seriousness is no more than I had expected. I am being charged with misbehaviour. The Labor Party is seeking to censure me for misbehaving. I restate the point I was making.

PARA.TAB: According to Senator Evans, he excused his duty minister for not having noticed that the tax file number was on the document, despite the fact that the duty minister closely studied that two-page document—which had very little typing on it—for at least five minutes before giving me approval to table it. If it was not immediately evident to her, I can assure you that it was equally not evident to me, and the reason is very simple: it does not say that it was his tax file number on the document.

The words `tax file number'—TFN—are meaningful to me. The fact that it says `file number' means that it was not necessarily meaningful to me, because on the document there were several references. There was our reference—a nine-digit figure. There was a file number—another nine-digit figure. I have to say that I was not someone who focused on the fact that one of those was the tax file number—the TFN. Senator Evans has conceded that he did not know, and it was not evident to the duty minister, that the file number was, in fact, the tax file number. I quote him exactly. Yet, Senator Evans has—

TALK.START.PARA: —She had a lot less opportunity to examine it than you did.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am being censured, and now Senator Evans, who has belatedly come into the chamber, is determined to interject. Do I have the protection of the chair from harassment when I am speaking on this censure motion?

—When Senator Baume asked this question a moment ago, I made it clear that all interjections are disorderly and that it is courteous, especially in a serious matter such as a censure motion, that we observe the standing orders.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Evans himself said that it was not evident that the `file number' was, in fact, the tax file number. I must say that I did not focus on that. I was so interested in the amount of tax avoidance revealed in the document that I concentrated my mind on that—just as the duty minister did. I am to be hanged according to Senator Evans because, like Senator Crowley, I did not focus on the fact that there was a number on this document which we now find out was a tax file number. The duty minister did not recognise this, and neither did I.

PARA.TAB: The big question is this: was it a criminal act? I have been accused of being involved in a criminal act—that is, revealing a tax file number. I have clearly indicated, and it is evident from all of my actions, that any revealing of a tax file number was inadvertent. I have apologised to Dr Macdonald in the terms that I have read to this chamber for that inadvertent inclusion of the tax file number in the document. However, that inadvertent activity does not, in my view, mean that I set out with the motive of damaging Dr Macdonald by revealing his tax file number. Yet that is what this motion purports to say.

It is distressing to me that Dr Peter Macdonald's tax file number was inadvertently on the document that I tabled in the Senate on Thursday night. I do not resile in any way from my publicising Dr Macdonald's $104,000 understatement of income for tax purposes—which I believe he had a duty to reveal to his electorate—after a tax office audit resulted in him paying $60,000 in back taxes in 1992.

Information on tax defaulters was made public annually in the taxation commissioner's report until 10 years ago when the Labor Party cut it out. I believe it should still be in the public domain, particularly when a member of parliament such as Dr Macdonald behaves with the utmost sanctimony, enforcing the resignation of one of the most decent, honourable men who have ever been the Premier of New South Wales—and I talk of Mr Nick Greiner.

I repeat: I regret that, in the brief amount of time I had to examine the document before tabling it, I did not focus on the fact that `file number' meant `tax file number'—nor, by the way, did Senator Crowley focus on this fact. I cannot imagine Senator Crowley giving me leave to table that document in the knowledge that the tax file number was there as she, like me, would not knowingly be party to releasing such information. Senator Evans condemns me for failing to draw to Senator Crowley's attention something of which I was not aware. I am guilty because I was not aware of it. As Senator Evans himself says, it is not evident that it is the tax file number. What humbug from Senator Evans. What a disgrace he is to this chamber.
Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, it is not parliamentary to call another senator a disgrace, and I ask you to withdraw that reference to Senator Evans.

—I withdraw. Contrary to Senator Evans's offensive and disgraceful suggestion, I had not realised the tax file number was included. I guess I have stated that clearly enough. The evidence of my concern about that is in the fact that, immediately it was drawn to my attention that `file number' meant `tax file number', I acted to correct the situation.

PARA.TAB: Shortly after the Senate rose at 8 p.m. last Thursday, I contacted the Table Office and requested a faxed copy of the tabled document, which I received at 8.06 p.m. Several minutes later when I was advised that the document contained the tax file number, I immediately asked the Table Office to excise it. After being advised that the clerk's approval was needed to do so, I immediately sought that approval by writing to the clerk on the nearest scrap of paper available to me in the committee room where I was attending an estimates hearing—so urgent did I regard the task.

Immediately after receiving the clerk's advice that the tax file number would be excised, I telephoned the three journalists who, to the combined knowledge of the Table Office and myself, had received the tabled document and I asked them to excise the tax file number. Each assured me that they did so. That did not stop one of them, I regret to say, referring to the tax file number being tabled in the parliament without bothering to mention what I had done subsequently to get that number excised. I guess journalistic ethics have changed since I was a journalist.

I did what I could to ensure that Dr Macdonald's tax file number was protected from becoming public knowledge as a result of my inadvertent tabling of it. However, the Table Office advised me, as I told Dr Macdonald, that two government senators—whose names it would not release to me—had also received copies. I asked that they be contacted to excise the tax file number. No other copies were released.

As I totally accept the assurances of the three journalists involved, it is only through these Labor senators that Dr Macdonald's tax file number could have been made public as a result of my inadvertent tabling of it. I am unaware that anyone else now knows Dr Macdonald's tax file number because of my action. However, I understand—as does Dr Macdonald from his published comments—that many copies of this correspondence have been circulated in Sydney in recent months. The only reason I tabled the document in raising the matter was to avoid the continual false, irresponsible and mendacious claim that, whenever I make allegations, they are unsubstantiated.

Whenever I make an allegation backed by an Australian Securities Commission document Senator Evans says it is unsubstantiated muckraking. When I provide land titles documents it is unsubstantiated muckraking. I have been right all the time. The only documents ever presented to this parliament on matters that I have raised here are those that demonstrate I am right. Dr Macdonald hid his understating of taxable income for three years after he became a state member of parliament before confessing to the Premier and asking that it not be used in the election campaign. Is the real objection the incidental and accidental revelation of Dr Macdonald's tax file number? If it is the tax file number, then I believe I have dealt with that matter. Why should a man who presents the facade of sanctimony and who played this, I believe, disgraceful role in the forced resignation of the Premier of New South Wales not be revealed for being someone who is prepared to hide from his constituents all the time he was a member of state parliament the fact that he had not only understated his tax but had also had to pay penal tax as a consequence. I remind the Senate of the personal attacks, the blackguarding of supporters of the Liberal Party—I hope some other speakers will have the time to deal with this later on—because they had taken the advice of their tax accountants during the 1980s. PARA.TAB: The thing is, if the offender is being turned into the victim by Senator Evans, for heaven's sake, I acted to the benefit of his constituents by informing them of what they had a right to know about the integrity of the man who was their elected representative and who traded on his integrity.
