SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should commence by reminding the Senate that we are sitting tonight—
—That is a terrible brief you have tonight.

—You wait and hear the argument. It will be better than your lame effort anyway. I thought I ought to start by reminding the Senate that we are sitting tonight as a result of a resolution of the government and the minority parties to deal with the government's legislative program. Apparently, the legislation was of such importance that the Senate needed to sit tonight. All of a sudden, the government produces a filler. Apparently, the legislation is no longer of the urgency that was suggested earlier in the week; rather the government has decided it is time to get on the attack in relation to Senator Baume.
—Some things just can't be ignored.

—We understand that Senator Baume gets under your skin. That is recognised by all. But whether that justifies the Senate spending all night on this frolic of yours is another question. This is your choice; this is your program; this is your priority. You have pushed aside the legislative program and said, `Let's have a go at punishing Senator Baume tonight. It doesn't matter how long it takes. Let's have a go at Senator Baume because he gets under our skin.'

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, have you ever heard such hypocrisy as that which you have heard tonight from Senator Evans and Senator Schacht? They are so sanctimonious. They have double standards beyond credibility. It is amazing that they would have the nerve, the gall, to come in here on the basis of the record of the Labor Party and attack Senator Baume in this way.

As I said, it is known by all that Senator Baume gets under the skin of members of the Labor Party, and tonight is punishment night. They say, `Tonight we're going to punish Senator Baume for getting under our skin, for irritating us for so long.' I remind you of a couple of those issues. Labor Party members were particularly upset that Senator Baume led the public debate on the question of Mr Keating's pig farm, his pig farming interest. They said, `The gall of this senator to raise questions about potential conflicts of interest in respect of the Prime Minister of Australia going out and buying into multi-million dollar piggeries!' He raised quarantine issues and overseas investment issues—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Bank lending money.

—He raised the issue of what we understand to be very substantial borrowings from the Commonwealth Bank. Members of the Labor Party attacked Senator Baume. They said, `You have got no right to raise these matters in relation to our dear Prime Minister. How dare you! We will pay you back for it one day.'

PARA.TAB: Even last week, Senator Baume again caused the Labor Party embarrassment by raising the issue of its very substantial debts in New South Wales. He embarrassed the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, in particular. Senator Evans said the debt was only $6 million, and the debt turned out to be $10 million. Senator Evans said, `We're repaying it at $10,000 a month.' In actual fact, the Labor Party was not repaying the debt at all. It was only making payments off interest. It was not $10,000 a month—it was $10,000 a week. Members of the Labor Party think, `For Senator Baume to suggest that there might have been cash payments of that money is disgraceful. Who does this Senator Baume think he is?' So tonight is punishment night. Tonight is the night where those opposite attempt to get it back on Senator Baume.

This is the government that comes in tonight and says, `We are all about privacy.' This was the government of the Australia Card. It has no concern about the privacy of individual Australians at all, yet those opposite come in tonight and say, `Senator Baume has invaded the privacy of this New South Wales parliamentarian by demonstrating that he substantially understated his taxable income' not for one year, not for two years, not for three years, not for four years—for five years. They say, `What a terrible invasion of privacy. We've got to censure Senator Baume for that incredible invasion of privacy.'

How many other occasions have we seen the government's disregard of privacy in this place? Any senator will remember the day that Senator Walsh, a former finance minister, put a personal cheque of a senator on the table. It turned out to be false. Nevertheless, those opposite had no compunction about that. They had no concern about the privacy of that individual. The cheque went down on the table. It was a window of opportunity to attack someone on our side. What double standards! It is no wonder the Australian people are getting so sick of this government. They are so sick of its double standards. This is the government of deceit. This is the Prime Minister of deceit. This was the Prime Minister that went out at the last election and told the Australian people, `There will not be tax increases under us. It's not just a promise. It's already in the law: l-a-w, law.' Of course, as soon as we got back here, the promise was broken; the law was broken. He demonstrated that he had no intention at all of keeping that promise to the Australian people, including the pensioners and the students.

This was perhaps the greatest electoral deceit that we have had in the history of the parliamentary process in this country. It is on that basis of deceit—that it is a government that has no compunction to lie to the Australian people—that those opposite come in here today holier than thou to condemn Senator Baume in terms of the charge that they have put on the table.

This is the Prime Minister of deceit. He has done secret deals, such as the Kirribilli deal. The Prime Minister did a secret deal with the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to determine the succession to the Lodge. They also determined that they would keep it secret from the Australian people. Then they lied to the Australian people about their intentions.

That is the bona fides of the people that lay this charge on the table tonight—no credibility whatsoever. Did Mr Keating the other day have any concern about slurring Mr Howard when he went out there and accused Mr Howard, just because it was politically convenient and necessary at the time, of a secret deal? Where was the evidence of that secret deal when he was put under pressure? The evidence did not exist, because the deal did not exist. But that did not stop Mr Keating from slurring the character of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, arguing that he was not fit to be Leader of the Opposition, let alone Prime Minister. That did not worry Mr Keating at the time. Nothing like a bit of character assassination when it advances you a notch or two in politics—that is the basis from which these people come to the chamber tonight. That is their credibility. That is what they bring to the chamber in terms of credibility for this debate.

Apart from that, of course, what they want more than anything else at the moment is another distraction. Why do they not want to debate the program? Why do they not want to debate the big issues that are facing the country at the moment, including the 800,000 Australians that are out of work?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Canberra voters do.

—Canberra voters do. When it is put to the test, the Australian people are sending a message to this government. But is it listening? Is the Prime Minister listening? Is this lot in the Senate responding positively to what the people are telling them? Of course they are not. They are just coming in here tonight to attack Senator Baume—to fill in the night, to try to take the focus off them because of their record. That is understandable.

PARA.TAB: Twenty-seven per cent of young Australians are still out of work in this country and all this government wants to do is to pat itself on the back in relation to its employment achievements. Do government members want to debate the issues of the ever rising interest rates and whether young families can afford to pay those interest rates? Do they want to debate the big issue of the current account deficit—again at a record high of nearly six per cent of GDP, the level that Mr Keating some years ago referred to as a banana republic level? Do they want to debate these major issues of substance, such as the net overseas debt of this country which is now $160 billion mortgaged for generations into the future? Of course, they do not want to debate these big issues such as their mismanagement of the economy, the way they deceived university students in relation to fees, the debacle with health care—and Aboriginal health care, which is practically at the worst level it has ever been. They do not want to debate these big issues. They want a distraction from these big issues. Unfortunately, the one they have chosen tonight as the subject of their distraction is Senator Baume.

Do not believe for a moment that they come to this debate with clean hands. Do not believe that they come with any genuine concern about any action that Senator Baume may or may not have taken in this chamber. They have no interest in that at all. It is all just part of a political game, and unfortunately the processes of the Senate are being abused in that way tonight. Let us come, on the basis of that background, to the charges made by the Leader of the Opposition in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government.

—Well, the soon to be Leader of the Opposition. That was a Freudian slip; I am sorry. Somebody raised Freud a while ago. Are you going to the High Court, or what is going to happen? You will then be the former Leader of the Government in this place. Judging by the drafting of this motion today it is hard to see how Senator Evans got past the magistrates court. He is the only one who applied for his own silk. Anyway, he tells me I am wrong; he was in the industrial court for a while. But that is an aside.

PARA.TAB: Let us come to the charge that he makes in this place. The first basis of his claimed censure is that Senator Baume disclosed Dr Macdonald's tax file number, which would have been a crime if done outside the parliament. If Senator Baume had deliberately publicly disclosed the tax file number, then Senator Baume would be the first one who would say he should be censured. But if you look at the evidence objectively, as I trust the minority parties will tonight, there is no suggestion that that tax file number was deliberately disclosed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about recklessness?

—It is now recklessness, is it? Is it not negligence? It is not deliberate. And it is now recklessness. Is that your charge? The problem was that, when Senator Evans drafted this motion, he did not seem to bother about checking whether Senator Baume had raced out afterwards to the Table Office and ensured that the tax file number was removed so that it would not be disclosed. You did not take the effort to find out whether that happened.
—I did not need to.

—Didn't need to! Didn't care. Didn't bother. He just presumed that they had Senator Baume on the hook without following up the details of the case. He might have done all right in the magistrates court—
—He didn't.
—He didn't? Well, it is certainly a good thing he wasn't the investigating officer! What Senator Evans must now accept—
—And he would have made a hopeless judge as well.
—Gareth? Him?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the Hansard. I was referring to Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order, Senator Forshaw! I do not know what the listeners are making of this debate. I assume that the opposition would like Senator Hill to continue. Could I ask that this debate be continued in a manner that is appropriate to the decorum of this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take the interjection because apparently it was the Prime Minister that vetoed Senator Evans's High Court application. We all know that it was on the cabinet table and all of a sudden it disappeared. Who runs this government? Mr Keating. Anyway, Gareth, I guess a favour wasn't owed or something.

PARA.TAB: Getting back to this charge that you make against Senator Baume, it was clearly based on your allegation that he deliberately put that tax file number onto the public record, into the public arena. Once anyone objectively looks at the facts, you know that that is not the case. You can tell from his record immediately after the event that there was no intention to deliberately do that at all, because what he did was to take every step he could to ensure that it did not get into the public arena. And for that he should be commended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another honourable man, like McLachlan!
—At least he is not taking the Miles Kupa defence.

—Standing behind his staff? Mr McLachlan actually showed a lot of honour. Bear in mind that he resigned for an inadvertent misleading of the parliament. Mr Keating deliberately misleads the Australian people, and we are all supposed to swallow that as just a legitimate part of the political process. What double standards! I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that Senator Baume, immediately after this document was tabled unfortunately with the tax file number, which was on the second page—and it is not all that easy to pick up, as Senator Crowley found—
—Senator Hill, I would prefer to see your face rather than your back, if you would not mind.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I beg your pardon. The point I was making is that Senator Baume missed it, Senator Crowley, the government minister, missed it—
—How long did Senator Crowley have it?
—What that demonstrates is that it is possible to read through those documents and miss the tax file number.
—If you deliberately choose to put it on the public record you have a responsibility.

—That must prove it. Unless you are saying that Senator Crowley saw the tax file number and had no objection to its being put on the public record, the only argument can be that she missed it also. So it was possible to miss it.

PARA.TAB: If you are saying to me that Senator Baume was negligent and that he should have seen it, Senator Baume may be prepared to accept that charge. If you say that Senator Crowley was negligent also because she should have seen it and she, on behalf of the government, should not have consented to its being put into the public record with the number being present, that charge would lie as well. It is possible, and it demonstrates to all of us that care should be taken. Perhaps in the case of Senator Baume not sufficient care was taken on this side—certainly, sufficient care was not taken on the other side—but there is no evidence at all that Senator Baume deliberately intended that that be put on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite the contrary.

—Quite the contrary. All the evidence before the Senate tonight is that Senator Baume took every step to ensure that it was not put on the public record. He went to the Table Office and said that this had come to his attention, it had to be removed and it must not go onto the public record. The Table Office said that he had to get the clerk's written authority. He went to the clerk, and he then went back to the Table Office and asked whether anyone had a copy of it. He was told that three journalists had copies. He went to those journalists and said, `This must not go onto the public record. It is improper that this goes onto the public record.' Senator Baume did everything to ensure that it did not go onto the public record.
—But who were the two Labor people who had it?

—Apparently there were Labor senators who took a copy of it. I cannot answer for them. I am not sure that it has gone into the public arena anyway. Is there an allegation that the tax file number is before the public?
—Of course it has been in the public arena once it is before this place.
—Is it before the public? No, it is not. It has been excised. It was blacked out.
—Once it is tabled it is in the public record.
—Who has seen it? Have you got any evidence of anyone seeing it? Who has seen it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! Senator Hill would like to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know who has seen it. Do you?
—I do not know. Neither do you.
—Minister and Senator Baume, I ask you to allow Senator Hill to continue.

—The government cannot find Senator Baume guilty on this account. It just cannot do it. If Senator Evans had argued in his censure motion that Senator Baume was negligent, he might have had a case. But he did not argue that. Did he argue that Senator Baume was reckless? That is how he wants to now amend his statement of claim. No, he did not argue that at all.
—Did I use the word `deliberately' there?
—We listened to your speech.
—I just said he tabled it. It could have been deliberate; it could have been reckless.

—Now he is hysterical as well. He came into the chamber today and argued that Senator Baume had deliberately put this on the public record. Firstly, it is not on the public record and, secondly, all the evidence demonstrates that Senator Baume did not deliberately put it on the public record. Quite the contrary: he made every attempt to ensure that it was not put on the public record.

PARA.TAB: I move to the second charge that the government makes. The second one is really quite exotic. What Senator Evans says is that for reasons of political advantage—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, could I see your face, please?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is there a standing order that requires you to direct a speaker to actually face you? As I understand it, the standing orders only require that comments be addressed through the chair—not that the speaker has to actually look at you.
—I was indicating that in a manner that I thought would convey the nature of that standing order. If my ruling is not appropriate, I am sure Senator Hill understands.

—The second charge is really quite extraordinary. This is important. I would like to be putting this argument to Senator Harradine and to Senator Chamarette because basically they will be asked to pass judgment. If Senator Evans and Senator Faulkner would stop harassing them so that I can put this argument to them, I would appreciate it. This is important. What Senator Evans is arguing is that we have to weigh the public interest of privacy against a more narrow interest of political advantage. He says that we should weigh this against Senator Baume and he should therefore be censured. That is extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: What the minister has said is that Senator Baume, for political advantage, put onto the public record matters that certainly are, I think according to all definitions, relevant for voters—they go to credit—in determining whether or not they wish to support a particular candidate. Anyone can pass judgment as to whether that is justified or not; that is individual opinion. Senator Baume put that document on the public record, and Senator Evans says it is outweighed by what he describes as a larger public interest of privacy and therefore Senator Baume should be censured.

What is the definition of this `larger public interest of privacy'. It seems to me that it is basically when you find that the material that has been put on the table is to your political disadvantage, when you find that that material is embarrassing and it relates to certain affairs—in this instance, the business affairs and the taxation affairs of a member of parliament who was standing for re-election—you come into this chamber and argue that there is an overriding principle of privacy that is paramount, therefore that should not be put on the public record and furthermore you should censure the person who put it on the public record.

To me, that is an extraordinary argument and would create a very dangerous precedent. Just think of how many instances there are across the whole political spectrum where one comes in here and criticises an opponent. You can argue that they are all issues of public interest, but apparently, from now on, they have to be weighed up as to whether they intrude upon a person's wider private interest, a person's privacy, to the extent that the senator should be censured. On the facts, that has not been made out in this case, but the precedent that the minister is seeking to establish would be highly undesirable, I would suggest, to this place.

Remember again that Senator Crowley—I hesitate to bring Senator Crowley into this again—consented to this material being put down by Senator Baume. Senator Crowley, on behalf of the government, said the government had no objection to this being tendered in the Senate. If government senators had no objection to its being tendered in the Senate, how can they then come in and censure Senator Baume for tendering the material? It is not as if this material was not first put before the government. This material was put before the duty minister, and the duty minister said, `We have no objection.' If the government had no objection to the document being put on the table of the Senate, how can it then censure Senator Baume for putting it on the table? What is the basis for that case? How does the minister make out that case to the Senate? What an appalling precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not listening. He couldn't care less.
—He could not care less because this has nothing to do with merit. This has all to do with punishing Senator Baume and also providing a distraction from this government.

PARA.TAB: In the last few minutes I have left to speak I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the government not only seeks to censure Senator Baume—quite improperly, I would suggest—but also argues that the Senate should agree tonight to refer certain matters to the Standing Committee of Privileges. I ask senators: have they read the detail of what Senator Evans is putting before them? Firstly, he says that the Senate Privileges Committee should look at this matter to determine whether it constitutes a contempt of the Senate on the grounds that:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Senator Baume incompletely informed the Senate as to the nature of the documents . . .
What is all that about? Where does that come from? How has Senator Baume `incompletely informed the Senate as to the nature of the documents'? Where was that invented? The censure motion continues:
. . . in particular, did not inform the Senate that it contained the tax file number . . .
Senator Baume did not realise it contained a tax file number. As soon as he did, he went outside to have it removed so that it could not cause any embarrassment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither did the government.

—Neither did the government. If that is what Senator Evans means by `incompletely informed the Senate', which is an extraordinary use of language, then Senator Crowley, on behalf of the government, is guilty of exactly the same offence. Secondly, I do not know if honourable senators, particularly those of the minority parties, have tried to read paragraph (B), but it almost defies interpretation. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume caused an injustice to a citizen to arise in the course of proceedings in the Senate without the Senate being aware of that consequence—
What consequence?
. . . and thereby impeded the Senate in the free exercise of its functions. . .

What does that mean? That is a load of nonsense. It does not make any sense at all. The new law clerk has come into the chamber. Senator Loosley might be able to help us with some of these questions of interpretation. Thirdly, Senator Evans, being a clever man, says, `I will add a catch-all, a final clause that catches everything.' So he states:
(C)any other ground consistent with section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987,
He presumes that no-one will read section 4. That talks about action that is:
. . . intended or likely to amount, to an improper interference with the free exercise by a House or committee of its authority or functions,
What does that have to do with this matter? It goes on:
. . . or with the free performance by a member of the member's duties as a member.

It has absolutely nothing to do with this matter whatsoever. I can only assume that Senator Evans did not read section 4 either. This might call for the Miles Cooper defence—blame the staffer—because no lawyer worth his salt would want to stand up here and say that he drafted these pleadings.

PARA.TAB: The important thing is that the case has not been made out in any way, shape or form. It is just a diversion tonight. It has nothing to do with true justice, and anyone who objectively looks at these findings will say that certainly Senator Baume does not deserve censure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. In the course of an exchange of interjections earlier on, I was accused by Senator Baume of profound, complete, total ignorance of the relevant tax law and the tax rates that were applicable because Senator Baume said it was not possible for an amount of $60,000, thereabouts, to be payable in back tax without a penalty element in the context of a tax liability of something of the order of $100,000. That was the context of the exchange. Senator Baume nods. I have taken the opportunity in the intervening period to check the circumstances of Dr Macdonald's tax returns in this matter and I am advised that the tax office said there was no culpability and therefore there was no penalty. Additional interest was paid.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. If this is intended to be a personal explanation, let Senator Evans first indicate where he says he has been wronged. What he is doing at the moment is simply making a further contribution to the debate to refute a point which he says he picked up across the chamber. How that can possibly constitute a defamation of Senator Evans that requires a personal explanation is simply beyond the Senate.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I was accused across the chamber of ignorance of the applicable tax law by saying that there was no penalty component, as I understood it, in terms of this particular tax liability. What I was saying in order to correct the record is that there was no penalty payable. It was just interest that was payable. The tax that was payable was of the order of $40,000 to $45,000. The interest component brought it up to $60,000. There was no penalty, as such, imposed.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: it is not your role to determine whether Senator Evans is ignorant or not. It might be well known out in the community that he is enormously ignorant. He may not think he is—he may have a jumped up sense of his own importance—but it is not your role to determine whether he is ignorant or not. He is imputing that the allegation was made that he was ignorant, so it is not your role to rule one way or the other.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Senator Herron, I believe I gave certain leeway earlier in the debate to Senator Baume when I suggested that perhaps claims of being misrepresented could be taken into account during the debate. I gave Senator Evans a similar ruling and I think we should now continue the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —During his pathetic attempt to justify his actions of last Thursday night, Senator Baume claimed that the motion before the Senate this evening was a political get square. Senator Baume, in his pathetic defence, talked about integrity. Senator Baume said that this was an offensive motion to him and he referred to Dr Macdonald as sanctimonious. The political get square in this issue was Senator Baume's disgraceful attempt last Thursday night to malign the character of Dr Macdonald. The person who lacks integrity in this issue is not Dr Macdonald; it is Senator Baume. The person who is sanctimonious when it comes to this debate is Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Baume launched his outrageous attack on Dr Peter Macdonald, the member for Manly, last Thursday night in the adjournment debate—I was present for that debate—Senator Baume tried to justify that attack on two grounds. The first ground was that the references in an earlier debate that day to the tax affairs of Phillip Smiles, a former state Liberal MP, were `cheap shots'. He felt that, as a result of Phillip Smiles's tax affairs being raised in this chamber, he had to get on board and make some allegations about Dr Macdonald.

The second ground Senator Baume endeavoured to use to defend his revealing of this tax information regarding Dr Macdonald and the tax file number was that the supporters of Dr Macdonald were going to `drop a bucket' on Mr Oldfield, the Liberal candidate for Manly. Senator Baume decided, and stated quite clearly, that he had to get in first because of what he claimed had been planned by Dr Macdonald and his supporters.

The first point to make about the first ground upon which Senator Baume tried to justify his attack is that there is absolutely no similarity between the raising of the issue of Phillip Smiles's tax cheating, for which he was convicted, and the abuse of parliamentary privilege by Senator Baume last Thursday during the adjournment debate when he referred to Dr Macdonald's tax affairs.

The remarks that I made in the debate earlier that day in the matter of public importance regarding Phillip Smiles have long been a matter of public record. Indeed, the details of Mr Smiles's tax evasion, for which he was convicted and for which he resigned from parliament, had been referred to very early on in the New South Wales state election campaign. They were a matter of public record; indeed, they were a part of the advertising campaign and the debate going on in respect of the New South Wales state election. That is a totally different situation from the position of Dr Macdonald, which Senator Baume raised at the 11th hour in the hope that he could `drop a bucket' on Dr Macdonald, to use his own words.

Senator Baume's first ground for raising this matter last Thursday night was totally spurious. The allegations that Senator Baume made about Dr Macdonald up until Thursday night were not a matter of public record. They were not known to the public at large or, I would suggest, to just about every individual citizen in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should have been.
—Here's another crook.
—You are defending this, are you, Senator Alston? Yes, I thought so.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I found Senator Murphy's comments to be unparliamentary. I ask that you tell him to withdraw it. If he does not know what he said, you ask him.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—I have to say that I did not hear what he said. I would ask all senators and the senator who is speaking to refrain from making unparliamentary statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—The taxation affairs in this matter, with respect to Dr Macdonald, were not known to the public at large, unlike the position with Phillip Smiles. Those matters were a matter of confidence, protected by law, between the Taxation Office and Dr Macdonald. Further, they were a matter of confidence between Dr Macdonald and Premier Fahey. That is because Dr Macdonald, of his own volition, drew these matters to the attention of the New South Wales Premier. As I understand it, it was firstly to Mr Greiner when he was Premier and, certainly, to Mr Fahey later on.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the situation of Dr Macdonald, and to get the allegations made by Senator Baume into the proper context, it is important to point out that not one single member of the New South Wales state parliament on any side—whether it be the opposition, the Liberal-National Party government or any independent of the state parliament—had ever raised these issues about Dr Macdonald. The premier, John Fahey who was aware of the situation, at no stage ever raised them, nor did he allege that Dr Macdonald was not a fit person to be a member of state parliament. In fact, not only did John Fahey not raise them, but he specifically stated to Dr Macdonald that he would not raise them in a political context.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he didn't.

—That is right; he did not. That is the point that has to be understood: no single member of the state parliament ever raised these issues at any time, and certainly not during the election campaign. Who raises them? Who puts them on the public record at the 11th hour in an endeavour to destroy the reputation of a member of the state parliament? Senator Baume does. It is a pity Senator Baume did not take some notice of the actions taken by his fellow party members in New South Wales and all the other state members. You would think that, if this were the important issue that needed to be raised and if this were something that the public needed to know about, they would have raised it, certainly in the context of an election. But, no; they did not.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume crawls into this chamber at the adjournment debate; he is the last speaker of the night; and he raises the issue less than 48 hours out from a state election polling day to, using his own words, `tip a bucket'. He stands singularly condemned for doing that. No other colleague of his, either in this chamber or in the state parliament, where this issue of the integrity of Dr Macdonald as a member of that parliament really mattered, ever raised the issue.

No charges have ever been laid against Dr Macdonald, unlike Phillip Smiles. No conviction has ever been recorded against Dr Macdonald, unlike Phillip Smiles. Senator Baume tried to put this situation into the same category as Phillip Smiles, as he stated at the outset of his speech in the adjournment debate. No-one can be in any doubt that, when he made his speech last Thursday night and raised these allegations, Senator Baume was implying that Dr Macdonald was the equivalent to a convicted tax cheat. That is what he was endeavouring to imply, and that is what Hansard shows.

As he said in his opening remarks, he puts Dr Macdonald into the same context as the position of Phillip Smiles. There has been a lot of discussion here this evening, a lot of interjections and comments thrown across the chamber, regarding the law, people's legal qualifications and suitability for legal office. What Senator Baume did—as I stated in my interjection, and will state now for the record so that Hansard correctly reports it—was set himself up as the prosecutor, the jury and the judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a good line. Where did you hear that before?

—Those of you on the opposite side, like Senator Abetz, who claim some expertise in the law know that if you want to be a prosecutor and if you want to be a judge you have to get your facts straight. You have to make sure when you put your case that you put it correctly and accurately

SPEECH.PARA: and not put false and misleading information to those people who will stand in judgment. What Senator Baume endeavoured to do was to `drop a bucket' on Dr Macdonald to give the impression to the voters of Manly that their local member, in a very tight marginal seat, was the equivalent of a tax cheat, that he had no integrity, and that he should not be re-elected on Saturday. That was what Senator Baume was endeavouring to do. He knows it, and every single member of this parliament knows it.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, Dr Macdonald was at least able to endeavour to point that out the following day. But, as they say, if you throw enough mud some of it sticks. That is what Senator Baume was intending to do—to throw a huge bucket of mud. It is okay if he gets a few facts wrong and if he unfortunately released the tax file number; he will try to apologise and set it right later. That is what he is implying.

As the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, has already indicated, if Senator Baume released that document in public outside this parliament, he would have committed an offence punishable by two years imprisonment, a fine of up to $10,000 or both. During his speech last Thursday night, Senator Baume, when referring to this alleged bucket job that Dr Macdonald's supporters were going to drop on the Liberal candidate, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: If the purpose of the bucket job is to demonstrate that Dr Macdonald is a man of greater integrity than his opponents, then it simply will not work. The reason is that Dr Macdonald's own taxation record shows a lack of integrity that must be of major concern to his constituents in Manly.

They are the words of Senator Baume. The allegations that the supporters of Dr Macdonald would be dropping a bucket on Mr Oldfield the next day were completely without foundation. It was the classic straw man argument. No evidence was presented to the Senate last Thursday night by Senator Baume to suggest that any such campaign was to be undertaken by Dr Macdonald's supporters. He provided absolutely no evidence for that allegation. He just stated that, because he said it was a fact, it must be accepted as a fact.

PARA.TAB: No bucket campaign was undertaken by Dr Macdonald's supporters on the Friday or the Saturday. The real bucket job was Senator Baume's, when he tabled the letter from the Taxation Office to Dr Macdonald, which included Dr Macdonald's tax file number. So it is clear that the person who dropped the bucket was Senator Baume. The problem for Senator Baume is that a bigger bucket is being dropped on his head. The person who lacks integrity is not Dr Macdonald; it is Senator Baume.

Since then, Senator Baume has been trying to worm his way out of his predicament by a series of lame excuses. First of all, he claims that he did not discuss the matter with Premier Fahey and that, if he did, he certainly would not have done it. He also claims that he was not aware the tax file number was on the correspondence before he tabled it. That is a truly pathetic excuse. As I said, it was Senator Baume's duty, in raising this most sensitive issue—an invasion of someone's privacy by the revealing of their tax information—in a serious situation to ensure that he got all the facts straight and that he knew what he was doing. To now come in and say that he did not know the tax file number was on the correspondence is a truly pathetic excuse. It is nothing more than an attempt to avoid responsibility.
Senator Baume tells us that he has written a letter of apology.

TALK.START.PARA: —To whom?

—He said that he has written it to Dr Macdonald. But Senator Baume has shown no remorse for his actions. We have heard some pious words this evening. But what did Senator Baume say to journalists last Friday when he was interviewed about this matter? He said, `Well, I hope this doesn't backfire on the Liberals in Manly.' He realised the blunder that he made. There was no remorse. His response was, `I hope this doesn't backfire on my Liberal colleagues in Manly.'

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, Senator Baume made a personal explanation to the Senate. He claimed that he had taken steps immediately after the Senate rose to have the tax file number removed from copies of the document held by the Senate Table Office. In a classic case of passing the buck, Senator Baume even tried to impugn government senators by suggesting that they may have distributed and published Dr Macdonald's tax file number. In his personal explanation yesterday, Senator Baume said:

SPEECH.PARA: If this tax file number has been distributed and published to anyone, it has been distributed and published by members of this government.
What a disgraceful inference for Senator Baume to make. It is a most offensive suggestion.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume is now endeavouring to defend his actions by making outrageous allegations and snide inferences against other members of this chamber with absolutely no evidence. He is just making allegations. He said, `If it has been distributed, it must have come from two government senators.' There is no evidence of that.

For the information of Senator Baume and the Senate, particularly for Senator Knowles, who kept interjecting earlier as to who the two government senators were, I inform the Senate that I was one of the two senators who obtained a copy from the Table Office after the adjournment debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what have you done with it? What effort did you take to—
—Is Senator O'Chee alleging that I have done anything with that document? If he is, he should be prepared to state it now.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. There is a provision in the standing orders that prohibits a senator being intimidated. For Senator O'Chee to merely ask what he did with it in no shape or form deserves that sort of hysterical outburst and the suggestion that he was making any imputation against Senator Forshaw.
—What a stupid point of order!

—It is not stupid. It is a very proper point of order. Senator Forshaw obviously overreacted. Madam Acting Deputy President, you ought to tell him that he cannot behave in that way. We are entitled to ask questions.
—On the point of order: throughout an earlier speech, Senator Knowles kept yelling out, `Who were the two government senators?'.
—And you are one of them.
—I freely acknowledge that. But the position is—
—What have you done with the TFN?
—If Senator Knowles shuts up, I will tell her what I have done with it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! That is disorderly. In fact, this entire debate is rather disorderly. Could everyone just settle down. There have been no points of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done with the TFN, mega mouth?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. In the terms of the debate that the government is running, the senator has admitted he has a document. Did he check whether the document had a tax file number on it?
—That is not a point of order. If the debate continues, a number of these issues may be elucidated.
—What have you done with it? Tell us that.
—Senator Knowles, listen!

—As I indicated, I was one of two senators who obtained a copy. I do not know who the other senator is; that is the first point. After the adjournment debate—I was here for that debate, and Senator Baume knows it—I took steps to obtain a copy of the document. I did not see it until after the adjournment debate. I was not aware of what was in it. I was not aware that there was a tax file number on it until I obtained a copy from the Table Office.

PARA.TAB: I assure the Senate that I obtained that copy. I have not photocopied it or handed it to anyone. I have not in any way made the contents of that document known to any other person, such as a journalist, or anyone outside this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you destroyed it?
—I invite any opposition senator to, rather than make these insidious allegations against the floor by interjection—
—Where is it?
—I have the copy in my possession. I have advised—
—Why didn't you give it to your leader, Senator Evans?
—Order! Senator Knowles, will you let Senator Forshaw continue.

—I have advised Senator Evans that I have that copy and I believe that there is absolutely nothing wrong with me obtaining a copy of a document that was tabled in the Senate last Thursday night. Once I realised the nature of that document I ensured that at no stage was it ever given to any other person or the contents made known to any journalist. I refute the inferences made by Senator Baume and other senators on the other side that I have engaged in those activities. This is the sort of spurious nonsense you get from the other side of the chamber. Because Senator Baume is in trouble for releasing a document by tabling it in the Senate he tries to transfer the blame onto other senators, including Minister Crowley.

PARA.TAB: On previous occasions in this chamber there has been a great deal of debate about privacy. Senators on both sides have spoken about the critical need to protect people's privacy. Senator Baume has on a number of occasions spoken most piously about the need to protect privacy. On 21 December 1989, in the debate on the Privacy Amendment Bill, Senator Baume said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let us recognise that it was the Opposition which, in a very clear and determined way, established a real concern for privacy in this place at the time of the tax file number debate . . . There is no doubt that in the Opposition ranks there is clear concern about the need for privacy and for appropriate legislation to protect people.

Those noble words were spoken by Senator Baume. In that speech I have just quoted Senator Baume referred to the previous debate on the tax file legislation. That debate took place in 1988. Senator Baume said on 9 November 1988:

The upgraded tax file number will now be required only in the relationship between the Australian Taxation Office and the taxpayer. Just as we now have a tax file number, this new system will represent an improvement on that tax file number but the only people who will have a requirement to use that number will be those in the Taxation Office and the taxpayer; just as it is now.
Further on in his speech on the tax file number legislation Senator Baume stated:

Under the massive changes we have proposed to this legislation revenue will be collected, but it will be collected in an honest and honourable way, not by using a device with the hidden agenda of compiling secret banks of information against the wishes of individual taxpayers.
Senator Baume further stated:
We made certain that it did not unreasonably intrude upon personal privacy and civil liberties by our massive privacy legislation amendments.
Senator Baume concluded his remarks on that occasion by stating:
. . . the Australian population will be grateful to us not only for protecting their privacy but also for ensuring that this legislation will collect revenue from tax cheats without being intrusive.

It is clear now that Senator Baume's words on that occasion were mere rhetoric and amount to hypocrisy. It is clear that when it comes to issues of protecting privacy Senator Baume does not practice what he preaches so often. Last Thursday night Senate Baume said:

If the game is going to be played like this, so that at the last minute buckets are going to be dropped, then I think people who drop buckets—I acknowledge this for myself too—have to face the risk of having buckets dropped on them.

On this comment, Senator Baume should be taken at his word. The bucket has well and truly dropped on him. By any standard the Senate should take the strongest possible action to oppose such blatant abuses of parliamentary privilege as we saw last Thursday. We often hear claims that one comment or another which senators may make reflects badly upon the chamber. Make no mistake, when parliamentary privilege is so abused, when there is such blatant and indefensible disregard for the privacy of an individual for reasons of political advantage, when acts which would otherwise constitute crimes are performed under the protection of parliamentary privilege then the Senate must respond, we must firmly reject those actions and we must censure those responsible.

PARA.TAB: Debates in this chamber do not occur in isolation. They have a real effect on those throughout the community. Whilst we do not know what damage may have been done to Dr Macdonald through these callous actions, what we do know is that such abuses must not be tolerated. The pathetic defence of Senator Baume that has been advanced tonight should not be tolerated either. No fair minded person can excuse this conduct. Senator Baume should be censured. I urge honourable senators to support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can tell when a government is in terminal decline. It is when it attacks everyone and everything that moves and no longer attempts to defend its own record. You do not have to go far to discover a classic example of that today. You were there in caucus when he was told that his abrasive and offensive style was alienating middle Australia. What did he say? He said it was the fault of the opposition, it was the fault of the media and it was the fault of Steve Martin. Not the comedian.
—Steve who?
—The Speaker. What sort of manic self-delusion is that that you have to attack the messenger.
—When are you going to defend Senator Baume?

—I can understand why you have bailed out. Understandably you can no longer hack the pressure, but certainly you will go out as a precious hack. The New South Wales Right has turned rorting the system into an art form. Keating could not even get here in a straight way, he had to rig the preselection ballot. It is appalling. When were you criticising the tax office when details of the returns of Metherell and Smiles were leaked? You were not complaining about that. Why have you not criticised Peter Macdonald for making a disgraceful and defamatory allegation that Fahey put Baume up to it? There is not a skerrick of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the evidence? If it was not so serious it would be funny. I am glad we have got a real live law student in the chamber. We have a vested interest in this bloke. Us taxpayers have been funding this law degree. Nonetheless, we are entitled to a return on our investment. I hope that Senator Loosley has at least got to the stage of studying criminal law. If he has, he will understand concepts like mens rea. You need to have a guilty intent before you can be guilty of a criminal offence.
—Absolutely right.
—Senator Loosley says, `Absolutely right.' What is this all about?
—What was Greiner doing in Manly a few days before? What were the polls telling you about Manly?

—Do not worry about the polls, let us worry about the law and civil liberties. You are very keen on wringing your hands in mock horror about civil liberties, people's rights, justice, social justice and all those very important aspects of life that are so dear to you when it suits you. What we have got here is a very serious allegation. I would not have thought even you would purport to deny that. The motion states right from the outset that the Senate notes:

SPEECH.PARA: that the Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes it an offence punishable by 2 years imprisonment . . . for the unauthorised disclosure of a person's tax file number—

I do not have any doubt who drafted this motion—it was Senator Evans. But he obviously did it very unwillingly. He did it with bad grace. You could see his lack of heart and commitment by the fact that he sat down early. It is very serious that someone like Senator Evans, who has fancied himself as a civil libertarian—and, indeed, Senator Loosley, who at times likes to pretend that he is one as well—could go so far as to suggest that there has been any skerrick of evidence in support of a criminal offence. Let us take what Senator Forshaw had to say. He said, `Get your facts right.' What are the facts here? The facts are that Senator Baume came into this chamber and released certain information contained in a taxation assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the tax file number.
—That document happened to have on it the words `file number'.
—It was on there.

—Just a moment. Senator Evans said that the fact that it was a tax file number was not immediately evident. Presumably, he did that in defence of Senator Crowley and to explain why even someone with Senator Crowley's limited intelligence needs more than five minutes to read two pages. What he was doing was saying that you should not blame Senator Crowley for the fact that she could not detect that this was a tax file number. Senator Baume has made that clear as well. He had this document for a couple of hours. It had written on it `file number'. That in itself does not indicate any awareness that it was a tax file number. Indeed, all of Senator Baume's subsequent actions were to the contrary.

PARA.TAB: You judge a person in criminal law not only by what he says but also by what he does. That is how you ought to judge politicians, too. As soon as the matter was drawn to his attention, Senator Baume immediately sought to retrieve the document and black out the tax file number. I have not heard Senator Forshaw say that he blacked out any tax file number, and I did not hear him say that he did not show the document to anyone. He said that he had not shown it to anyone outside this chamber. He was waving a document around to Senator Schacht and Senator Evans, so I think he should explain whether or not he did show it to those two people.

If he did not reveal the number, we are still left with the fact that the tax file number has not been disclosed to a single person. It is not on the public record. No-one knows it, unless the other unidentified, flying Labor senator somehow went out and told someone and we do not know about it. Senator Evans says he does not know who has seen it. Where is the publication? Where is there a skerrick of evidence that anyone has actually seen the tax file number? So the question of whether Dr Macdonald has suffered a detriment is one issue. Clearly, if no-one knows his tax file number, you can hardly say that he has suffered gravely.

The more important issue relates to the wording of the censure motion and why it is so fundamentally flawed. You will note very carefully that the motion does not allege that there was anything wrong with Senator Baume bringing to the attention of the electors of Manly the fact that their member of parliament had understated his income by in excess of $100,000. We have not had any complaint made about that; it is not mentioned in this motion.

All this motion does is continue to complain that, by drawing attention to the tax file number identified therein, a criminal offence was committed. How can you be guilty of a criminal offence if you did not know that the tax file number was there and you did not intend to commit an offence? It is a very simple proposition, and I would have thought that Senator Evans would know it. That is why his conduct of going through this charade of making very serious allegations is reprehensible to the extreme.

I could understand it if you had wanted to complain and say, `These are the sorts of tactics we wouldn't use. They are dirty tricks.' But you have not done that. You have come in here and solemnly alleged that a criminal offence has been committed. There is not a skerrick of evidence to support that. The facts simply do not stack up. That is why you have grossly overplayed your hand. As Senator Hill quite rightly pointed out, you waffle on about all this nonsense of Senator Baume having `incompletely informed the Senate as to the nature of the documents'. What is the nature of the documents? The documents are a tax assessment indicating the underpayment of income. There has been no incomplete information to the Senate as to the nature of those documents.

What you are presumably intending to try to convey is that you did not point out that there was a tax file number on it. We have heard Senator Baume say that he was not aware of it at the time. Then the complaint is that he did it `without the Senate being aware of that consequence'. Who is the Senate? The Senate comprises individuals. Only Senator Baume, Senator Forshaw and another unidentified senator know anything about this matter. How is the Senate unaware of the consequence? What is the consequence? Is it the consequence of the number being circulated to two senators? It is an absolute nonsense. Just to show how fraudulent this whole exercise is, you end up with this proposition: that the Privileges Committee should inquire and report into:

SPEECH.PARA: if the action of Senator Baume could not be held to be a contempt under the law as it presently stands, whether such action should be able to be held to be a contempt.

In other words, the government is saying to the Privileges Committee, `Look at it and see whether he has committed a crime. If he hasn't, tell us how we can show that he did, after all, commit one.' Kafka would have loved that. You are really saying, `By hook or by crook, by whatever means or facts, we want to demonstrate that somehow or other Senator Baume is guilty of contempt, and, if necessary, we will change the law.' It is an appalling abuse of this chamber to come in here and solemnly pretend—and I trust that the Democrats and the Greens will reflect very carefully on this—that, if you allege criminal intent, you have to make out your case. Yet what did Senator Evans—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Baume would know all about that, wouldn't he? And a few of the others over there would know about it too, wouldn't they? You would know all about integrity, wouldn't you? You would know all about honesty, wouldn't you?

—I know you do not understand and are not interested in the finer principles of criminal law. But I hope that if you ever found yourself in a court of law—as Senator Loosley once did—you would be very anxious to ensure that every aspect of the law is carefully scrutinised and that every aspect of an offence is made out before you are convicted. That has to be your most basic and sacred right. Yet, do you know what Senator Evans said across the chamber? He said, `It could be negligent, it could be reckless or it could be deliberate.' I hope Senator Loosley is listening to this. In support of the allegation that this constituted a criminal offence, Senator Evans said, `It could be negligent, it could be reckless or it could be deliberate.' Indeed, there was a fair bit of banter about the fact that this was obviously reckless behaviour.

PARA.TAB: We all know that negligence does not constitute a criminal offence. That is a civil matter—it is breach of duty and negligence. I would not have thought that you would have had to even studied law to understand the difference between a civil burden of proof and a criminal burden of proof. Nor would you have to be terribly smart to understand that you cannot commit a criminal offence simply because you are negligent.

So why would Senator Evans have even got himself into that impossible situation of logic? Do you know what he then said when he was absolutely cornered? He said, `Of course he deliberately put the paper on the public record.' In other words, the mere fact that somehow he did not accidentally put the paper on the public record—that he tabled it—is supposed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that he had a criminal intent to disclose a tax file number of which he was not aware. It is an absolute nonsense, and that is why it is a fraudulent case.

It is a classic example of a trumped up charge. You are absolutely desperate to change the subject. You do not want the people of Australia to focus on your legislation or your record. You come in here with plenty of hand wringing. Senator Faulkner threw a pink fit the other day about how urgent it was and, therefore, we had to negate the adjournment for three out of four nights to debate legislation which he never demonstrated was in the slightest bit urgent.

Nonetheless, what do we have here? Quite clearly, we have people prepared to do the bidding of the Prime Minister, who of course has an absolute obsession with Senator Baume. He is determined to get him by hook or by crook. He has sued him for defamation. He will stoop to any level. He is pursuing him remorselessly and relentlessly inside this parliament and out. He calls him `swill', a `low life' and all those words that he is perfectly happy to trot out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because he was forced to sell out of the piggery.

—I think we all understand what is going on about the piggery. I am sure one day the full truth will come out—just as it might come out one day about the extent to which Warren Anderson might have been very helpful during the 1980s. The fact remains that the Prime Minister is absolutely obsessed with Senator Baume. That is what this is about.
—Where is the evidence?
—Read the August 1986 National Times, sport.
—Where is it? The National Times!

—Read the National Times. There it is. Just read it. If you want to know, just read it and take note of the fact that the Prime Minister has never denied the very serious allegations contained in that document. That is what this about.

PARA.TAB: This is not in any way a legitimate attempt to demonstrate that a senator in this chamber has been guilty of a criminal offence. This is worded in such a way as to make it clear that you do not even have a case. You complain that he did not draw attention to the tax file number identified therein. It is such a manifest logical inconsistency to say that whether or not you knew about something you failed in your duty by not drawing it to someone's attention, to say that merely because there was an unauthorised disclosure you must have committed a criminal offence.

Let us take someone who has a bunch of tax files on the back seat of his car and the car is broken into. Is he guilty because there was an unauthorised disclosure? Of course he is not. If you left them in the pub and someone got hold of them, that is an unauthorised disclosure. Are you guilty of a criminal offence? Of course you are not. The only way in which you can be guilty of a criminal offence is if you intended to break the law. There is not a scintilla of evidence to suggest that Senator Baume intended to do that—in fact, quite the contrary.

That is why I think not only Senator Harradine but also, I am sure, other members of this chamber who are not simply locked into slavishly following the tactics adopted by Senator Evans on this occasion will take this matter with the utmost seriousness and will not be confused by issues of whether or not you would personally have chosen to disclose matters. John Fahey might have agreed not to but there is nothing at all to suggest that John Fahey told Senator Baume not to do what he did, nor is there a skerrick of evidence to suggest that Senator Baume was aware of that agreement. So how, again, could you possibly hold that against Senator Baume?

Yet, once again, you trot out the fact that the New South Wales Premier publicly stated he had been aware of the matter and undertaken not to raise it. So what? It has nothing whatsoever to do with Senator Baume's behaviour unless Senator Baume was aware of that agreement and deliberately breached it, and the evidence is quite to the contrary.

Similarly, Senator Evans did not repeat Peter Macdonald's utterly defamatory allegation that John Fahey had put Michael Baume up to it. What is the basis for saying something like that? You cannot just wave these things around. Quite clearly, you have to look at the facts and the facts here point in only one direction. There is no case to answer. There is not even the basis of a prima facie case in terms of the criminal law.

I would be absolutely amazed to hear Senator Loosley argue that Senator Evans did not do anything other than get it fundamentally wrong when he said that there was sufficient evidence of deliberateness by merely putting papers on the public record. That is tawdry; that is desperate. It is basically despicable because it demonstrates that you have no genuine interest in pursuing the matter. You are simply wanting to raise the political heat.

You don't like the way Senator Baume has pursued with great vigour, and I think very properly indeed, issues of conflict of interest arising out of a Prime Minister who spends half a million dollars which he got from nowhere buying an interest in a piggery when he of course is in a supreme position to make decisions that will influence the outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's another example of your hypocrisy.
—Why don't we go back to the print media inquiry. You were on the print media inquiry. Do you remember what the Prime Minister said there about balanced coverage?
—We remember what you did. Issue a press statement; go on.

—You do. If you do remember, you'll realise that the Prime Minister will stop at absolutely nothing. What he is not stopping at here is any low trick that will nobble Senator Baume. It has nothing to do with the conduct of Senator Baume. That is why the criminal law is fundamentally important. The protection of the courts must be available to all citizens.

PARA.TAB: To think that somehow this chamber could seriously be asked to effectively convict and refer a matter to the Privileges Committee based on evidence which even the mover of the motion concedes does not amount to a deliberate intent to commit a criminal offence—there is no evidence of breaching the law—and to say that because he might have acted recklessly and that somehow that supports a serious charge of committing an offence punishable by two years imprisonment is ludicrous in the extreme.

Recklessness might come into felony/ murder. It might come into murder per se. It certainly does not come into a commission of an offence of this nature and nor does negligence. The fact that Senator Evans had to fall back on those sorts of shabby defences I think demonstrates the hollowness of the argument. I do not want to take up the time of the Senate any longer other than to say this motion will be condemned for what it is worth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The New South Wales election on 25 March was always going to be very, very close. It is very clear from the Liberal campaign in the last week or so that Manly was going to be absolutely pivotal in so far as the Liberal assessment was concerned about its fortunes. So a week or so out there was a massive blitz in Manly of direct mail from Nick Greiner. Two days later we had John Fahey appear—again, a concerted Liberal focus on Manly. It assumed a crucial significance to the conservative campaign. Then of course 24 hours out, in an act of desperation, Senator Baume launched a violent personal attack upon the sitting Independent member, Dr Macdonald.

PARA.TAB: All of this was poll driven. It was driven by Liberal Party internal polling. The reason I can say that with great confidence tonight in the Senate is that yesterday over lunch Senator Baume boasted that, before his attack on Dr Macdonald, Dr Macdonald had a five per cent lead. This disappeared of course after the attack. The unfortunate thing from Dr Macdonald's point of view was that he had precious little time in which to respond. This was poll driven. It was a deliberate tactic by the New South Wales Liberal Party to take the seat of Manly from the sitting Independent.

Over recent times we have seen different tactics from the American Republican Party imported into this country. We have seen push polling in the ACT. We have seen negative ads, built upon negative ads until they constituted the entire campaign. We have seen inflammatory direct mail. We have seen unsubstantiated allegations. We have seen the tendency on the part of the Liberal Party, particularly in New South Wales, to divinise opponents; now we arrive at the situation where Senator Baume seeks to criminalise opponents. That was the intent of the attack upon Dr Macdonald on the last day or so prior to the New South Wales general election, to accuse the sitting Independent member, Dr Macdonald—I think he will be returned; on the count today it looks like he will be returned—of having been guilty of at best gross negligence in terms of his taxes and at worst criminal offences.

The act of putting all that detail into the public record here in the Senate chamber, regardless of whether or not the tax file number was obvious and published, is appalling by any standard. I regard it as an honour to serve in this place. I regard it as a privilege. I think everybody ought to regard it as a privilege. All of us have responsibilities and obligations here. This kind of activity lowers the Senate by way of its performance. It is a stain upon the chamber.

The indignity of what was inflicted upon Dr Macdonald is compounded by the fact that two New South Wales Liberals have actually been convicted of tax offences. This is not a matter that had been canvassed in the parliament in Macquarie Street or here. But they have been before the courts. It was a matter of public record. We have the Smiles affair and the Metherell affair—people convicted of tax offences. These were not false allegations as they turned out to be in respect of Dr Macdonald.

By the way, senator, you are known fondly over here as `Senator Own Goal'. As a consequence of what you have done I think you will become known as `Senator Own Government'. I think you have done your own government in New South Wales. By your action one of two things is likely to happen. Either Dr Macdonald is likely never to look favourably upon the New South Wales Liberal Party again or, alternatively, is likely to hold the seat forever, or as long as he wants it, courtesy of what you have done because now the allegation has been proven to be absolutely and utterly false.

Of course a pattern of deceit is obvious in opposition ranks—a pattern of deceit that began with push polling. It began some weeks ago with the personal denigration of the ALP candidate in the Canberra by-election, Sue Robinson. Again, that was poll driven. Then we had the opening of private mail and sensitive Aboriginal documents in the Hindmarsh Island affair—acts of deception and duplicity again. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Theft by Employee of Pacific Power

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to raise the case of Mr Steven Garden. I wish to put on the record first of all the facts of the case.
—Are you going to reveal his tax file number too?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I think Senator Murphy made a reflection on Senator Woods by asking if he was going to reveal this employee's tax file number, and I think he should be asked to withdraw it.
—Senator Panizza, are you saying that there was a remark that was against the standing orders? Could you clarify that for me?
—Yes, that Senator Woods may be dropping a tax file number; so Senator Murphy should withdraw his comment
—I do not see that there is anything contrary to the standing orders, even if the interjection were made. I ask Senator Woods to continue his speech.

—Steven Garden was an employee of the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, which was trading as Pacific Power. He had been an employee since about 1980. In January 1992, by his own admission, he stole scaffolding from Pacific Power valued at around $300. He was subsequently apprehended by the police as he was hiding the scaffolding in the bush. Again, by his own admission, he lied to police on several occasions about exactly what he was doing with this scaffolding as he was secreting it away, having transported it there in one of Pacific Power's own vehicles. Subsequently, he pleaded guilty in the relevant court to a charge of larceny as a servant. Because of his previous good character, no conviction was recorded.

PARA.TAB: On the basis of this theft from the Electricity Commission, Pacific Power decided it would sack Mr Steven Garden. On the face of it, it seemed like a very reasonable thing to do. Mr Steven Garden subsequently appealed to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission and the matter was heard by one of the counsellors, and the decision from the counsellor at the time was that Mr Garden should be reinstated with back pay for some 13 months. The matter was then appealed to the full commission, and the full commission endorsed the decision of the individual commissioner.

You have to ask yourself: why is this the case? On the face of it, it does seem pretty crazy that somebody who pleaded guilty in the courts to stealing from his employers—was found guilty by his own admission—and was sacked for stealing from his employers, was ordered to be reinstated. The reasons given by the commission and confirmed were that the theft was, in fact, community minded. It was community minded apparently because Mr Steven Garden had stolen the scaffolding because he wanted to make use of it for his local surf club. This is community mindedness being taken to an extreme.

I was always a great fan of the Robin Hood principle of stealing from the rich and giving to the poor. In the time of Robin Hood we had serfs and vassals, and effectively slaves, stealing from, raping, pillaging and plundering lords of the manor. Sometimes the bills from Pacific Power get a bit high, but I do not think you can put them in the plunging, pillaging and raping category and, indeed, I do not think you can put Mr Steven Garden into the category of a vassal or a serf.

I guess the question we have to ask is: where does this actually lead us? If the Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales or elsewhere is going to take the view that theft is okay—and not only turn a blind eye to it but actually condone it and, indeed, in some ways, endorse it because it is community minded—what happens if somebody pinches a video cassette recorder to take it to the local spastic centre, for example? Where does this end? Is it okay to steal a video cassette recorder because it is going to a worthy cause? It seems to me that this is theft, theft is a crime, and we should not in any way encourage individuals to commit a crime against anybody and particularly not against their employer.

There is a growing trend in Australia towards enshrining the so-called rights of workers at the expense of what really are the fundamental rights of employers, regardless of the facts. The federal industrial relations courts have, indeed, also been moving towards a position where the rights of workers to keep their jobs takes precedence over any wrongdoing, no matter how extreme it might be on the parts of those workers.

Until recently, the New South Wales IR commissioner had taken a much more rational approach, but this case clearly indicates that there are major aberrations in the New South Wales systems. This is a clear example of a case where people who have been sacked have been reinstated in defiance of all reason and rationality. It is not as if it is a minor amount; it is over $300. The fact is that this is clearly ridiculous because the person concerned was found guilty by the courts and was reinstated because he was doing this for a good cause. Where do you stop? The next situation is that employees could steal anything belonging to their employers and expect to keep their jobs if the reasons in this case were to apply elsewhere.

It seems to me that this situation is completely untenable. It means presumably that bosses never have the right to sack any staff no matter what they do in the workplace. If you carry this to its logical end, it means that those caught robbing their employers will be able to get away with naming some community organisation as the alleged beneficiary of their actions, as a means of escaping either punishment or dismissal.

This decision obviously has trivialised and undermined a very vital part of our industrial relations system. It sends all the wrong signals to the workers who want to rip off the boss. It really does mean that our system is being turned on its head, and I am amazed not only that the decision was made in the first place but that it was confirmed by the full Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales. There is really now a situation where somebody who was previously a supervisor for Pacific Power—and, therefore, would be expected to give a better than average example of integrity and honesty and decency—stole from the company and Pacific Power has now been forced to reemploy this man, presumably in his same position.

The message he will give to the people working under him is simply this: you can steal from Pacific Power and get away with it. Not only do you not have a conviction recorded against you—which may well be reasonable in this case if his character really was as good as it apparently was—but you can actually get reinstated to your job and paid for the time you had off the job because you were sacked because you stole from your employers. It does seem to me to be crazy. If our industrial relations system is encouraging people to steal from their employers, where does this end? We have to maintain some sort of decency, integrity and values in our IR system. To condone and, indeed, to encourage this sort of behaviour is going to lead to all sorts of problems in the future.
